Revision of title. —

Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1, revised this title, amending and renumbering §§ 14-1-101 through 14-9-106 as §§ 14-1-101 through 14-7-104. No detailed explanation of the changes made by the 1978 Act has been attempted, but, where appropriate, historical citations to former provisions have been added to corresponding sections in this title, and annotations from cases decided under former provisions have been placed under comparable sections in this title where it was felt they will be helpful. For tables of revised and renumbered sections, see Volume 11 of the Wyoming Statues Annotated.

Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 2, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this Act to the extent that such acts are in conflict herewith.”

Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 3, provides: “This act is effective January 1, 1979.”

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Governmental tort liability for social service agency's negligence in placement, or supervision after placement, of children, 90 ALR3d 1214.

Actions under 42 USC § 1983 for violations of Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act (42 USC §§ 620 et seq. and 670 et seq.), 93 ALR Fed 314.

Library References.

Family Law and Practice § 33.02 (Matthew Bender).

Chapter 1 General Provisions

  • Article 1. In General
  • Article 2. Emancipation of Minors

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

42 Am. Jur. 2d Infants § 1 et seq.

43 C.J.S. Infants § 1 et seq.

Article 1. In General

  • § 14-1-101.  Age of majority; rights on emancipation.
  • § 14-1-102.  Right to contract.

§ 14-1-101. Age of majority; rights on emancipation.

  1. Upon becoming eighteen (18) years of age, an individual reaches the age of majority and as an adult acquires all rights and responsibilities granted or imposed by statute or common law, except as otherwise provided by law.
  2. A minor may consent to health care treatment to the same extent as if he were an adult when any one (1) or more of the following circumstances apply:
    1. The minor is or was legally married;
    2. The minor is in the active military service of the United States;
    3. The parents or guardian of the minor cannot with reasonable diligence be located and the minor’s need for health care treatment is sufficiently urgent to require immediate attention;
    4. The minor is living apart from his parents or guardian and is managing his own affairs regardless of his source of income;
    5. The minor is emancipated under W.S. 14-1-201 through 14-1-206 ;
    6. The minor is twelve (12) years of age or older, is a smoker or user of tobacco products and the health care to which the minor consents is a tobacco cessation program approved by the department of health pursuant to W.S. 9-4-1204 .
  3. The consent given pursuant to subsection (b) of this section is not subject to disaffirmance because of minority.
  4. Any competent adult may enter into a binding contract and shall be legally responsible therefor.
  5. A person who is at least eighteen (18) years of age may consent to donate and may donate blood.

History. Laws 1973, ch. 213, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 14-1.1, 16-3; W.S. 1977, §§ 14-1-101 , 16-3-101 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1981, ch. 26, § 1; 1982, ch. 62, § 1; 1986, ch. 20, § 1; 1989, ch. 207, § 2; 1993, ch. 1, § 1; 2006, ch. 114, § 1; 2009, ch. 198, § 1.

Cross references. —

For constitutional prohibition against local or special laws declaring any person of age, see art. 3, § 27, Wyo. Const.

As to minority being legal disability staying statute of limitations, see § 1-3-114 .

As to ineligibility of person under the age of majority to serve as administrator, see § 2-4-203 .

As to preference for appointment of guardian of minor, see § 3-2-107 .

For definition of “adult,” see § 8-1-102 .

As to minimum marriageable age, see § 20-1-102 .

As to minimum age to register to vote, see § 22-3-102 .

As to exclusion of minors under 18 years of age from definition of “employee” for purposes of minimum wage law, see § 27-4-201 .

As to service of subpoena not being made by any person under the age of 18 years, see Rule 45(b), W.R.C.P.

The 2006 amendment, deleted “or” at the end of (b)(iii).

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, added “any one (1) or more of the following circumstances apply” at the end of the introductory language of (b); added (b)(vi); and made a minor stylistic change.

Prospective operation. —

Laws 1973, ch. 213, § 4, provides: “This act shall operate prospectively only and shall not apply to existing court decrees, trusts, wills or other written documents.”

Severability. —

Laws 1973, ch. 213, § 5, provides: “If any provision of this act or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this act which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application and to this end the provisions of this act are declared to be severable.”

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3 provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Amendment applies prospectively. —

The legislature intended for the change in the age of majority made in 1993 to apply prospectively and not to apply to an existing court decree such as a child support order in a divorce decree; the district court erred in modifying the child support orders to reflect the new age of majority. Thomas v. Thomas, 913 P.2d 854, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1996).

Trial court properly granted a father's request to reduce his child support obligation when his eldest son turned 18-years-old and properly denied the mother's request to apply Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-1-101 as it existed when the parties were divorced, which would have extended the father's obligation until the children were 19-years-old, as the original divorce decree and settlement agreement did not specify a child support obligation for either parent. Jordan v. Brackin, 2003 WY 151, 79 P.3d 536, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 180 (Wyo. 2003).

Juvenile tried and sentenced as adult. —

Although son answered to criminal charges in district court, he remained a minor until he reached eighteen, the age of majority, and son's incarceration, standing alone, did not effect an emancipation; father was therefore not entitled to suspension or termination of his child support obligation. Garver v. Garver, 981 P.2d 471, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 84 (Wyo. 1999).

District court properly denied defendant's motion to correct an illegal sentence because he did not met his burden of proving that the statute under which he was sentence was cruel or unusual where he was 18 at the time he committed a double homicide, his sentence to two consecutive life sentences for first-degree murder was effectively a sentence of life without the possibility of parole, and the defining the age of majority as 19 did not do so for purposes of determining criminal culpability. Nicodemus v. State, 2017 WY 34, 392 P.3d 408, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 2017).

Parent has duty to support incapacitated child even though the child has reached the age of majority. Kamp v. Kamp, 640 P.2d 48, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 288 (Wyo. 1982).

Quoted in

McArtor v. State, 699 P.2d 288, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 481 (Wyo. 1985); Daniel v. State, 923 P.2d 728, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1996); Bagley v. Bagley, 2013 WY 126, 311 P.3d 141, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 131 , 2013 WL 5593300 (Oct 11, 2013).

Cited in

Jennings v. Jennings, 783 P.2d 178, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 239 (Wyo. 1989); KT v. State, 902 P.2d 1288, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 178 (Wyo. 1995).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Wyoming's Law of Decedents' Estates, Guardianship and Trusts: A Comparison with the Uniform Probate Code — Part IV,” see X Land & Water L. Rev. 155 (1975).

For comment, “The Institutional Transfer Statute: Three Challenges to the Imprisonment of Juvenile Offenders,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 643 (1982).

For article, “The Ungrateful Living: An Estate Planner's Nightmare — The Trial Attorney's Dream,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 401 (1989).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Enlistment, or consent to enlistment, of minor in military service as emancipating him, 36 ALR2d 1018.

Right of parent to maintain tort action against child, 60 ALR2d 1284, 62 ALR3d 1299.

Federal or state law as controlling question of representation of infant, 68 ALR2d 752.

Allowance from incompetent's estate to children, 99 ALR2d 946, 24 ALR3d 863.

Power to lease, or to authorize lease of, infant's lands beyond minority of guardianship, 6 ALR3d 570.

Liability for prenatal injuries, 40 ALR3d 1222.

Right of minor to have abortion performed without parental consent, 42 ALR3d 1397.

Right of child or parent to recover for alienation of the other's affections, 60 ALR3d 931.

Death action by or in favor of parent against unemancipated child, 62 ALR3d 1299.

Power of parent to have mentally defective child sterilized, 74 ALR3d 1224.

Statutory change of age of majority as affecting preexisting status or rights, 75 ALR3d 228.

Modern trends as to contributory negligence of children, 32 ALR4th 56.

Parent's or relative's rights of visitation of adult against latter's wishes, 40 ALR4th 846.

Post-secondary education as within nondivorced parent's child-support obligation, 42 ALR4th 819.

Infant's liability for medical, dental or hospital services, 53 ALR4th 1249.

Statute protecting minors in a specified age range from rape or other sexual activity as applicable to defendant minor within protected age group, 18 ALR5th 856.

§ 14-1-102. Right to contract.

  1. An unemancipated minor may obtain a birth certificate from the department of health and may enter into a legally binding contract for housing, employment, purchase of a motor vehicle, receipt of a student loan, admission to postsecondary school, establishing a bank account, admission to a domestic violence or homeless shelter and receipt of services as a homeless youth or victim of domestic violence or sexual abuse, provided that the minor:
    1. Meets all of the following:
      1. At least sixteen (16) years of age;
      2. Willingly living separate and apart from his parents who consent to or acquiesce in the separate living arrangement;
      3. Homeless;
      4. Managing his own financial affairs.
    2. Submits a notarized affidavit in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.
  2. A notarized affidavit required under this section shall be:
    1. Signed and sworn to by the minor which includes all of the following:
      1. The minor’s full name;
      2. The minor’s birth date;
      3. A statement by the minor verifying the conditions listed in paragraph (a)(i) of this section;
      4. A statement by the minor declaring that the information provided is true and correct under penalty of perjury.
    2. Witnessed by two (2) or more adults. The acknowledgment by each adult witnessing the affidavit shall include a declaration that he is an attorney, health care provider, rabbi, priest, minister, clergy or other religious counselor or a college or school administrator or counselor and that to the best of his knowledge the minor signed the affidavit willingly and understands the nature and legal implications of the contract, if applicable. The affidavit shall require a rabbi, priest, minister, clergy or other religious counselor who witnesses an affidavit to verify under penalty of false swearing under W.S. 6-5-303 that the witness has not been convicted of a felony in this state or another jurisdiction. An adult witnessing an affidavit pursuant to this paragraph shall not assume any legal responsibility or liability under a contract entered into pursuant to this section.
  3. A person that in good faith accepts an affidavit purportedly signed and sworn to in accordance with this section and who is without actual knowledge that the affidavit is fraudulent or otherwise invalid may rely upon the affidavit as if it were genuine and may enter into a contract that is legally binding upon the minor as provided under subsection (a) of this section.
  4. For purposes of this section, “homeless” means as that term is defined in 42 U.S.C. section 11434a(2).

History. Laws 2017, ch. 180, § 1.

Effective dates. —

Laws 2017, ch. 180, § 3, makes the act effective July 1, 2017.

Article 2. Emancipation of Minors

  • § 14-1-201.  Definitions.
  • § 14-1-202.  Application for emancipation decree; effect of decree.
  • § 14-1-203.  Application for emancipation decree; hearing; notice; rights and liabilities of emancipated minor; conditions for issuance of decree; filing of decree; copy to applicant.
  • § 14-1-204.  Third party application; procedure.
  • § 14-1-205.  Application to department of transportation for emancipated status on driver's license; fee.
  • § 14-1-206.  Emancipated minor subject to adult criminal jurisdiction.

§ 14-1-201. Definitions.

  1. As used in this article:
    1. “Emancipation” means conferral of certain rights of majority upon a minor as provided under this article and includes a minor who:
      1. Is or was married;
      2. Is in the military service of the United States; or
      3. Has received a declaration of emancipation pursuant to W.S. 14-1-203 .
    2. “Minor” means an individual under the age of majority defined by W.S. 14-1-101(a);
    3. “Parent” means the legal guardian or custodian of the minor, his natural parent or if the minor has been legally adopted, the adoptive parent;
    4. “This act” means W.S. 14-1-201 through 14-1-206 .

History. Laws 1989, ch. 207, § 1; 1990, ch. 7, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 14-1-202. Application for emancipation decree; effect of decree.

  1. Upon written application of a minor under jurisdiction of the court and notwithstanding any other provision of law, a district court may enter a decree of emancipation in accordance with this act. In addition to W.S. 14-1-101(b), the decree shall only:
    1. Recognize the minor as an adult for purposes of:
      1. Entering into a binding contract;
      2. Suing and being sued;
      3. Buying or selling real property;
      4. Establishing a residence;
      5. The criminal laws of this state.
    2. Terminate parental support and control of the child and their rights to his income;
    3. Terminate parental tort liability for the minor.

History. Laws 1989, ch. 207, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-1-201(a)(iv).

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Minor's entry into home of parent as sufficient to sustain burglary charge, 17 ALR5th 111.

§ 14-1-203. Application for emancipation decree; hearing; notice; rights and liabilities of emancipated minor; conditions for issuance of decree; filing of decree; copy to applicant.

  1. Upon written application of a minor subject to personal jurisdiction of the court, a district court may enter a decree of emancipation in accordance with this act. The application shall be verified and shall set forth with specificity all of the following facts:
    1. That he is at least seventeen (17) years of age;
    2. That he willingly lives separate and apart from his parents;
    3. That his parents consent to or acquiesce in the separate living arrangement;
    4. That he is managing his own financial affairs; and
    5. That the source of his income is not derived from means declared unlawful under state or federal law or from assistance received under W.S. 42-2-104 .
  2. The district court shall conduct a hearing on the minor’s application for emancipation within sixty (60) days after the date of filing. Notice of the hearing shall be given to the minor and his parents by certified mail at least ten (10) days before the date set for hearing.
  3. At the hearing, the court shall advise the minor of the effect of emancipation pursuant to W.S. 14-1-202 . These rights and liabilities shall be stated in the emancipation decree.
  4. The court may enter a decree of emancipation if the minor is at least seventeen (17) years of age and the court finds emancipation is in the best interests of the minor. In making a determination, the court shall consider if the:
    1. Minor’s parents consent to the proposed emancipation;
    2. Minor is living or is willing to live apart from his parents and is substantially able to provide self-maintenance and support without parental guidance and supervision;
    3. Minor demonstrates he is sufficiently mature and knowledgeable to manage his personal affairs without parental assistance; and
    4. Source of the minor’s income is not derived from means declared unlawful under state or federal law.
  5. Upon entry of a decree of emancipation, the court shall file the decree with the county clerk of the county in which the child resides. A copy of the decree shall be issued to the minor.
  6. A declaration of emancipation shall be conclusive evidence that the minor is emancipated, but emancipation may also be proved by other evidence like any other fact.

History. Laws 1989, ch. 207, § 1; 1996, ch. 111, § 2.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-1-201(a)(iv).

Child not emancipated. —

A child was not emancipated and, therefore, a noncustodial father was not relieved of his support obligation either by the mother's interference with visitation or by the entry of a temporary restraining order, which restrained the father from further contact with his daughter. Stone v. Stone, 7 P.3d 887, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (Wyo. 2000).

Child not emancipated for purposes of determining if support is due. —

Judgment for unpaid child support in post-decree action was affirmed because nothing under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-1-203(f) was shown to indicate the child was emancipated and, absent a sufficient record, the appellate court assumes that sufficient evidence exists to support the trial court's implicit finding that the child is not emancipated. McElwain v. McElwain, 2005 WY 147, 123 P.3d 558, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 2005).

Juvenile tried and sentenced as adult. —

Although son answered to criminal charges in district court, he remained a minor until he reached eighteen, the age of majority, and son's incarceration, standing alone, did not effect an emancipation; father was therefore not entitled to suspension or termination of his child support obligation. Garver v. Garver, 981 P.2d 471, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 84 (Wyo. 1999).

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

§ 14-1-204. Third party application; procedure.

  1. Any interested third party having dealings with an apparently emancipated minor may apply to the district court where that minor is domiciled or may be found for a declaration of emancipation.
  2. The application under this section shall be made in conformity with W.S. 14-1-203(a).
  3. Proceedings under this section shall be conducted in conformity with the requirements of W.S. 14-1-203 .

History. Laws 1989, ch. 207, § 1.

§ 14-1-205. Application to department of transportation for emancipated status on driver's license; fee.

  1. Upon application of an emancipated minor, the department of transportation shall indicate the minor’s emancipated status on his Wyoming driver’s license or if without a driver’s license, on the minor’s Wyoming identification card issued under W.S. 31-8-101 .
  2. An applicant under this section shall pay two dollars ($2.00) to the division. The department of transportation shall deposit the fees in the manner prescribed by law for driver’s license and identification card fees and submit receipt and acknowledgement to the state treasurer.

History. Laws 1989, ch. 207, § 1; 1991, ch. 241, § 3; 1993, ch. 1, § 1; 2015, ch. 12, § 1.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in the second sentence in (b), substituted “department of transportation” for “state treasurer” and added “and submit receipt and acknowledgement to the state treasurer.”

§ 14-1-206. Emancipated minor subject to adult criminal jurisdiction.

An emancipated minor is subject to jurisdiction of adult courts for all criminal offenses.

History. Laws 1989, ch. 207, § 1.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Sufficiency of evidence to establish parent's knowledge or allowance of child's sexual abuse by another under statute permitting termination of parental rights for “allowing” or “knowingly allowing” such abuse to occur, 53 ALR5th 499.

Library References.

Family Law and Practice §§ 20.05, 63.02 (Matthew Bender).

Article 1. Parentage; Paternity Actions

  • §§ 14-2-101 through 14-2-120.  [Repealed.]

Cross references. —

As to adoption, see chapter 22 of title 1.

Illegitimacy proceedings statutorily based. —

Illegitimacy or filiation proceedings are purely creation of statute since in common law an illegitimate child is considered the child of no one. Vigil v. Tafoya, 600 P.2d 721, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 457 (Wyo. 1979).

Chapter only statutory authority for determination of paternity.—

There is no common-law authority for the determination of paternity, and in this jurisdiction the only statutory authority therefor is found in this chapter. Blanton v. Warn, 444 P.2d 325, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 190 (Wyo. 1968).

Provisions authorizing parentage proceedings to be carefullyand strictly followed. —

Since common law gave a putative father no right of action but this article does give him a cause of action which permits him to establish the parent-child relationship, the sections which authorize the proceedings in such matters must be carefully and strictly followed in order to give effect to the intention of the legislature. In re TRG, 665 P.2d 491, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 337 (Wyo. 1983).

Parties. —

An agency cannot bring an action and then claim it is not a party. Department of family services (DFS) initiated the action, participated and exercised control over the proceedings, and was a real party in interest who stood to benefit from identifying the father; just because DFS was required by statute to bring this action is irrelevant to whether the agency is a party. Department of Family Servs., Div. of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs. v. DDM, 877 P.2d 259, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 81 (Wyo. 1994).

Paternity determinations made in divorce actions not subjectto provisions. —

The rules under this article do not apply where paternity of a child presumed to be a child of the marriage is determined by consent of the parties in a proceeding to modify a divorce decree to include a child conceived during the marriage but born afterward. CSP v. DDC, 842 P.2d 528, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 171 (Wyo. 1992).

Termination of parental rights in adoption proceedings. —

In an adoption proceeding, the provisions regarding termination of parental rights found in the adoption statutes (§ 1-22-101 et seq.) control over the more general provisions for the termination of parental rights found in this article. GWJ v. MH (In re BGH), 930 P.2d 371, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 187 (Wyo. 1996).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

41 Am. Jur. 2d Illegitimate Children § 1 et seq.

Mother's right to custody of illegitimate child, 98 ALR2d 417.

Right of putative father to visit illegitimate child, 15 ALR3d 887.

Discrimination on basis of illegitimacy as denial of constitutional rights, 38 ALR3d 613.

Right of putative father to custody of illegitimate child, 45 ALR3d 216.

Term “children” as used in beneficiary clause of life insurance policy as including illegitimate child, 62 ALR3d 1329.

Effect, in subsequent proceedings, of paternity findings or implications in divorce or annulment decree or in support or custody order made incidental thereto, 78 ALR3d 846.

Legitimation by marriage to natural father of child born during mother's marriage to another, 80 ALR3d 219.

Determination of paternity of child as within scope of proceeding under Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act, 81 ALR3d 1175.

Validity and construction of surrogate parenting agreement, 77 ALR4th 70.

Rights of unwed father to obstruct adoption of his child by withholding consent, 61 ALR5th 151.

14 C.J.S. Children out of Wedlock § 1 et seq.

Article 2. Rights and Obligations

  • § 14-2-203.  Parental tort liability for property damage of certain minors; exception; action cumulative.

  • § 14-2-205.  Presence of parent, custodian or guardian at hearings; failure to appear; issuance of bench warrant.
  • § 14-2-206.  Protection of parental rights.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

42 Am. Jur. 2d Infants §§ 36 to 44; 59 Am. Jur. 2d Parent and Child §§ 9 to 13, 16 to 56, 58 to 87; 62A Am. Jur. 2d Prenatal Injuries; Wrongful Life, Birth, and Conception § 1 et seq.

Constitutionality of gender-based classifications in criminal laws proscribing nonsupport of spouse or child, 14 ALR4th 717.

Sexual child abuser's civil liability to child's parent, 54 ALR4th 93.

Parent's right to recover for loss of consortium in connection with injury to child, 54 ALR4th 112.

Right of child to action against mother for infliction of prenatal injuries, 78 ALR4th 1082.

Prosecution of mother for prenatal substance abuse based on endangerment of or delivery of controlled substance to child, 70 ALR5th 461.

43 C.J.S. Infants §§ 5 to 119.

§ 14-2-201. Maintenance and education of minor out of income from own property.

Any minor having a living parent and owning property with income sufficient for his maintenance and education in a manner more expensive than his parent can reasonably afford, regard given to the situation of the parent’s family and to all circumstances of the case, the expenses of the minor’s education and maintenance may be defrayed out of the income of the minor’s own property in whole or in part, as judged reasonable and as directed by the court. The charges for maintenance and education may be allowed accordingly in the settlements of the accounts of the minor’s guardian.

History. Laws 1890-91, ch. 70, art. 21, § 11; R.S. 1899, § 4876; C.S. 1910, § 5745; C.S. 1920, § 7021; R.S. 1931, § 50-112; C.S. 1945, § 7-111; W.S. 1957, § 14-4; W.S. 1977, § 14-1-102 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

Quoted in

Bagley v. Bagley, 2013 WY 126, 311 P.3d 141, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Oct 11, 2013).

§ 14-2-202. Payment or delivery to parent of minor's estate not exceeding $3,000; duty of parent.

  1. Money or other property not exceeding three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) in value belonging to a minor having no guardian of his estate may be paid or delivered to a parent entitled to the custody of the minor to hold for the minor, upon written assurance verified by the oath of the parent that the total estate of the minor does not exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) in value. The written receipt of the parent shall be an acquittance of the person making the payment or delivery of money or other property.
  2. It is the duty of the parent to apply the funds received to the use and benefit of the minor.

History. Laws 1953, ch. 28, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-5; Laws 1965, ch. 40, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 14-1-103; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

§ 14-2-203. Parental tort liability for property damage of certain minors; exception; action cumulative.

  1. Any property owner is entitled to recover damages from the parents of any minor under the age of seventeen (17) years and over the age of ten (10) years who maliciously and willfully damages or destroys his property. The recovery is limited to the actual damages in an amount not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) in addition to taxable court costs. This section does not apply to parents whose parental custody and control of the child had been terminated by court order prior to the destructive act.
  2. The action authorized in subsection (a) of this section is in addition to all other actions which the owner is entitled to maintain and nothing in this section precludes recovery in a greater amount from the minor, parents or any person for damages for which the minor or other person would otherwise be liable. The purpose of this section is to authorize recovery from parents in situations where they would not otherwise be liable.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 73, §§ 1-3; W.S. 1957, §§ 14-5.1 to 14-5.3; W.S. 1977, §§ 14-1-104 to 14-1-106; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1991, ch. 65, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to sanctions for juvenile offenders, see § 14-6-247 .

Section is constitutional. Mahaney v. Hunter Enters., 426 P.2d 442, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Wyo. 1967).

Section compatible with supreme court policy. —

Because Wyoming has rejected the “family purpose” doctrine, this section does not fly in the face of the policy set by the supreme court. Mahaney v. Hunter Enters., 426 P.2d 442, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Wyo. 1967).

Father not liable. —

Father not liable for negligence where son took vehicle without knowledge or consent of father and not on mission for father. See Kimble v. Muller, 417 P.2d 178, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1966).

Quoted in

Campbell v. State, 709 P.2d 425, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 608 (Wyo. 1985); WJH v. State, 2001 WY 54, 24 P.3d 1147, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 2001).

Law reviews. —

For legislative comment, “Parental Tort Liability,” see I Land & Water L. Rev. 299 (1966).

For comments, “Wyoming Tort Reform and the Medical Malpractice Insurance Crisis: A Second Opinion,” see XXVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 593 (1993).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity and construction of statutes making parents liable for torts committed by their minor children, 8 ALR3d 612.

Parental liability for injury or damage intentionally inflicted by minor child, 54 ALR3d 974.

Criminal responsibility of parent for act of child, 12 ALR4th 673.

Modern trends as to tort liability of child of tender years, 27 ALR4th 15.

Construction and effect of statutes which make parent, custodian or other person signing minor's application for vehicle operator's license liable for licensee's negligence or willful misconduct, 45 ALR4th 87.

Jurisdiction or power of juvenile court to order parent of juvenile to make restitution for juvenile's offense, 66 ALR4th 985.

§ 14-2-204. Liability for support; right of action; venue; service; measure of recovery; remedies cumulative; execution; continuing jurisdiction; notice.

  1. Any person legally responsible for the support of a child who abandons, deserts, neglects or unjustifiably fails to support the child is liable for support of the child. It is no defense that the child was not or is not in destitute circumstances. For purposes of this section, a parent’s legal obligation for the support of his or her children, whether natural or adopted, continues past the age of majority in cases where the children are:
    1. Mentally or physically disabled and thereby incapable of self support; or
    2. Repealed by Laws 2000, ch. 1, § 2.
    3. Between the age of majority and twenty (20) years and attending high school or an equivalent program as full-time participants.
  2. Either of the parents of the child, the department of family services or any other person, agency or institution furnishing the physical care or support of the child may commence civil action for past and future child and medical support.
  3. The petition or complaint shall be filed in the district court of the county where the defendant resides, is found or has assets subject to attachment or execution. Service of process shall be as provided by the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure.
  4. The measure of recovery from the defendant is the reasonable value of the care or support, including medical support furnished to the child by the petitioner and the child support ordered pursuant to W.S. 20-2-303 , 20-2-304 , 20-2-307 and 20-2-311 . In addition, the court may make other suitable order for future care or support of the child. These remedies are cumulative and in addition to other remedies provided by law. Payments of future support shall be paid to the clerk of the district court.
  5. and (f) Repealed by Laws 2000, ch. 1, § 2.

History. Laws 1879, ch. 1, § 4; R.S. 1887, § 2285; R.S. 1899, § 3026; C.S. 1910, § 3963; C.S. 1920, § 5028; R.S. 1931, § 20-214; C.S. 1945, § 58-215; Laws 1953, ch. 134, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-18; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-104; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1989, ch. 182, § 1; 1991, ch. 161, § 3; 1993, ch. 197, § 1; 2000, ch. 1, §§ 1, 2; 2018, ch. 42, § 1.

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, in (d), substituted “W.S. 20-2-303 , 20-2-304 , 20-2-307 ” for “W.S. 20-2-303 through 20-2-305 , 20-2-307 .”

Cross references. —

As to enforcement of judgments, see chapter 17 of title 1.

As to service of process, see Rule 4, W.R.C.P.

Amendment applies prospectively. —

The legislature intended for the change in the age of majority made in 1993 to apply prospectively and not to apply to an existing court decree such as a child support order in a divorce decree; the district court erred in modifying the child support orders to reflect the new age of majority. Thomas v. Thomas, 913 P.2d 854, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1996).

Parent has duty to support incapacitated child even though the child has reached the age of majority. Kamp v. Kamp, 640 P.2d 48, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 288 (Wyo. 1982).

Support retroactive to birth. —

District court had statutory authority to award child support retroactively to date of child's birth. Thomas v. Thomas, 983 P.2d 717, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 111 (Wyo. 1999).

Father owed his children reasonable support from the date of their birth because the statute intended and recognized that child support would be collected retroactively in cases where a parent had abandoned a child and refused to participate in the support of the child. JAG v. State, 2002 WY 158, 56 P.3d 1016, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 179 (Wyo. 2002).

Support to end at age of majority. —

Trial court did not err in ordering child support to end when the child became 18 and in having deviated from the presumptive support level; although the parties were not aware of their son's learning disability at the time that the divorce decree, stated support would end once each child reached the age of 18, and the mother had forgiven the child support arrearages owed to her by the father. Shelhamer v. Shelhamer, 2006 WY 83, 138 P.3d 665, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 93 (Wyo. 2006).

Full-time participation in school. —

The trial court did not err in denying father's petition to terminate child support once his daughter reached the age of majority based on his contention that she was not a full-time participant in a high school or its equivalent, where the daughter's absences from school were due to medical conditions and where she took immediate steps to enroll in an alternative school once she was forced to leave high school. Cossette v. Cossette, 2003 WY 107, 76 P.3d 795, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Wyo. 2003).

Statutes permit award to state of child support and other expenses. —

Sections 14-2-101 through 14-2-204 are broad enough to permit an award, on the petition of the state, for child support owing the child's mother and other expenses. Holtz v. State, 847 P.2d 972, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1993).

Disabled and in high school 19-year-old entitled to support. —

As the divorcing parties' 19-year-old daughter was disabled and still attending high school, she was entitled to child support. Bagley v. Bagley, 2013 WY 126, 311 P.3d 141, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Wyo. 2013).

Interest, but not a penalty incurred on child support arrearages.—

Because child support arrears did not become a judgment by operation of law under the relevant statute, as the matter was not an action separate from the parties' divorce proceedings, but was initiated by a mother's motion to show cause that was filed in the original divorce action, the mother was not entitled to a 10 percent penalty. However, the delinquent amounts did bear interest by the relevant statute at a rate of 10 percent per year from the date of rendition. Rambo v. Rambo, 2017 WY 32, 391 P.3d 1108, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 2017).

Quoted in

Campbell v. State, 709 P.2d 425, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 608 (Wyo. 1985); Garver v. Garver, 981 P.2d 471, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 84 (Wyo. 1999).

Stated in

Redman v. Redman, 521 P.2d 584, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 199 (Wyo. 1974); Glandt v. Taylor, 920 P.2d 647, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 101 (Wyo. 1996).

Cited in

Lucas v. Strauser, 65 Wyo. 98, 196 P.2d 862, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (1948); Heather v. Delta Drilling Co., 533 P.2d 1211, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 138 (Wyo. 1975); State ex rel. Wyo. Workers' Comp. Div. v. Halstead, 795 P.2d 760, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 79 (Wyo. 1990); In re Adoption of G.A.R., 810 P.2d 113, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 61 (Wyo. 1991); Stone v. Stone, 7 P.3d 887, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (Wyo. 2000); Jordan v. Brackin, 2003 WY 151, 79 P.3d 536, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 180 (Wyo. 2003).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Status of Legal Abandonment in Wyoming,” see 8 Wyo. L.J. 205.

For article, “Observations and Suggestions Concerning Wyoming Statutes Relating to Adoption Based on Abandonment,” see 8 Wyo. L.J. 218.

For note, “Enforcement of Civil Liability for Nonsupport in the State of Wyoming,” see 8 Wyo. L.J. 227 (1954).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Maintenance of suit by child, independently of statute, against parent for support, 13 ALR2d 1142.

Presumption that child's clothes were furnished by parent, 61 ALR2d 1270.

Trust income or assets as subject to claim against beneficiary for child support, 91 ALR2d 262.

What voluntary acts, other than marriage or entry in military service, terminate parent's obligation to support, 32 ALR3d 1055.

Automobile or motorcycle as necessary for child, 56 ALR3d 1335.

Liability of parent for support of child institutionalized by juvenile court, 59 ALR3d 636.

Parent's obligation to support unmarried minor child who refuses to live with parent, 98 ALR3d 334.

Child's right of action for loss of support, training, parental attention or the like, against a third person negligently injuring parent, 11 ALR4th 549.

Post-secondary education as within nondivorced parent's child-support obligation, 42 ALR4th 819.

Stepparent's postdivorce duty to support stepchild, 44 ALR4th 520.

Postmajority disability as reviving parental duty to support child, 48 ALR4th 919.

Rights and obligations resulting from human artificial insemination, 83 ALR4th 295.

Parent's child support liability as affected by other parent's fraudulent misrepresentation regarding sterility or use of birth control, or refusal to abort pregnancy, 2 ALR5th 337.

Death of obligor parent as affecting decree for support of child, 14 ALR5th 557.

Enforcement of claim for alimony or support, or for attorneys' fees and costs incurred in connection therewith, against exemptions, 52 ALR5th 221.

Validity, construction, and application of Child Support Recovery Act of 1992 (18 U.S.C. § 228), 147 ALR Fed 1.

§ 14-2-205. Presence of parent, custodian or guardian at hearings; failure to appear; issuance of bench warrant.

  1. It is the responsibility of one (1) or both parents, and the guardian or custodian of an unemancipated minor, if applicable, to appear with the minor before any court of this state in any proceeding in which the minor is required to appear and is alleged to have committed a criminal offense or to have violated a municipal ordinance. It shall be the responsibility of the court to afford any parent, guardian or custodian appearing with a minor pursuant to this subsection a reasonable opportunity to address the court.
  2. In any proceeding in juvenile court, attendance of one or both parents, and the guardian or custodian of the minor, if applicable, shall be compelled as provided by W.S. 14-6-215 .
  3. In a proceeding in a court other than the juvenile court, the presiding judge may require the presence of one or both parents, and the guardian or custodian of the minor, if applicable, at any hearing by causing an order to appear to be served in the manner provided by W.S. 14-6-214 .
  4. Any person served with an order to appear under subsection (c) of this section who without reasonable cause fails to appear, is liable for contempt of court and the court may issue a bench warrant to cause the person to be brought before the court.

History. Laws 1999, ch. 185, § 1.

§ 14-2-206. Protection of parental rights.

  1. The liberty of a parent to the care, custody and control of their child is a fundamental right that resides first in the parent.
  2. The state, or any agency or political subdivision of the state, shall not infringe the parental right as provided under this section without demonstrating that the interest of the government as applied to the parent or child is a compelling state interest addressed by the least restrictive means.

History. Laws 2017, ch. 188, § 1.

Effective Dates. — Laws 2017, ch. 188, § 2, makes the act effective July 1, 2017.

Due process.—

Applicability.—

Due process.—

Supreme court considered a father’s argument that he was deprived of due process in the juvenile proceedings even though it was not raised below because given the close connection between procedures required in the early stages of a child protection action and the cessation of reunification efforts, the issue was of a fundamental nature; however, because the father did not address the issue to the juvenile court, the supreme court’s review was limited to a search for plain error. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

Applicability.—

It was not an abuse of discretion to order supervision of a father’s visitation because (1) the father’s statutory right to associate with the children did not apply, (2) the evidence supported findings that the father abused the children, and (3) the evidence supported findings conditioning the father’s unsupervised visitation on the father’s and the children’s therapy. Johnson v. Johnson, 2020 WY 18, 458 P.3d 27, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 2020).

Article 3. Termination of Parental Rights

  • §§ 14-2-301 through 14-2-307.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-2-308.  Definitions.
  • § 14-2-309.  Grounds for termination of parent-child relationship; clear and convincing evidence.
  • § 14-2-310.  Parties authorized to file petition.
  • § 14-2-311.  Contents of petition.
  • § 14-2-312.  Hearing; appointment of guardian ad litem.
  • § 14-2-313.  Service of petition.
  • § 14-2-314.  Social study required; information to be shown; not excluded as hearsay.
  • § 14-2-315.  Order terminating the parent-child legal relationship; contents.
  • § 14-2-316.  Dismissal of petition; continuation of hearing.
  • § 14-2-317.  Effect of order of termination.
  • § 14-2-318.  Costs of proceedings; appointment of counsel.
  • § 14-2-319.  Determination of indigency; recovery of payment.

Cross references. —

For Child Custody Act, see chapter 5 of title 20.

As to appointment of guardians ad litem, see Rule 17(c), W.R.C.P.

Right to associate with one's family is fundamental liberty. DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980).

But state may regulate and terminate parental rights in proper cases and upon valid grounds. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976); DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980).

Ad hoc evaluation of parental rights terminations. —

No two cases as to termination of parental rights are alike, and each must be decided on the basis of its own individual facts. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976).

Strict construction and non-consenting parents. —

Article is strictly construed when proceeding is against nonconsenting parent and every reasonable intendment is made in favor of that parent's claims. DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980).

Termination proceeding requires service of process. —

The termination of parental rights under §§ 14-2-308 through 14-2-319 is an independent legal proceeding for which jurisdiction over the parents is independently required. Previous court proceedings involving an interim juvenile custody determination would not vest jurisdiction in the district court to take action under this article independent of compliance with the criteria for service on non-residents and application of the specific provisions of Rule 4, W.R.C.P. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Summary judgment not precluded. —

A termination of parental rights cannot generally be accomplished by summary judgment after a motion hearing. However, summary judgment is not necessarily precluded in every termination-of-parental-rights case, and the fundamental fairness and propriety of a particular procedure invoked in a termination proceeding may be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. In re Adoption of JLP, 774 P.2d 624, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1989).

Duty of reviewing court. —

The rule to apply under this article is that a reviewing court is not in a position to interpret and evaluate evidence but instead is obligated to determine whether or not such evidence presented is a substantial basis for the trial court's holding. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976).

Applied in

In re Adoption of GSD, 716 P.2d 984, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 521 (Wyo. 1986).

Law reviews. —

For note on medical aid for children without parental consent, see 8 Wyo. L.J. 88 (1958).

For note in termination of parental rights, see 8 Wyo. L.J. 185 (1959).

For comment, “The Wyoming Juvenile Court Act of 1971,” see VIII Land & Water L. Rev. 237 (1973).

For article, “Child Protection: A Suggested Role for Members of the Wyoming State Bar,” see IX Land & Water L. Rev. 187 (1974).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

39 Am. Jur. 2d Habeas Corpus § 82; 59 Am. Jur. 2d Parent and Child §§ 16, 29 to 31, 36 to 50.

Physical abuse of child by parent as ground for termination of parent's right to child, 53 ALR3d 605.

Sexual abuse of child by parent as ground for termination of parent's right to child, 58 ALR3d 1074.

Right, in child custody proceedings, to cross-examine investigating officer whose report is used by court in its decision, 59 ALR3d 1337.

Parent's involuntary confinement, or failure to care for child as result thereof, as evincing neglect, unfitness, or the like in dependency or divestiture proceeding, 79 ALR3d 417.

Right of indigent parent to appointed counsel in proceeding for involuntary termination of parental rights, 80 ALR3d 1141.

Admissibility of social worker's expert testimony on child custody issues, 1 ALR4th 837.

Initial award or denial of child custody to homosexual or lesbian parent, 6 ALR4th 1297.

Validity of state statute providing for termination of parental rights, 22 ALR4th 774.

Admissibility at criminal prosecution of expert testimony on battering parent syndrome, 43 ALR4th 1203.

Parent's transsexuality as factor in award of custody of children, visitation rights or termination of parental rights, 59 ALR4th 1170.

67A C.J.S. Parent and Child § 4.

§§ 14-2-301 through 14-2-307. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 1955, ch. 169, §§ 1 through 6, related to termination of parental rights. For present similar provisions, see §§ 14-2-308 through 14-2-319 .

§ 14-2-308. Definitions.

  1. As used in this act:
    1. “Abuse” means as defined by W.S. 14-3-202(a)(ii);
    2. “Authorized agency” means:
      1. A public social service agency authorized to care for and place children; or
      2. A private child welfare agency certified by the state for such purposes pursuant to W.S. 14-6-201 through 14-6-243 , 14-4-101 through 14-4-116 , 1-22-101 through 1-22-114 ;
    3. “Child” or “minor” means an individual who is under the age of majority;
    4. “Court” means the district court in the district where the child resides or is found or the district court which has previously retained jurisdiction of the child because of a previous order entered by that court;
    5. “Mental health professional” means a person with an advanced degree in one of the behavioral sciences including a psychologist, social worker or clinical counselor;
    6. “Neglect” means as defined by W.S. 14-3-202(a)(vii);
    7. “Parent” means a natural parent or a parent by adoption;
    8. “Indigent party” means a person whose financial resources and income are insufficient to enable him to pay the reasonable fees and expenses of an attorney licensed to practice in this state;
    9. “This act” means W.S. 14-2-308 through 14-2-319 .

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1985, ch. 86, § 2; 2000, ch. 48, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Clear and convincing evidence. —

Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure do apply to proceedings for termination of parental rights, and an entry of default can be entered by the clerk against the delinquent parent; however, a default judgment that terminates the rights of the parent cannot be entered by the district court without (1) holding the required hearing; and (2) Wyoming's Department of Family Services presenting clear and convincing evidence of the grounds to terminate the parental rights, all in accordance with the termination of parental rights statutes. If the court finds that a statutory basis for termination has been established by clear and convincing evidence, it can then terminate the parent-child legal relationship. In re HLL, 2016 WY 43, 372 P.3d 185, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 2016).

DFS is “authorized agency”. —

Department of Family Services (DFS), a public social service agency, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 9-2-2101(a), with authority to oversee the custody and care of children in cases of abuse and neglect under the Child Protection Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-3-401 through 14-3-441 , was an “authorized agency” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-2-308 and 14-2-310 with authority to file a petition to terminate a mother's parental rights, even though DFS did not have custody of the children. State v. DH (In the Interest of LB), 2014 WY 10, 316 P.3d 1184, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 2014).

Applied in

LM v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs., 2007 WY 189, 171 P.3d 1077, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 201 (Dec. 5, 2007).

Stated in

Michael v. Hertzler, 900 P.2d 1144, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 136 (Wyo. 1995).

Cited in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982); SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (2005); DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017); DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

§ 14-2-309. Grounds for termination of parent-child relationship; clear and convincing evidence.

  1. The parent-child legal relationship may be terminated if any one (1) or more of the following facts is established by clear and convincing evidence:
    1. The child has been left in the care of another person without provision for the child’s support and without communication from the absent parent for a period of at least one (1) year. In making the above determination, the court may disregard occasional contributions, or incidental contacts and communications. For purposes of this paragraph, a court order of custody shall not preclude a finding that a child has been left in the care of another person;
    2. The child has been abandoned with no means of identification for at least three (3) months and efforts to locate the parent have been unsuccessful;
    3. The child has been abused or neglected by the parent and reasonable efforts by an authorized agency or mental health professional have been unsuccessful in rehabilitating the family or the family has refused rehabilitative treatment, and it is shown that the child’s health and safety would be seriously jeopardized by remaining with or returning to the parent;
    4. The parent is incarcerated due to the conviction of a felony and a showing that the parent is unfit to have the custody and control of the child;
    5. The child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the state of Wyoming for fifteen (15) of the most recent twenty-two (22) months, and a showing that the parent is unfit to have custody and control of the child;
    6. The child is abandoned at less than one (1) year of age and has been abandoned for at least six (6) months;
    7. The child was relinquished to a safe haven provider in accordance with W.S. 14-11-101 through 14-11-109 , and neither parent has affirmatively sought the return of the child within three (3) months from the date of relinquishment;
    8. The parent is convicted of murder or homicide of the other parent of the child under W.S. 6-2-101 through 6-2-104 ;
    9. The parent committed sexual assault and the child was conceived as a result of the sexual assault. For the purposes of this paragraph, the following shall apply:
      1. A person committed sexual assault if the person was convicted of an offense under W.S. 6-2-302 , 6-2-303 , 6-2-314 through 6-2-316 or other similar law of another jurisdiction;
      2. Reasonable effort to reunify the family is not required to terminate parental rights;
      3. This paragraph shall not apply if the parent seeking termination was married to or cohabiting with the parent committing the sexual assault resulting in the birth of the child for not less than two (2) years immediately after the birth of the child. Nothing in this subparagraph shall be construed as limiting a parent from seeking termination under another provision of this section or from seeking sole custody under title 20, chapter 5 of the Wyoming statutes.
  2. Proof by clear and convincing evidence that the parent has been convicted of any of the following crimes may constitute grounds that the parent is unfit to have custody or control of any child and may be grounds for terminating the parent-child relationship as to any child with no requirement that reasonable efforts be made to reunify the family:
    1. Murder or voluntary manslaughter of another child of the parent or aiding and abetting, attempting, conspiring to commit or soliciting such a crime; or
    2. Commission of a felony assault which results in serious bodily injury to a child of the parent. As used in this paragraph “serious bodily injury” means as defined by W.S. 6-1-104 .
  3. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, evidence that reasonable efforts have been made to preserve and reunify the family is not required in any case in which the court determines any one (1) or more of the following by clear and convincing evidence:
    1. The parental rights of the parent to any other child have been terminated involuntarily;
    2. The parent abandoned, chronically abused, tortured or sexually abused the child;
    3. The parent has been convicted of committing one (1) or more of the following crimes against the child or another child of that parent:
      1. Sexual assault under W.S. 6-2-302 through 6-2-304 ;
      2. Sexual battery under W.S. 6-2-313 ;
      3. Sexual abuse of a minor under W.S. 6-2-314 through 6-2-317 .
    4. The parent is required to register as a sex offender pursuant to W.S. 7-19-302 if the offense involved the child or another child of that parent. This shall not apply if the parent is only required to register for conviction under W.S. 6-2-201 ;
    5. Other aggravating circumstances exist indicating that there is little likelihood that services to the family will result in successful reunification.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1998, ch. 111, § 1; 1999, ch. 156, § 1; 2003, ch. 167, § 2; 2010, ch. 55, § 1; 2011, ch. 131, § 1; 2013, ch. 145, § 1; 2019, ch. 180, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to making reasonable efforts to preserve the family, see § 14-3-440 .

For disposition of children by court in granting divorce, see § 20-2-201 et seq.

As to desertion of children, see chapter 3 of title 20.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, added (a)(viii).

The 2011 amendment, in (a)(i), added the present last sentence.

Laws 2011, ch. 131, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 2, 2011.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, in (c), in the introductory language, added “any one (1) or more of the following,” added (iii) and (iv), and made related and stylistic changes.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, added (a)(ix).

Aggravating circumstances.—

Juvenile court abused its discretion by concluding the State had proven by clear and convincing evidence that aggravating circumstances existed that would make reunification between a father and a child unlikely because the facts did not establish severe misconduct toward child; the father was never charged with abuse or neglect of child, and he was taking drug tests and following the case plan so he could have visitation with the child. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

“Other circumstances” in subsection (v) must be different from those listed in the other provisions of subsection (c) and serious enough to warrant the degree of culpability or liability imposed; interpreting subsection (v) in harmony with the other provisions of subsection (c), the legislature logically meant for “other aggravating circumstances” to meet the same level of severity as set out in the preceding provisions. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

Failure to provide father with opportunity to be heard.

—

Supreme court considered a father’s argument that he was deprived of due process in the juvenile proceedings even though it was not raised below because, the issue was of a fundamental nature; the provision the State relied upon when requesting the juvenile court relieve the Department of Family Services of the duty to make reasonable efforts to reunify the father with the child was included within the statute setting out the procedure for termination of parental rights. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

In a termination of parental rights action, the trial court violated the father’s due process rights when it determined the best interests of the child without providing the father an opportunity to be heard. The hearing on summary judgment was limited to whether grounds for termination existed and there was no indication in the record that the related, and essential, issue of whether termination was in the best interests of the child was raised or considered. In re NRAE v. Dep't of Family Servs., 2020 WY 121, 472 P.3d 374, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 2020).

Evidence sufficient to sustain termination of parental rights under paragraphs (a)(v).

—

District court properly terminated a father’s parental rights to his children as an unfit parent because the Department of Family Services had custody of the children for 15 of the most recent 22 months preceding trial, the father’s history and pattern of behavior were plainly relevant to his current parental fitness, the jury could infer that the father participated in or knew about the mother’s drug use, and the father failed to complete almost every requirement of the case plan, failed to take any steps to assist with therapy and recovery of the children’s significant mental health needs, made no attempts to maintain a relationship with them when he left town, and used methamphetamine as recently as two months before the trial began. Clark v. State (In re GGMC), 2020 WY 50, 460 P.3d 1138, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 2020).

Evidence sufficient to sustain termination of parental rights under paragraphs (a)(v).—

Clear and convincing evidence supported the termination of a mother's parental rights on the ground that the mother was unfit to have custody and control of the mother's children, despite repeated exposure to substance abuse treatment and parenting classes, because the mother's behavior put the children at risk as the mother lived with roommates who had serious and lengthy criminal histories, participated with the roommates in distributing drugs, allowed drugs and pornography in the home, and drove while intoxicated with children in the car. LeBlanc v. State (In re ARLeB), 2017 WY 107, 401 P.3d 932, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 2017).

Mother was unfit to have custody or control of the mother’s children because the mother admitted that the children were in foster care under the State of Wyoming’s responsibility for well over 15 of the most recent 22 months. Furthermore, the State presented clear and convincing evidence that, at the time of trial, the mother was not able to meet the children’s physical, mental, or emotional needs, as the mother lost contact with the children and could not provide a positive, nurturing, or safe environment for them. 2019 WY 15, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 15 .

Termination of a mother’s parental rights was appropriate because the children were in foster care for more than the 15 of the last 22 months when the termination petition was filed, the children exhibited significant mental health problems and educational issues, the mother lacked contact with the children while they were in foster care, the mother could not meet the children’s needs, the mother never completed parenting and diagnosis-specific trainings, and the mother did not address the mother’s own mental and physical health concerns. Harmon v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re DKS), 2020 WY 12, 456 P.3d 918, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 2020).

Section 1-22-110 (adoption without consent) is not unconstitutional because it allegedly has different standards for terminating parental rights than this section. The two sections do not serve identical purposes. In re Adoption of RHA, 702 P.2d 1259, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 516 (Wyo. 1985).

Due process. —

Due to the fundamental nature of the rights affected by a termination action, the procedures involved must satisfy due process and the evidence supporting a termination must be clear and convincing. MB v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs. ex rel. LB, 933 P.2d 1126, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1997).

Department of family services failed to comply with affidavit requirements of W.R.C.P. 56(e) to such an extent that clear and convincing evidence standard, required for termination of mother's parental rights, was not met, and district court's failure to hold hearing before terminating mother's parental rights on summary judgment deprived her of due process. CAC v. Natrona County Dep't of Family Servs., 983 P.2d 1205, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 1999).

Guardian ad litem did not violate her duties or a mother's due process rights because she presented the child's preference to the jury and did not improperly argue that the jury had to decide the case based upon the child's best interests; the jury needed to know what was required to keep the child healthy and safe in order to determine if his health and safety would be seriously jeopardized if he were returned to the mother. Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

Guardian ad litem entitled to fully participate in termination case.—

Termination of parental rights cannot be based solely upon the best interests of the child, however, that does not mean that the guardian ad litem cannot participate in the evidentiary portion of the trial; the statutory provisions setting forth the requirements for termination of parental rights include factors directly related to the child's well-being. Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

State authorized to terminate parental rights under limited circumstances. —

The state has a compelling interest in the welfare of minor children and has the authority to terminate parental rights under certain limited circumstances, so long as it makes that determination in the best interest of the child and after a hearing. Blair v. Supreme Court of Wyoming, 671 F.2d 389, 1982 U.S. App. LEXIS 21745 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1982).

So long as there is reason to believe that a positive, nurturing parent-child relationship exists, the state's interest coincides with the parents' interest in preserving, not severing, family bonds. Once a parent has been proven unfit, however, the state's interest in terminating that parent's rights arises. In re Matter of GP, 679 P.2d 976, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 269 (Wyo. 1984).

Parental rights terminated due to domestic violence and other issues. —

Court properly terminated a father's parental rights where the child was subjected to domestic violence, and where the father failed to follow the case plan, failed to obtain consistent and adequate housing, and failed to visit the child as often as allowed. RS v. Dept. of Family Servs. (In re KLS), 2004 WY 87, 94 P.3d 1025, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 115 (Wyo. 2004).

Strict scrutiny required in considering evidence to terminate parental rights. —

It is a fundamental right for one to have custody of his minor child, and the court must, therefore, consider the evidence to terminate parental rights with strict scrutiny. In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

Justification for a decision to terminate parental rights by summary judgment encounters rules, including the strict scrutiny standard, because the fundamental liberty of familial association is first presented. Consequently, clear and convincing evidence is required. In re Eb, 795 P.2d 1212, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 1990).

Strict scrutiny standard requires that a case for termination of parental rights be established by clear and convincing evidence. LDC v. Department of Family Servs. (In re ZKP), 979 P.2d 953, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 1999).

Necessary to show that less intrusive means of protection attempted or impractical. —

It must be shown that less intrusive means of protecting the child (e.g., counseling the parents) have been attempted or are impractical, before parental rights are terminated. In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

Failure to follow departmental rules. —

Even though the trial court found clear and convincing evidence of facts sufficient to terminate parental rights, the failure of the department of family services to follow its own rules adversely affected the parent's fundamental rights and mandated reversal of the trial court's order of termination. MB v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs. ex rel. LB, 933 P.2d 1126, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1997).

Termination of a mother's parental rights under this section was not invalidated due to a decision not to place children with their maternal grandmother because the placement decision did not affect the mother's ability to visit the children or strengthen a relationship with them; moreover, that placement was unsuitable due to the grandmother's failure to cooperate and the fact that she lived with a convicted sex offender. In addition, the Wyoming Department of Family Services was not required to wait for a second home evaluation for the grandmother after she moved to a different state before commencing termination proceedings against the mother. K.H. v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re D.H.), 2007 WY 196, 173 P.3d 365, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (Wyo. 2007).

District court did not err when it denied a father’s motion for judgment as a matter of law because the failure of the Department of Family Services to comply with its rules and regulations was harmless; the late completion of the father’s case plan made no difference in the outcome because the father failed to meet the requirements of the case plan, and an earlier explanation of the conditions for visitation or of the case plan requirements would have changed the results. Anastos v. State (In re Asa), 2018 WY 5, 408 P.3d 791, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2018).

Incarceration. —

Termination of the father's parental rights to his children under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(iv) was proper because, while the record was clear that a police report was admitted into evidence, the supreme court did not need to determine whether a clear and unequivocal rule of law was violated because the father failed to prove that, if there was error, it was prejudicial. While the officer's report and testimony certainly informed the district court of the factual background regarding the allegations against father in the criminal case, his report and testimony were not necessary to establish that father was incarcerated due to a felony conviction; the father's own testimony established that to be the case, including that the crime was aggravated sexual assault of a minor. Msh v. Alh, 2012 WY 29, 271 P.3d 983, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Feb. 29, 2012).

Court committed no error in relying upon evidence of rehabilitative efforts in Oklahoma to sustain the requirement of unsuccessful efforts to rehabilitate the family (i.e., termination of parental rights is the least intrusive means to satisfy the state's interest), by concluding that the evidence of efforts in Oklahoma was clear and convincing on this issue. In In Interest of JG, 742 P.2d 770, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 509 (Wyo. 1987).

Subsection (a)(i) requires findings of both lack of support and lack of communication. In re Adoption of SLS, 808 P.2d 207, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 44 (Wyo. 1991).

Showing that child's well-being jeopardized required. —

Termination of parental rights cannot be ordered on the grounds of abuse or neglect unless the showing is clear and unequivocal that the child's health, mental or physical, and/or his social or educational well-being has actually been placed in jeopardy through the neglect or abuse by the parent. DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980) (decided under prior law).

Consideration of “best interests” of child. —

In considering a termination of the parent-child relationship under subsection (a)(i), the court may consider the best interests of the child only as those interests relate to support and communication. In re Parental Rights of SCN, 659 P.2d 568, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1983).

Burden of proving neglect or abuse is upon him who seeks to take the child from the parent. DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980) (decided under prior law).

Clear and convincing evidence. —

The case for termination of parental rights must be made by clear and convincing evidence. DKM v. RJS (In re SYM), 924 P.2d 985, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 143 (Wyo. 1996).

A father's parental rights were properly terminated where social services made appropriate efforts to reunify him with his child, they gave him notice of a change of goal for the case management, and they offered to pay transportation costs to visit the child and yet the father had no contact with the child for two years and never voluntarily paid child support despite court orders compelling him to do so. EBH v. Hot Springs Dep't of Family Servs., 2001 WY 100, 33 P.3d 172, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 2001).

There was clear and convincing evidence that it was in the best interests of a minor child to terminate the parents' rights to the child, since the parents failed to maintain a clean and healthy home for the child; the parents refused to properly feed and care for the child, resulting in health and developmental problems for the child; and the parents lacked stability to care for the child. SD v. Carbon County Dep't of Family Servs. (In re SED), 2002 WY 168, 57 P.3d 1235, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 195 (Wyo. 2002).

Jury could reasonably conclude that placing an eight-month-old baby in a fleece bag and tying it shut placed the child in imminent risk of physical injury under Wyo. Stat. §§ 14-3-202(a)(ii) and (vii), 14-2-309 . In re Cs v. Johnson County Dep't of Family Servs., 2006 WY 130, 143 P.3d 918, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 145 (2006).

Clear and convincing evidence supported the district court's decision to terminate the mother's parental rights under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(v) because it was undisputed that the children were in foster care for the 15 months preceding the termination hearing and the evidence tending to show that the mother was unfit was substantial. The evidence showed that: (1) the mother displayed an inability to monitor, to make healthy decisions regarding nutrition, or to provide a safe environment for her children; (2) she had a long-established history of surrounding herself and her children with unsafe individuals; (3) she experienced auditory hallucinations and paranoia; (4) she attempted to commit suicide in front of her children; (5) the children were upset with and resistant to visitation with their mother; and (6) the mother failed to complete various parts of her case plan and often refused to cooperate with service providers. M.L. v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs. (In the Interest of L.L.), 2007 WY 92, 159 P.3d 499, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 2007).

District court's decision terminating a mother's parental rights pursuant to Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(iii) (2007) was affirmed where the findings that the mother had not maintained a stable residence, been sporadically employed, continued substance abuse, and had made little progress in the treatment of her psychological problems were fully supported by evidence in the record. MDW v. Hot Springs County Dep't of Family Servs. (In re SRJ), 2009 WY 94, 212 P.3d 611, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 104 (Wyo. 2009).

Clear and convincing evidence supported the termination of a father's parental rights under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(v) for unfitness, because he had a child abuse conviction, was incarcerated, and had weapons violations; the father also failed to comply with a case plan requiring him to obtain employment, attending counseling, and participate in regular visitation. The Wyoming Department of Family Services was not required to prove that less intrusive alternatives to termination of his parental rights were impractical. AJJ v. State (In re KMJ), 2010 WY 142, 242 P.3d 968, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 153 (Wyo. 2010).

There was sufficient clear and convincing evidence to support termination of a father’s parental rights because he was unable to meet any of the child’s ongoing needs; the father was in prison at the time of the trial and did not anticipate being released on parole for more than a year, he admitted that he was found guilty of assault and battery on a son he had with another mother, and he had a history of substance abuse. Anastos v. State (In re Asa), 2018 WY 5, 408 P.3d 791, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2018).

District court correctly found clear and convincing evidence supported termination of a mother’s parental rights under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(v) (2019) where testimony from various Department of Family Services case workers, counselors, and the mother herself demonstrated a clear pattern of the inability to recognize and provide for the ongoing physical, mental and emotional needs of the children. Dunlap v. State (In re BAD), 2019 WY 83, 446 P.3d 222, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 85 (Wyo. 2019).

Evidence was sufficient to support termination of parental rights under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(iv) (2013) given the father's incarceration, alcohol consumption, and lack of responsibility for the child's schooling and medical needs. DRW v. DLP (In re ARW), 2015 WY 25, 343 P.3d 407, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 2015).

State not required to show reasonable efforts to reunify where abuse and neglect not at issue. —

State was not required to show reasonable efforts to reunify the family in a parental rights termination proceeding where the State did not file termination proceedings on the basis of abuse or neglect by a parent nor did the district court enter its order on that basis. Rather, the State filed termination proceedings, and the district court granted the petition, on the basis that the children were left in the care of another for at least a year and had been in foster care with the state for over fifteen of the last twenty-months, and the parents were unfit. SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs.(In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2005).

In a termination of parental rights proceeding, appellant mother failed to prove the Wyoming Department of Family Services (DFS) did not provide reasonable efforts under this section to rehabilitate her; DFS was not required to renew her drug testing contract because the mother appeared for testing infrequently and could have made her own arrangements for drug testing. Appellant had the opportunity but failed to attend team meetings; and DFS pursued less intrusive means of protecting the children such as a guardianship with relatives. TMC v. Dep't of Family Serv. (In re ARC), 2011 WY 119, 258 P.3d 704, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 2011).

Consent to county's custody of children did not constitute “provision for child's support” under subsection (a)(i). In re SKJ, 673 P.2d 640, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 399 (Wyo. 1983).

“Neglect” defined. —

“Neglect” is word of common usage and understanding and can certainly be defined as a failure to do what is needed or required in connection with a factual situation. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976) (decided under prior law).

Finding of “unintentional neglect” does not add ground for termination. —

A finding of “unintentional” neglect, although the word “unintentional” is not used in the statute, is not an addition of a ground for termination of rights constituting an amendment to this article by judicial legislation. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976).

Adoption proceedings. —

In an adoption proceeding, the provisions regarding termination of parental rights found in the adoption statutes (§ 1-22-101 et seq.) control over the more general provisions for the termination of parental rights found in this article. GWJ v. MH (In re BGH), 930 P.2d 371, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 187 (Wyo. 1996).

Mental incapacity. —

In finding the parents unable, because of mental incapacity, to give the child proper care now or in the future and that such inability constituted “neglect,” the courts are considering the best interests and welfare of a child rather than the penalizing of parents. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976).

Family doctor may give opinion on parent's mental age. —

In a case of unintentional neglect by mentally retarded parents, the family doctor with some mental health training and his own personal knowledge is as competent to reach an opinion as to mental age of a parent as is the expert witness whose examination will ordinarily cover a period of time not exceeding one week. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976).

Evidence of abuse by stepfather admissible to show evidence of neglect by mother. —
