In a proceeding to terminate parental rights on the grounds of neglect, admitting the evidence of a bruise, spanking and abuse by the stepfather was not an abuse of discretion, for if a stepfather or another abuses a child, it is evidence of neglect if the mother does not take some action to stop the abuse or remove the child from the abusive environment. MS v. Kuchera, 682 P.2d 982, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 290 (Wyo. 1984).

Summary judgment improper. —

Summary judgment order terminating parental rights was not appropriately granted where the affidavit of the mother denying abandonment raised a clear factual conflict, especially in light of the strict scrutiny and clear and convincing evidence required for parental rights termination. In In Interest of SVG, 826 P.2d 237, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1992).

Evidence sufficient to terminate parental rights under subsection (a)(iii). —

See In re SKJ, 673 P.2d 640, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 399 (Wyo. 1983).

Father's parental rights to his daughter were properly terminated under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(iv) where given the length of the father's term of incarceration, it was extremely improbable that the father would ever be able to appropriately care for the ongoing physical, mental, or emotional needs of his daughter during her minority or indeed well into her adulthood; most importantly, though, the father was convicted on several counts of sexually abusing his daughter. There could be nothing that made him more intrinsically unfit than abusing his child. CDB v. DJE, 2005 WY 102, 118 P.3d 439, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 123 (Wyo. 2005).

Termination of parental rights was justified by evidence of children's inadequate care, maintenance and supervision, as well as inappropriate physical punishment, and where agencies' extensive rehabilitative efforts had been unsuccessful, and children's health and safety would be jeopardized if they were returned to parents. RS v. Johnson County Dept. of Family Servs. (In re JL), 989 P.2d 1268, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 164 (Wyo. 1999).

Where the record disclosed long-term general neglect and the detailed instances were adequate to show by clear and convincing evidence that a mother had neglected, if not abused, her child and was unable to provide the child with basic health and safety within the prescribed statutory guidelines and where the State had met its responsibility to provide the services necessary to accomplish the specific goals and tasks called for before reunification could occur and yet the mother had made minimal progress toward meeting those goals, the court correctly terminated the mother's parental rights.MN v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (In the Interest of MN), 2003 WY 135, 78 P.3d 232, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 163 (Wyo. 2003).

Clear and convincing evidence supported the termination of appellant mother's parental rights under this section, because drugs and drug paraphernalia were found in the home within the reach of the children when they were taken into custody, the Wyoming Department of Family Services provided reasonable efforts to rehabilitate her by focusing on the drug issues, and appellant failed to comply with the service plan by missing drug tests and continuing to test positive for illegal drugs. Appellant failed to recognize her drug addiction, and the children's health and safety would be seriously jeopardized by returning them to her care; in fact, the children's health had improved in foster care. TMC v. Dep't of Family Serv. (In re ARC), 2011 WY 119, 258 P.3d 704, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 2011).

Court properly terminated a mother's parental rights on the basis of unfitness because testimony revealed that the mother's substance abuse issues caused significant concern and created a barrier to the mother's reunification with her children; the mother failed to make progress under the service plan due to her inability to stay sober. The mother was also on probation in a criminal matter at the time of the hearing, and she continued to fail court-ordered urinalysis tests. ZMETS v. State, 2012 WY 68, 276 P.3d 392, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 72 (Wyo. 2012).

Evidence insufficient to sustain termination of parental rights under paragraph (a)(i). —

Where the father was incarcerated for the commission of a felony and had additional charges pending against him, the mother sought termination of parental rights pursuant to subsection (a)(i). In its decision letter the district court found termination under this section inappropriate, because the mother did not establish that the father had left the child in the care of another; in fact, he had never met the child. JLW v. CAB (In re WDW), 2010 WY 9, 224 P.3d 14, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 2010).

Evidence fell short of meeting the mother's burden to prove grounds for termination under(a)(1) of this section, as the father consistently sent letter and cards to his children while he was incarcerated, in spite of the fact that no communication came back, and he attempted to initiate communication through visitation once he was placed on supervised release. RAA v. AW, 2016 WY 117, 384 P.3d 1156, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 131 (Wyo. 2016).

Evidence sufficient to establish neglect. —

See In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998); TR v. Washakie County Dep't of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 736 P.2d 712, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 431 (Wyo. 1987).

Evidence of filthy and unsafe conditions in home, and of failure of six years of rehabilitative efforts, was sufficient to justify termination of mother's parental rights. LDC v. Department of Family Servs. (In re ZKP), 979 P.2d 953, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 1999).

Evidence of unclean premises insufficient for termination. —

Evidence of isolated instances of unclean premises, dirty dishes and related matters is not sufficient grounds for termination. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976).

Divorced parent's joblessness alone is insufficient basis for severing parent-child relationship. In re Parental Rights of SCN, 659 P.2d 568, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1983).

Evidence insufficient to establish abuse or neglect. —

See DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980).

Evidence insufficient to terminate parental rights under subsection (a)(iii). —

Where the father's five children were living in an extremely dirty home, the Wyoming Department of Family Services (DFS) did not provide evidence to connect his marijuana use with his unfitness as a parent; testimony indicated that he was a good father figure, and never used marijuana in the presence of the children. In the termination of parental rights action brought under this section, DFS did not prove by clear and convincing evidence that returning the children to the father would be a risk to their health or safety. State v. TWE (In re ATE), 2009 WY 155, 222 P.3d 142, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 2009).

Conviction of child abuse justifies termination. —

Even if father had been successful in arguing the insufficiency of the evidence to terminate his parental rights for abuse, the judgment of termination would have to stand because of his conviction of the felony of child abuse, coupled with the clear and convincing evidence that he was an unfit parent by any standard. In In Interest of JG, 742 P.2d 770, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 509 (Wyo. 1987).

Rights terminated for rape, resistance to rehabilitation. —

Evidence warranted the termination of the father's parental rights, where the record showed that he had repeatedly committed forcible rapes, beginning when he was 17 years old, culminating in the rape and death of an elderly woman, for which he was presently incarcerated under an extended prison sentence, and that he had resisted a rehabilitative program for sexual offenders available to him. In re Adoption of JLP, 774 P.2d 624, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1989).

Appeal.—

District court did not err in terminating a father's parental rights to his children because the father's pro se “Brief Letter” presented no cogent legal argument; the letter presented no legal argument at all. NRL v. State (In re NRL), 2015 WY 27, 344 P.3d 759, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 2015).

Incarceration. —

“Incarceration,” as used in subdivision (a)(iv), is an unambiguous term entitled to its plain and ordinary meaning. DKM v. RJS (In re SYM), 924 P.2d 985, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 143 (Wyo. 1996).

Where the father was incarcerated for the commission of a felony and had additional charges pending against him, he had struggled with drug and alcohol abuse when not in prison; he never voluntarily paid child support, and had never met his child. The district court's decision to terminate the father's parental rights under subsection (a)(iv) was supported by clear and convincing evidence. JLW v. CAB (In re WDW), 2010 WY 9, 224 P.3d 14, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 2010).

Incarceration, per se, justifies termination. —

Where the termination of parental rights is premised, under subsection (a)(iv), upon the parent's incarceration, the state has no burden to demonstrate the unavailability of means less intrusive than termination. RW v. State, 766 P.2d 555, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1989).

When termination of parental rights is sought pursuant to subsection (a)(iv), the petitioner must establish: (1) that the parent is incarcerated due to a felony conviction; and (2) that the parent is unfit to have custody and control of the child. DKM v. RJS (In re SYM), 924 P.2d 985, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 143 (Wyo. 1996).

And conviction not affected by pending writ. —

The pendency of an application for a discretionary writ of certiorari to the United States supreme court in the case of the natural parents' second-degree murder convictions did not affect the status of those convictions for purposes of subsection (a)(iv). RW v. State, 766 P.2d 555, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1989).

But where mother's felony conviction was on appeal as of right, it could not qualify as a “conviction” for purposes of subdivision (a)(iv) of this section, until it was finally resolved by court. CAC v. Natrona County Dep't of Family Servs., 983 P.2d 1205, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 1999).

Evidence sufficient to sustain termination of parental rights under paragraphs (a)(i) and (a)(v). —

Mother's parental rights were properly terminated where the children lived with their grandmother for many years, the mother provided no monetary support, and the mother visited the children only a few times. SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs.(In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2005).

Trial court properly terminated a mother's parental rights to her children pursuant to Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(v) because the children had been in foster care for 15 of the most recent 22 months, and she continuously put them in dangerous situations and placed the wants and desires of her ex-husband and boyfriends ahead of their welfare; she also participated in the sexual abuse of one child. NLT v. State (In re KAT), 2012 WY 150, 288 P.3d 1217, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 2012).

Evidence sufficient to sustain termination of parental rights under paragraph (a)(i). —

District court properly terminated a father's parental rights because the child was left in the care of the mother for nearly all of his life, the father made no provision for the child's support for four years, none of his contacts were directed to the child, but rather were addressed specifically to the mother and revolved around an effort to form some sort of a relationship with her, and although one e-mail mentioned that the father loved the child, it was not a communication toward the child, and the statute did not require that the mother pursue lesser options before seeking termination. Johnson v. Calkins, 2017 WY 50, 393 P.3d 1316, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 53 (Wyo. 2017).

Evidence was sufficient to support termination of a father's parental rights where the children's mother proved by clear and convincing evidence that the father was incarcerated due to a felony conviction and was manifestly unfit to have custody of any child. DKM v. RJS (In re SYM), 924 P.2d 985, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 143 (Wyo. 1996).

Proof that the mother and father were incarcerated on felony charges relating to the endangerment of the children, evidence of their past parenting failures, and indications that their parenting skills had not improved supported the district court's termination of their parental rights for unfitness pursuant to Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-309(a)(iv). JD v. State (In re AE), 2009 WY 78, 208 P.3d 1323, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 83 (Wyo. 2009).

Evidence sufficient to sustain termination of parental rights under paragraphs (a)(v). —

District court properly found there was clear and convincing evidence that appellant mother's parental rights be terminated under this section for unfitness, because the mother had a history of drug use, the children had low weights for their age, and the youngest child had a serious medical condition that required close monitoring. The children's health improved in foster care. TMC v. Dep't of Family Serv. (In re ARC), 2011 WY 119, 258 P.3d 704, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 2011).

District court's determination that appellant, who had been incarcerated for nearly 20 years of his life, was unfit to have custody and control of his child was supported by clear and convincing evidence; accordingly, there was sufficient evidence to support termination of appellant's parental rights under subsection (a)(v) of this section. RGS v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (In re KGS), 2017 WY 2, 386 P.3d 1144, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 2017).

Termination of the mother’s parental rights was proper because the children were in foster care under the responsibility of the State for 50 months at the time of trial; the record was replete with evidence that the mother was unable to meet the needs of the children at the time of trial even during short visits, whether supervised or unsupervised; she tacitly admitted that she was unfit to have custody by arguing that she would have gained fitness at some time in the future if the termination had not occurred; and the mother’s claim that she might improve in the future and become fit to have custody and control of the children was irrelevant to the elements of this section. Swenson v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (In re: LCH), 2019 WY 13, 434 P.3d 100, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 2019).

Clear and convincing evidence established that parents were unfit to have custody and control of their child because of the parents’ mental health diagnoses, history of substance abuse, drug-related criminal activity, inconsistent visitation, inconsistent housing, and failure to apply for services and benefits. Termination was also in the child’s best interest because the child had been placed out of the home and the court had no clear indication of when, if ever, the parents would have been sufficiently rehabilitated. Hood v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (In re JPL), 2021 WY 94, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 103 (Wyo. 2021).

Trial court's determination of the mother's unfitness was supported by evidence that the mother exhibited a clear pattern of neglect adversely affected, and even injuring, the children, that such reckless and dangerous behavior resulted from the mother's drug and/or alcohol abuse, and that the mother paced the mental emotional needs of the children at risk; SAS v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re AGS), 2014 WY 143, 337 P.3d 470, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Wyo. 2014).

Applied in

WR v. Natrona County Dep't of Family Servs., 916 P.2d 991, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1996).

Stated in

Perkins v. State, 2014 WY 11, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Jan 24, 2014).

Quoted in

In re CH, 783 P.2d 155, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 234 (Wyo. 1989); Jet v. State (In re Drt), 2010 WY 137, 241 P.3d 489, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (Oct. 21, 2010); E.R.C.K. v. State Dep't of Family Servs., 2013 WY 160, 314 P.3d 1170, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 166 , 2013 WL 6822656 (Dec 24, 2013); E.R.C.K. v. State Dep't of Family Servs., 2013 WY 160, 314 P.3d 1170, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 166 , 2013 WL 6822656 (Dec 24, 2013).

Cited in

State ex rel. TRL v. RLP, 772 P.2d 1054, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 1989); DH v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re “H” Children), 2003 WY 155, 79 P.3d 997, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 2003).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Termination of Parental Rights: Establishing Standards for the Wyoming Law, In the Matter of Parental Rights to X, Y and Z, DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980),” see XVI Land & Water L. Rev. 295 (1981).

For comment “Wyoming's New Termination of Parental Rights Statute,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 621 (1982).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Legal malpractice in defense of parents at proceedings to terminate parental rights over dependent or neglected children, 18 ALR5th 902.

Parent's use of drugs as factor in award of custody of children, visitation rights, or termination of parental rights, 20 ALR5th 534.

Smoking as factor in child custody and visitation cases, 36 ALR5th 377.

Sufficiency of evidence to establish parent's knowledge or allowance of child's sexual abuse by another under statute permitting termination of parental rights for “allowing” or “knowingly allowing” such abuse to occur, 53 ALR5th 499.

Rights of unwed father to obstruct adoption of his child by withholding consent, 61 ALR5th 151.

Natural parent's indigence resulting from unemployment or underemployment as precluding finding that failure to support child waived requirement of consent to adoption, 83 ALR5th 375.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — Constitutional issues, 110 ALR5th 579.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — General considerations, 113 ALR5th 349.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — Effect on parenting ability and parental rights, 116 ALR5th 559.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — Best interests analysis, 117 ALR5th 349.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — Issues concerning guardian ad litem and counsel, 118 ALR 5th 561.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — Applicability of Americans With Disabilities Act, 119 ALR 5th 351.

Parents' mental illness or mental deficiency as ground for termination of parental rights — Evidentiary issues, 122 A.L.R.5th 385.

§ 14-2-310. Parties authorized to file petition.

  1. The petition for the termination of the parent-child relationship shall be filed with the court by:
    1. Either parent, when termination of the parent-child legal relationship is sought with respect to the other parent; or
    2. The guardian or the legal custodian of the child; or
    3. An authorized agency.
  2. The petition for the termination of the parent-child relationship may be filed with the court by a biological or adoptive grandparent acting in loco parentis to the child, where the child has resided with the grandparent for a period of not less than one (1) year and the placement is not under the direction of a juvenile court or the department of family services.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 2019, ch. 88, § 1.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, added (b).

Cross references. —

As to commencement of actions generally, see Rule 3, W.R.C.P.

DFS is “authorized agency”. —

Department of Family Services (DFS), a public social service agency, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 9-2-2101(a), with authority to oversee the custody and care of children in cases of abuse and neglect under the Child Protection Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-3-401 through 14-3-441 , was an “authorized agency” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-2-308 and 14-2-310 with authority to file a petition to terminate a mother's parental rights, even though DFS did not have custody of the children. State v. DH (In the Interest of LB), 2014 WY 10, 316 P.3d 1184, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 2014).

Commencement of termination proceedings. — Termination of a mother's parental rights was not invalidated due to a decision not to place children with their maternal grandmother because the placement decision did not affect the mother's ability to visit the children or strengthen a relationship with them; moreover, that placement was unsuitable due to the grandmother's failure to cooperate and the fact that she lived with a convicted sex offender. In addition, the Wyoming Department of Family Services was not required to wait for a second home evaluation for the grandmother after she moved to a different state before commencing termination proceedings against the mother. K.H. v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re D.H.), 2007 WY 196, 173 P.3d 365, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (Wyo. 2007).

Assistance of counsel required. — The department of family services and its director are not permitted to file a petition for parental termination without the assistance of counsel. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Applied in

In re HLL, 2016 WY 43, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Apr. 12, 2016).

Stated in

Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

§ 14-2-311. Contents of petition.

  1. The petition for the termination of the parent-child legal relationship shall state:
    1. The legal name, sex, date and place of birth of the child, if known, and the jurisdictional facts;
    2. The name and residence of the petitioner and his relationship to the child;
    3. The name, address and place and date of birth of the parent, if known, and of the name of the person having the legal custody or guardianship of the child;
    4. The grounds for termination of the parent-child legal relationship pursuant to W.S. 14-2-309 ;
    5. Name and address of the person or authorized agency requesting appointment as the guardian of the child.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Stated in

Johnson v. Calkins, 2017 WY 50, 393 P.3d 1316, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 53 (Wyo. 2017).

§ 14-2-312. Hearing; appointment of guardian ad litem.

After the petition has been filed, the court shall appoint a guardian ad litem to represent the child unless the court finds the interests of the child will be represented adequately by the petitioner or another party to the action and are not adverse to that party. If the court appoints a guardian ad litem it shall approve a fee for services. When a petition is filed and presented to the judge, the judge shall set the petition for hearing. The Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure, including the right of a parent, child or interested person to demand a jury trial, are applicable in actions brought under this act.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1985, ch. 86, § 2; 1993, ch. 109, § 1.

Cross references. —

For jury trial of right, see Rule 38, W.R.C.P.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-308(a)(ix).

Authority to appoint guardian ad litem.—

District court plainly had jurisdiction over a father’s petition to modify custody, and it had authority to use a guardian ad litem (GAL) to assist in deciding the petition, because when the father invoked the district court’s jurisdiction by filing a petition to modify custody and alleging a material change in circumstances the district court had before it a child custody matter and authority to appoint a GAL. Van Fleet v. Guyette, 2020 WY 78, 466 P.3d 812, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2020).

This section is unambiguous and mandatory. — Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-312 is an unambiguous mandatory statute that does not allow a district court discretion not to appoint a guardian ad litem or not to make the appropriate record findings that no guardian ad litem is required; furthermore, the requirement that mandatory statutes be obeyed is most compelling in cases where fundamental parent-child relationships are at risk of severance. LM v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs., 2007 WY 189, 171 P.3d 1077, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 201 (Dec. 5, 2007).

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-312 leaves no room for an assumption that the Department of Family Services will adequately represent the interests of children in a termination action. LM v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs., 2007 WY 189, 171 P.3d 1077, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 201 (Dec. 5, 2007).

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-312 is an unambiguous mandatory statute that requires a district court in a parental rights termination action either to appoint a guardian ad litem to represent involved children, or to make a finding that no guardian ad litem is necessary because the petitioner or another party to the action will adequately represent the interests of the children, and the interests of the children are not adverse to that party. LM v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs., 2007 WY 189, 171 P.3d 1077, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 201 (Dec. 5, 2007).

Judgment terminating a mother's parental rights to her children was reversed and remanded because no guardian ad litem was appointed to represent the children in the proceedings, and Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-312 is an unambiguous mandatory statute that does not allow a district court discretion not to appoint a guardian ad litem or not to make the appropriate record findings that no guardian ad litem was required. LM v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs., 2007 WY 189, 171 P.3d 1077, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 201 (Dec. 5, 2007).

Guardian ad litem entitled to fully participate in termination case.—

District court did not err by refusing to restrict the guardian ad litem's (GAL) participation in an action seeking to terminate a mother's parental rights because the GAL was entitled to fully participate in the action; regardless of whether the child was technically a party to the action, he had an interest and rights in the proceeding. Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

Termination of parental rights cannot be based solely upon the best interests of the child, however, that does not mean that the guardian ad litem cannot participate in the evidentiary portion of the trial; the statutory provisions setting forth the requirements for termination of parental rights include factors directly related to the child's well-being. Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

No order terminating parental rights may be entered in Wyoming without hearing. Blair v. Supreme Court of Wyoming, 671 F.2d 389, 1982 U.S. App. LEXIS 21745 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1982).

One has a statutory right to a jury trial in a parental-termination proceeding. In re Matter of GP, 679 P.2d 976, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 269 (Wyo. 1984).

Court must appoint attorney for child's interests before adjudicating termination issues. —

It is improper for the district court to adjudicate the substantive issues of termination of parental rights without appointing an attorney to protect the welfare of the child. In re Child X, 617 P.2d 1078, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 308 (Wyo. 1980) (decided under prior law).

Assistance of counsel required. —

The department of family services and its director are not permitted to file a petition for parental termination without the assistance of counsel. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Motion to set aside entry of default denied.—

District court exercised sound judgment to deny a mother’s motion to set aside the entry of default because it properly applied the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure and reasonably considered the three factors; the Department of Family Services would be prejudiced by the delay to the permanent placement of the children, and the mother’s failure to respond to the petition to terminate her parental rights for approximately four months constituted culpable conduct that led to her default. Hurd v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (In re EMM), 2018 WY 36, 414 P.3d 1157, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 2018).

No reversal despite unjustified ex parte conference. —

An ex parte conference between the trial judge and the guardian ad litem appointed to represent the minor child of the parties could not be ethically justified, but did not require the reversal of an adjudication of child custody in a divorce action where no prejudicial error was manifested. Moore v. Moore, 809 P.2d 261, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 70 (Wyo. 1991).

Sufficiency of the Evidence. —

Party in default who has appeared at a parental rights termination hearing may challenge the sufficiency of the evidence in an appeal from an order terminating parental rights. ZMETS v. State, 2012 WY 68, 276 P.3d 392, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 72 (Wyo. 2012).

Applied in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982); In re Parental Rights of SCN, 659 P.2d 568, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1983); In Interest of SVG, 826 P.2d 237, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1992).

Quoted in

In re Adoption of JLP, 774 P.2d 624, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1989); WR v. Natrona County Dep't of Family Servs., 916 P.2d 991, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1996).

Cited in

MTM v. LD, 2002 WY 26, 41 P.3d 522, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 2002).

Law reviews. —

For comment “Wyoming's New Termination of Parental Rights Statute,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 621 (1982).

For article, “Attorney for Child Versus Guardian Ad Litem: Wyoming Creates a Hybrid, but is it a Formula for Malpractice?,” see XXXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 381 (1999).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Consideration and weight of religious affiliations in appointment of guardian for child, 22 ALR2d 696.

Right of child to select his own guardian, 85 ALR2d 921.

Right of putative father to guardianship of illegitimate child, 45 ALR3d 216.

Right of indigent parent to appointed counsel in proceeding for involuntary termination of parental rights, 92 ALR5th 379.

§ 14-2-313. Service of petition.

  1. The petition shall be served on the following persons:
    1. The parent of the child;
    2. The guardian ad litem;
    3. The guardian or next friend of the parent if the parent is a minor;
    4. The department of family services if the child is or has been supported by public assistance funds.
  2. Service of the petition on the person required to be served by subsection (a) of this section shall be made as provided by the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure. If the person is a nonresident or his residence is unknown, service may be had by constructive service or by publication as provided in the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1993, ch. 109, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to service of process, see Rule 4, W.R.C.P.

Service by publication. —

Adoption court did not err in granting the foster parents’ petition for adoption because service by publication upon an unknown father was proper at the time that it was completed, and the court in the termination case obtained jurisdiction over the parties and terminated the father’s parental rights; nothing on the face of the termination order or the record indicated that the district court subsequently lost jurisdiction; the father’s collateral attack on the termination order could not be maintained in the adoption case; and the father did not have standing to object to or otherwise participate in the adoption proceeding as his parental rights had already been terminated, and he had no legally protectable interest at stake. RB v. State (In re SSO), 2017 WY 142, 406 P.3d 723, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 149 (Wyo. 2017).

“Constructive service” allowed if procedural requirements followed. —

“Constructive service,” as applied in subsection (b), includes service by publication under Rule 4(e), W.R.C.P., and service for out-of-state residents under Rule 4(l), W.R.C.P. A petitioner has the right to use Rule 4 service of process to satisfy the service requirements of this section only if the procedural requirements delineated in the rule are accurately followed. Therefore, a petitioner's failure to properly conform to Rule 4(l)(2), W.R.C.P., when serving an out-of-state mother by registered mail in a termination proceeding, constituted inadequate service of process. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Answer not waiver of defense of defective service. —

In a parental termination proceeding, a parent did not waive her defense to an agency's defective service of process by filing an answer, where she had already appropriately attacked the inadequate service with a defensive motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b), W.R.C.P. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

If there was defective service, guardian ad litem waived objection by filing report the morning of the trial. In re Parental Rights to ARW, 716 P.2d 353, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 518 (Wyo. 1986), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

Stated in

Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

§ 14-2-314. Social study required; information to be shown; not excluded as hearsay.

Upon the filing of a petition by anyone other than an authorized agency as defined by W.S. 14-2-308(a)(ii)(A), the court shall direct that a social study be made by the appropriate county office of public assistance and social services or by any authorized agency to aid the court in making a final disposition of the petition. The social study shall state the factual information pertaining to the allegations in the petition, the social history and the present situation and environment of the child and parent. The social study shall not be excluded as evidence by reason of hearsay alone. The social study shall be made available to any party to the action upon request.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1985, ch. 86, § 2.

Hearsay rules apply where agency is party. —

Under this section, when a social study is independently made and an authorized agency is not the petitioner, the study is not solely inadmissible because of its character as hearsay. Where, however, the authorized agency is a party, this section does not apply to the submitted report and Rules 801 through 806, W.R.E., can operate to preclude its introduction. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Psychological studies of mentally retarded parents held ofno assistance. —

Psychological studies of selected mentally retarded married parents and their capabilities and success in the care of their children may be of interest to those engaged in that phase of psychology, but they offer no assistance in determining the cases brought under the provisions of this article. In re M., 556 P.2d 514, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1976) (decided under prior law).

Noncompliance with this section was not prejudicial error.—

When the district court entered its decision letter concluding that the father's parental rights should be terminated, it was filed prior to the receipt of the social study required by this section; however, the father was not prejudiced. The decision letter was not a judgment, and the district court had the opportunity to consider the social study before issuing the order terminating parental rights. JLW v. CAB (In re WDW), 2010 WY 9, 224 P.3d 14, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 2010).

Section not violated. —

See In re Parental Rights to ARW, 716 P.2d 353, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 518 (Wyo. 1986), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

Applied in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982); In re Parental Rights of SCN, 659 P.2d 568, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1983); In re Adoption of BBC, 849 P.2d 769, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 1993).

Stated in

Zmets v. State, 2012 WY 68, 276 P.3d 392, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 72 (May 16, 2012).

Law reviews. —

For comment “Wyoming's New Termination of Parental Rights Statute,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 621 (1982).

§ 14-2-315. Order terminating the parent-child legal relationship; contents.

The order terminating the parent-child legal relationship shall be in writing and shall contain the findings of the court. If the court terminates the parent-child legal relationship of either one (1) or both parents, it shall fix the responsibility for the child’s support and appoint a guardian of the child’s person or estate or both.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1.

Quoted in

In Interest of SVG, 826 P.2d 237, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1992).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Nonresidence as affecting one's right to custody of child, 15 ALR2d 432.

Alienation of child's affections as affecting custody award, 32 ALR2d 1005.

§ 14-2-316. Dismissal of petition; continuation of hearing.

If the court does not terminate the parent-child legal relationship, it shall dismiss the petition or direct an authorized agency to continue to make efforts to rehabilitate the parent and continue the hearing for no longer than six (6) months. The authorized agency shall provide the court with any additional reports regarding its rehabilitative efforts and results. Pending final hearing, the court may continue the present placement of the child or place the child in the temporary custody of an authorized agency and fix responsibility for temporary child support.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1.

Once parent-child relationship terminated, section inapplicable.—

Where the trial court properly decided to terminate the parent-child relationship, there was no need to determine whether the court abused its discretion in refusing to continue the hearing so that additional efforts to rehabilitate the father might occur, as this section was not applicable. In In Interest of JG, 742 P.2d 770, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 509 (Wyo. 1987).

Applied in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982).

§ 14-2-317. Effect of order of termination.

  1. An order terminating the parent-child legal relationship divests the parent of all legal rights and privileges and relieves the child of all duties to that parent except:
    1. The order does not divest that parent of duties and support obligations unless otherwise specifically ordered by the court or the child is adopted; and
    2. Except as provided in W.S. 2-4-107(a)(i), the right of the child to inherit from the parent shall not be affected by the order.
  2. The parent whose parent-child legal relationship has been terminated is not thereafter entitled to the notice of proceedings for the adoption of the child, nor has he any right to object to the adoption or otherwise participate in the adoption proceedings.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1993, ch. 109, § 1; 2015, ch. 51, § 1.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (a)(ii), added “Except as provided in W.S. 2-4-107(a)(i).”

No violation to award grandmother temporary custody. —

In a neglect action, a mother's parental rights were not violated by a temporary custody award to the grandmother, where the mother had already given up custody through the divorce decree when this case came before the juvenile court, and her rights as a parent remained intact in residual character. In In Interest of MKM, 792 P.2d 1369, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 59 (Wyo. 1990).

No standing to object to adoption. —

Adoption court did not err in granting the foster parents’ petition for adoption because service by publication upon an unknown father was proper at the time that it was completed, and the court in the termination case obtained jurisdiction over the parties and terminated the father’s parental rights; nothing on the face of the termination order or the record indicated that the district court subsequently lost jurisdiction; the father’s collateral attack on the termination order could not be maintained in the adoption case; and the father did not have standing to object to or otherwise participate in the adoption proceeding as his parental rights had already been terminated, and he had no legally protectable interest at stake. RB v. State (In re SSO), 2017 WY 142, 406 P.3d 723, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 149 (Wyo. 2017).

Applied in

In re Adoption of JLP, 774 P.2d 624, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1989).

Quoted in

In re TLB, 771 P.2d 811, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1989); In re CH, 783 P.2d 155, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 234 (Wyo. 1989).

Cited in

Stone v. Stone, 7 P.3d 887, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (Wyo. 2000); Shippey v. Rogers (In re Estate of Kirkpatrick), 2003 WY 125, 77 P.3d 404, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 150 (Wyo. 2003); DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Residual parental rights.—

Mother's claim that a permanency order should have designated the her preferred adoptive parents as the court-ordered adoptive parents had not been waived, but failed on the merits where the permanency order had not terminated the mother's parental rights or changed legal custody, and nothing in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-431(k) (2017) required findings as to the merits of the prospective adoption applicants. DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Mother’s claim that a permanency order should have designated the her preferred adoptive parents as the court-ordered adoptive parents had not been waived, but failed on the merits where the permanency order had not terminated the mother’s parental rights or changed legal custody, and nothing in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-431(k) (2017) required findings as to the merits of the prospective adoption applicants. DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

§ 14-2-318. Costs of proceedings; appointment of counsel.

  1. The court may appoint counsel for any party who is indigent. Indigency shall be established by written affidavit signed and sworn to by the party or sworn testimony made a part of the record of the proceedings. The affidavit or sworn testimony shall state that the party is without sufficient money, property, assets or credit to employ counsel in his own behalf. The court may require further verification of financial condition as it deems necessary.
  2. Where petitioner is an authorized agency as defined by W.S. 14-2-308(a)(ii)(B), it shall pay for the costs of the action. Costs shall include:
    1. Fee for the guardian ad litem. If the agency had entered into an agreement with the guardian ad litem program pursuant to W.S. 14-12-101 through 14-12-104 and the program was appointed to provide the guardian ad litem, the program shall pay the fee for the guardian ad litem in accordance with that agreement;
    2. Attorney’s fee for an indigent party;
    3. Other professional fees incurred by an indigent party in defense of an action brought under this act.
  3. Prior to incurring any cost under subsection (b) of this section application shall be made to the court and written approval by the court shall be obtained.
  4. Where petitioner is an authorized agency as defined by W.S. 14-2-308(a)(ii)(A):
    1. The district attorney for the county in which the petition is filed shall represent the authorized agency in all proceedings under this act;
    2. The authorized agency shall pay the reasonable attorney’s fees and expenses for an indigent party incurred in the defense of an action brought under this act and approved by the court; and
    3. The authorized agency shall pay the guardian ad litem reasonable fees and expenses approved by the court unless the agency had entered into an agreement with the guardian ad litem program pursuant to W.S. 14-12-101 through 14-12-104 and the program was appointed to provide the guardian ad litem. If so, the program shall pay the fee for the guardian ad litem in accordance with that agreement.

History. Laws 1981, ch. 102, § 1; 1985, ch. 86, § 2; 2012, ch. 76, § 3.

The 2012 amendment, added the second sentence in (b)(i); and in (d)(iii), added “unless the agency had entered into an agreement with the guardian ad litem program pursuant to W.S. 14-12-101 through 14-12-104 and the program was appointed to provide the guardian ad litem” and the last sentence.

Laws 2012, ch. 76 § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2012.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-308(a)(ix).

Assistance of counsel required. —

The department of family services and its director are not permitted to file a petition for parental termination without the assistance of counsel. In In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Reasonable fees. —

Trial court did not err in awarding an attorney 50 percent of the fees the attorney requested under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-318(a) and (b) for representing an indigent parent in a termination of parental rights proceeding because the attorney's billing entry of over four hours of legal research regarding a pretrial memorandum revealed that the attorney failed to exercise billing judgment. Tolin v. State (In re NRF), 2013 WY 9, 294 P.3d 879, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 2013).

Stated in

Zmets v. State, 2012 WY 68, 276 P.3d 392, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 72 (May 16, 2012).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Attorney for Child Versus Guardian Ad Litem: Wyoming Creates a Hybrid, but is it a Formula for Malpractice?,” see XXXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 381 (1999).

§ 14-2-319. Determination of indigency; recovery of payment.

  1. In determining whether a person is an indigent party for purposes of W.S. 14-2-318 , the court shall consider in addition to any other relevant factors the person’s income, property owned, outstanding obligations and the number and ages of his dependents. In each case the person, subject to the penalties for perjury, shall certify in writing, or by other record, material facts relating to his ability to pay as the court prescribes.
  2. To the extent that an indigent party is able to provide for an attorney or for other expenses incurred in defense of an action brought under this act, the court may order that he make payment within a specified period of time or in specified installments.
  3. Within eight (8) years after the date the services were rendered, the attorney general may sue on behalf of the state to recover payment or reimbursement from each person who has received legal assistance or another benefit under this act:
    1. To which he was not entitled;
    2. With respect to which he was not an indigent person when he received it; or
    3. With respect to which he has failed to make the certification required by subsection (a) of this section.
  4. Within three (3) years after the date the services were rendered, the attorney general may sue on behalf of the state to recover payment or reimbursement from each person other than a person covered by subsection (c) of this section who:
    1. Has received legal assistance or other benefit under this act; and
    2. On the date on which suit is brought is financially able to pay or reimburse the state for all or part of the legal assistance or other benefit according to the standards of ability to pay applicable under this act but refuses to do so.
  5. Amounts recovered under this section shall be remitted to the general fund.

History. Laws 1985, ch. 86, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-308(a)(ix).

Cited in

SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (2005).

Article 4. General Provisions

  • § 14-2-401.  Short title.
  • § 14-2-402.  Definitions.
  • § 14-2-403.  Scope of act; choice of law.
  • § 14-2-404.  Court of this state.
  • § 14-2-405.  Protection of participants.
  • § 14-2-406.  Determination of maternity.
  • § 14-2-407.  Severability clause.
  • § 14-2-408.  Free transcript for appeal.

Cross references. —

As to adoption, see chapter 22 of title 1.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 4, directs that a proceeding to adjudicate parentage under W.S. 14-2-401 et seq. which was commenced prior to July 1, 2003 is to be governed by the law in effect at the time the proceeding was commenced.

Editor's note. —

The following annotations are taken from cases decided under prior law.

Illegitimacy proceedings statutorily based. —

Illegitimacy or filiation proceedings are purely creation of statute since in common law an illegitimate child is considered the child of no one. Vigil v. Tafoya, 600 P.2d 721, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 457 (Wyo. 1979).

Chapter only statutory authority for determination of paternity.—

There is no common-law authority for the determination of paternity, and in this jurisdiction the only statutory authority therefor is found in this chapter. Blanton v. Warn, 444 P.2d 325, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 190 (Wyo. 1968).

Provisions authorizing parentage proceedings to be carefullyandstrictly followed. —

Since common law gave a putative father no right of action but this article does give him a cause of action which permits him to establish the parent-child relationship, the sections which authorize the proceedings in such matters must be carefully and strictly followed in order to give effect to the intention of the legislature. In re TRG, 665 P.2d 491, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 337 (Wyo. 1983).

Parties. —

An agency cannot bring an action and then claim it is not a party. Department of family services (DFS) initiated the action, participated and exercised control over the proceedings, and was a real party in interest who stood to benefit from identifying the father; just because DFS was required by statute to bring this action is irrelevant to whether the agency is a party. Department of Family Servs., Div. of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs. v. DDM, 877 P.2d 259, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 81 (Wyo. 1994).

Paternity determinations made in divorce actions not subjectto provisions. —

The rules under this article do not apply where paternity of a child presumed to be a child of the marriage is determined by consent of the parties in a proceeding to modify a divorce decree to include a child conceived during the marriage but born afterward. CSP v. DDC, 842 P.2d 528, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 171 (Wyo. 1992).

Termination of parental rights in adoption proceedings. —

In an adoption proceeding, the provisions regarding termination of parental rights found in the adoption statutes (§ 1-22-101 et seq.) control over the more general provisions for the termination of parental rights found in this article. GWJ v. MH (In re BGH), 930 P.2d 371, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 187 (Wyo. 1996).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

41 Am. Jur. 2d Illegitimate Children § 1 et seq.

Mother's right to custody of illegitimate child, 98 ALR2d 417.

Right of putative father to visit illegitimate child, 15 ALR3d 887.

Discrimination on basis of illegitimacy as denial of constitutional rights, 38 ALR3d 613.

Right of putative father to custody of illegitimate child, 45 ALR3d 216.

Term “children” as used in beneficiary clause of life insurance policy as including illegitimate child, 62 ALR3d 1329.

Effect, in subsequent proceedings, of paternity findings or implications in divorce or annulment decree or in support or custody order made incidental thereto, 78 ALR3d 846.

Legitimation by marriage to natural father of child born during mother's marriage to another, 80 ALR3d 219.

Determination of paternity of child as within scope of proceeding under Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act, 81 ALR3d 1175.

Validity and construction of surrogate parenting agreement, 77 ALR4th 70.

Rights of unwed father to obstruct adoption of his child by withholding consent, 61 ALR5th 151.

14 C.J.S. Children out of Wedlock § 1 et seq.

§ 14-2-401. Short title.

This act shall be known and may be cited as the Wyoming Parentage Act.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referenced in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

De facto parentage not recognized. —

De facto parentage was not recognized in Wyoming because the legislature (1) defined the mother-child and father-child relationships, when adopting the Wyoming Parentage Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-401 et seq., advisedly, (2) left no gap of sufficient size to permit judicial adoption of the doctrine, and (3) acted extensively to define the parent-child relationship and children's relationships with those not their legal parents. LP v. LF, 2014 WY 152, 338 P.3d 908, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 2014).

Parentage by estoppel not recognized. —

Parentage by estoppel was not recognized in Wyoming because the legislature (1) defined the mother-child and father-child relationships, when adopting the Wyoming Parentage Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-401 et seq., advisedly, (2) left no gap of sufficient size to permit judicial adoption of the doctrine, (3) acted extensively to define the parent-child relationship and children's relationships with those not their legal parents, and (4) created criteria for presumptive parentage, preempting the field. LP v. LF, 2014 WY 152, 338 P.3d 908, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 2014).

Cited in

In re Paternity, JWH v. DAH, 2011 WY 66, 252 P.3d 942, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Apr. 14, 2011); IC v. DW, 2015 WY 135, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Oct. 7, 2015).

§ 14-2-402. Definitions.

  1. As used in this act:
    1. “Acknowledged father” means a man who has established a father-child relationship under article 6 of this act;
    2. “Adjudicated father” means a man who has been adjudicated by a court of competent jurisdiction to be the father of a child;
    3. “Alleged father” means a man who alleges himself to be, or is alleged to be, the genetic father or a possible genetic father of a child, but whose paternity has not been determined. The term does not include:
      1. A presumed father;
      2. A man whose parental rights have been terminated or declared not to exist; or
      3. A male donor.
    4. “Assisted reproduction” means a method of causing pregnancy other than through sexual intercourse. The term includes:
      1. Intrauterine insemination;
      2. Donation of eggs;
      3. Donation of embryos;
      4. In-vitro fertilization and transfer of embryos; and
      5. Intracytoplasmic sperm injection.
    5. “Child” means an individual of any age whose parentage may be determined under this act;
    6. “Commence” means to file the initial pleading seeking an adjudication of parentage in a district court of this state;
    7. “Determination of parentage” means the establishment of the parent-child relationship by the signing of a valid acknowledgment of paternity under article 5 of this act or by adjudication by the court;
    8. “Donor” means an individual who produces eggs or sperm used for assisted reproduction, whether or not for consideration. The term does not include:
      1. A husband who provides sperm, or a wife who provides eggs, to be used for assisted reproduction by the wife;
      2. A woman who gives birth to a child by means of assisted reproduction;
      3. A parent under article 9 of this chapter.
    9. “Ethnic or racial group” means, for purposes of genetic testing, a recognized group that an individual identifies as all or part of the individual’s ancestry or that is so identified by other information;
    10. “Genetic testing” means an analysis of genetic markers to exclude or identify a man as the father or a woman as the mother of a child. The term includes an analysis of one (1) or a combination of the following:
      1. Deoxyribonucleic acid; and
      2. Blood-group antigens, red-cell antigens, human-leukocyte antigens, serum enzymes, serum proteins or red-cell enzymes.
    11. “Man” means a male individual of any age;
    12. “Parent” means an individual who has established a parent-child relationship under W.S. 14-2-501 ;
    13. “Parent-child relationship” means the legal relationship between a child and a parent of the child. The term includes the mother-child relationship and the father-child relationship;
    14. “Paternity index” means the likelihood of paternity calculated by computing the ratio between:
      1. The likelihood that the tested man is the father, based on the genetic markers of the tested man, mother and child, conditioned on the hypothesis that the tested man is the father of the child; and
      2. The likelihood that the tested man is not the father, based on the genetic markers of the tested man, mother and child, conditioned on the hypothesis that the tested man is not the father of the child and that the father is of the same ethnic or racial group as the tested man.
    15. “Presumed father” means a man who, by operation of law under W.S. 14-2-504 , is recognized as the father of a child until that status is rebutted or confirmed in a judicial proceeding;
    16. “Probability of paternity” means the measure, for the ethnic or racial group to which the alleged father belongs, of the probability that the man in question is the father of the child, compared with a random, unrelated man of the same ethnic or racial group, expressed as a percentage incorporating the paternity index and a prior probability;
    17. “Record” means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form;
    18. “Signatory” means an individual who authenticates a record and is bound by its terms;
    19. “State” means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States;
    20. “Title IV-D” means Title IV-D of the federal Social Security Act;
    21. “This act” means W.S. 14-2-401 through 14-2-907 .

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 14-2-403. Scope of act; choice of law.

  1. This act applies to every determination of parentage in this state.
  2. The court shall apply the law of this state to adjudicate the parent-child relationship. The applicable law does not depend on:
    1. The place of birth of the child; or
    2. The past or present residence of the child.
  3. This act does not create, enlarge or diminish parental rights or duties under other law of this state.
  4. This act does not authorize or prohibit an agreement between a woman and a man and another woman in which the woman relinquishes all rights as a parent of a child conceived by means of assisted reproduction, and which provides that the man and the other woman become the parents of the child. If a birth results under such an agreement and the agreement is unenforceable under Wyoming law, the parent-child relationship is determined as provided in article 4 of this act.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

§ 14-2-404. Court of this state.

The district court is authorized to adjudicate parentage under this act.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

§ 14-2-405. Protection of participants.

Proceedings under this act are subject to other law of this state governing the health, safety, privacy and liberty of a child or other individual who could be jeopardized by disclosure of identifying information, including address, telephone number, place of employment, social security number and the child’s day-care facility and school.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

§ 14-2-406. Determination of maternity.

Provisions of this act relating to determination of paternity apply to determinations of maternity.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

§ 14-2-407. Severability clause.

If any provision of this act or its application to an individual or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or applications of this act which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this act are severable.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

§ 14-2-408. Free transcript for appeal.

If a party is financially unable to pay the cost of a transcript, the court shall furnish on request a transcript for purposes of appeal under this act.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

Article 5. Parent-Child Relationship

  • § 14-2-501.  Establishment of parent-child relationship.
  • § 14-2-502.  No discrimination based on marital status.
  • § 14-2-503.  Consequences of establishment of parentage.
  • § 14-2-504.  Presumption of paternity in context of marriage.

§ 14-2-501. Establishment of parent-child relationship.

  1. The mother-child relationship is established between a woman and a child by:
    1. The woman’s having given birth to the child;
    2. An adjudication of the woman’s maternity; or
    3. Adoption of the child by the woman.
  2. The father-child relationship is established between a man and a child by:
    1. An unrebutted presumption of the man’s paternity of the child under W.S. 14-2-504 ;
    2. An effective acknowledgment of paternity by the man under article 6 of this act, unless the acknowledgment has been rescinded or successfully challenged;
    3. An adjudication of the man’s paternity;
    4. Adoption of the child by the man; or
    5. The man’s having consented to assisted reproduction by his wife under article 9 of this act which resulted in the birth of the child.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1; 2017, ch. 172, § 1.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (b)(v) substituted “article 9 of this act” for “article 8 of this act.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

Editor's notes. —

The following annotations are taken from cases decided under prior law.

Not giving biological father same procedure to establish paternity as mother not unconstitutional. —

The failure to give the biological father the same procedure to establish paternity or nonpaternity as is given to the mother does not unconstitutionally deprive the father of due process oflaw nor equal protection of the law by virtue of an impermissible gender-based classification. A v. X, Y, & Z, 641 P.2d 1222, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 459 U.S. 1021, 103 S. Ct. 388, 74 L. Ed. 2d 518, 1982 U.S. LEXIS 4426 (U.S. 1982); A v. X, 459 U.S. 1021, 103 S. Ct. 388, 74 L. Ed. 2d 518, 1982 U.S. LEXIS 4426 (U.S. 1982).

Statutes permit award to state of child support and other expenses. —

Former provisions were broad enough to permit an award, on the petition of the state, for child support owing the child's mother and other expenses. Holtz v. State, 847 P.2d 972, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1993).

State bound to protect child's right to legitimacy. —

Even in this era of no-fault divorce, frequent premarital sex, cohabitation and new attitudes toward child rearing, a child has a right to legitimacy and that right is one the state is bound to protect during minority. A v. X, Y, & Z, 641 P.2d 1222, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 459 U.S. 1021, 103 S. Ct. 388, 74 L. Ed. 2d 518, 1982 U.S. LEXIS 4426 (U.S. 1982).

Intestacy. —

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 2-4-107 is unequivocally one-sided and does not establish mutuality for inheritance purposes because adoptive parents have all relevant rights after an adoption, and the terms “mother” and “father” mean the adoptive parents; therefore, a district court erred by entering judgment in favor of several biological siblings because a niece was the only true heir of a decedent, who, along with the niece’s father, had been adopted. Shippey v. Rogers (In re Estate of Kirkpatrick), 2003 WY 125, 77 P.3d 404, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 150 (Wyo. 2003).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Relationship between victim and plaintiff-witness as affecting right to recover damages in negligence for shock or mental anguish, 94 ALR3d 486.

Marital status of prospective adopting parents as factor in adoption proceedings, 2 ALR4th 555.

Initial award or denial of child custody to homosexual or lesbian parent, 62 ALR5th 591.

Stepparent's postdivorce duty to support stepchild, 44 ALR4th 520.

Parental rights of man who is not biological or adoptive father of child but was husband or cohabitant of mother when child was conceived or born, 84 ALR4th 655.

Custodial parent's homosexual or lesbian relationship with third person as justifying modification of child custody order, 65 ALR5th 591.

§ 14-2-502. No discrimination based on marital status.

A child born to parents who are not married to each other has the same rights under the law as a child born to parents who are married to each other.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

§ 14-2-503. Consequences of establishment of parentage.

Unless parental rights are terminated, a parent-child relationship established under this act applies for all purposes, except as otherwise specifically provided by other law of this state.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

§ 14-2-504. Presumption of paternity in context of marriage.

  1. A man is presumed to be the father of a child if:
    1. He and the mother of the child are married to each other and the child is born during the marriage;
    2. He and the mother of the child were married to each other and the child is born within three hundred (300) days after the marriage is terminated by death, annulment, declaration of invalidity, divorce or after the entry of a decree of separation;
    3. Before the birth of the child, he and the mother of the child married each other in apparent compliance with law, even if the attempted marriage is or could be declared invalid, and the child is born during the invalid marriage or within three hundred (300) days after its termination by death, annulment, declaration of invalidity, divorce or after the entry of a decree of separation;
    4. After the birth of the child, he and the mother of the child married each other in apparent compliance with law, whether or not the marriage is or could be declared invalid, and he voluntarily asserted his paternity of the child, and:
      1. The assertion is in a record filed with the state office of vital records;
      2. He agreed to be and is named as the child’s father on the child’s birth certificate; or
      3. He promised in a record to support the child as his own.
    5. For the first two (2) years of the child’s life, he resided in the same household with the child and openly held out the child as his own.
  2. A presumption of paternity established under this section may be rebutted only by an adjudication under article 8 of this act.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

The following annotations are taken from cases decided under prior law.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-2-402(a)(xxi).

Not giving biological father same procedure to establish paternity as mother not unconstitutional. —

The failure to give the biological father the same procedure to establish paternity or nonpaternity as is given to the mother does not unconstitutionally deprive the father of due process of law nor equal protection of the law by virtue of an impermissible gender-based classification. A v. X, Y, & Z, 641 P.2d 1222, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 459 U.S. 1021, 103 S. Ct. 388, 74 L. Ed. 2d 518, 1982 U.S. LEXIS 4426 (U.S. 1982).

Presumed father was barred from contesting parentage of children by his failure to bring his action within a “reasonable time” pursuant to former § 14-2-104(a)(ii) [repealed] and by the doctrines of res judicata, collateral estoppel and judicial estoppel. In re Paternity of JRW, 814 P.2d 1256, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 114 (Wyo. 1991).

Where the record demonstrated that the defendant was the presumed father of a child under this section by virtue of the fact that he married the child's natural mother and became obligated to pay child support through a Utah divorce decree, the paternity action was barred by the United States constitution's full faith and credit clause, res judicata, Wyoming precedent and this section's limitations period. Livingston v. Vanderiet, 861 P.2d 549, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1993).

Best interests of the children is standard to resolve paternity dispute. —

Where the mother's husband asserted paternity under the marital presumption provided in former Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-102(a)(i), now § 14-2-504(a)(i), and the mother's boyfriend asserted paternity under the holding out presumption of former § 14-2-102(a)(iv), now § 14-2-504(a)(v), the trial court was required to consider the best interests of the children and look to the presumption based on the weightier considerations of policy and logic as provided in former Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-102(b), now § 14-2-504(b). The trial court's decision finding that the boyfriend was the father of the children was supported by the record and simply confirmed and gave legal effect to a relationship that existed throughout the children's lives and did not impermissibly interfere with any rights the husband might have had stemming from his marriage to the children's mother. GDK v. State, 2004 WY 78, 92 P.3d 834, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 101 (Wyo. 2004).

Presumption rebutted. —

Putative father was not a child's presumptive parent, under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-2-504(a)(v), because the putative father stipulated to the accuracy and admissibility of a paternity test conclusively proving the putative father could not be the biological father, rebutting any presumption beyond any doubt. LP v. LF, 2014 WY 152, 338 P.3d 908, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 2014).

Action to declare nonexistence of presumptive father/child relationship time barred. —

Biological mother's action to declare the nonexistence of a presumptive father and child relationship, where the issue was not contested until almost four years after all of the relevant facts were known, was time barred under the statute that requires the action to be brought within a reasonable time. In re Adoption of R.S.C., 837 P.2d 1089, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Wyo. 1992).

Where no timely action has been instituted within five years of a child's birth to declare the nonexistence of a father and child relationship, the statutory presumption of paternity becomes absolute, and any action to establish another's paternity is foreclosed. JA v. CJH, 923 P.2d 758, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo. 1996).

Presumption arising from marriage controls. —

The presumption of paternity found in former § 14-2-102(a)(i) controlled over the presumption in former § 14-2-102(a)(iv). This state has made a policy choice in favor of legitimacy. That choice is based on social considerations of the family unit and the child, which go beyond the marriage itself. LC v. TL, 870 P.2d 374, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 513 U.S. 871, 115 S. Ct. 195, 130 L. Ed. 2d 127, 1994 U.S. LEXIS 6327 (U.S. 1994).

The proper construction of former § 14-2-102(c), when read in accord with the related paternity statute, § 35-1-411 , is that the mother cannot file an affidavit of paternity if she was married either at the time of conception or the time of birth of the child. Department of Family Servs., Div. of Public Assistance & Social Servs. v. PAJ, 934 P.2d 1257, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 54 (Wyo. 1997).

Conflicting presumptions. —

Presumptive father failed to provide clear and convincing evidence to meet his burden of proving that results of genetic test favoring another man were inaccurate or somehow deficient. TL v. CS, 975 P.2d 1065, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1999).

Failure to adhere to procedural requirements. —

Although failure to adhere to the procedural requirements of the statutes governing establishment of paternity of a child receiving aid from the department of family services may cause a judgment rendered under those statutes to be void, where the defendant had notice of the hearing, an opportunity to be heard, and was accorded the process due under all the circumstances of his case, the district court did not err in entering default against the defendant, nor did it abuse its discretion in refusing the defendant relief from that default. A.P. v. Department of Health & Human Servs., Div. of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 849 P.2d 703, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 52 (Wyo. 1993).

Blood or DNA test not required. —

Nothing in former § 14-2-102(b)'s language dictates that a blood or DNA test is a prerequisite to determining which of two presumptions is “founded on the weightier considerations of policy and logic.” LC v. TL, 870 P.2d 374, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 513 U.S. 871, 115 S. Ct. 195, 130 L. Ed. 2d 127, 1994 U.S. LEXIS 6327 (U.S. 1994).

Where evidence supports finding of paternity. —

Although the court did not make a specific finding that defendant was the father, it did find that the natural mother and presumptive father were separated during the conceptive period and without sexual access, that such access had existed between the mother and defendant, that there was no evidence of sexual access by a third party and that the testimony rebutted the presumption of parentage by the presumptive father. Accordingly, the trial court found the defendant to be the father. Vigil v. Tafoya, 600 P.2d 721, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 457 (Wyo. 1979).

Res judicata barred plaintiff's second action to establish his paternity and to rebut presumed paternity of mother's husband where involuntary dismissal of first suit for failure to appear was adjudication on the merits and facts, parties, claims and issues raised or that could have been raised were the same; fact that defendants were divorced after first suit did not alter identity of parties nor provide basis for a different claim. CLS v. CLJ, 693 P.2d 774, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 424 (Wyo. 1985).

Action by child not barred by prior action by mother. —

A child who has not been included as a party in any prior paternity case nor any prior divorce action cannot be foreclosed by the doctrines of res judicata, collateral estoppel, or judicial estoppel with respect to the child's subsequent effort to achieve determination of paternity. RKS v. SDM by TY (In re SDM), 882 P.2d 1217, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1994).

Summary judgment appropriate. —

The court was correct in finding that a father was entitled to the two statutory presumptions as a matter of law, and where the presumptions were unrebutted, he was entitled to summary judgment. KC v. KM (In re IC), 941 P.2d 46, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 1997).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Recognition of child within statutes affecting status or rights of illegitimates, 33 ALR2d 705.

Proof of husband's impotency or sterility as rebutting presumption of legitimacy, 84 ALR3d 495.

Who may dispute presumption of legitimacy of child conceived or born during wedlock, 90 ALR3d 1032.

Article 6. Voluntary Acknowledgment of Paternity

  • § 14-2-601.  Acknowledgment of paternity.
  • § 14-2-602.  Execution of acknowledgment of paternity.
  • § 14-2-603.  Denial of paternity.
  • § 14-2-604.  Rules for acknowledgment and denial of paternity.
  • § 14-2-605.  Effect of acknowledgment or denial of paternity.
  • § 14-2-606.  No filing fee.
  • § 14-2-607.  Proceeding for rescission.
  • § 14-2-608.  Challenge after expiration of period for rescission.
  • § 14-2-609.  Procedure for rescission or challenge.
  • § 14-2-610.  Ratification barred.
  • § 14-2-611.  Full faith and credit.
  • § 14-2-612.  Forms for acknowledgment and denial of paternity.
  • § 14-2-613.  Release of information.
  • § 14-2-614.  Adoption of rules.

§ 14-2-601. Acknowledgment of paternity.

  1. The mother of a child and a man claiming to be the genetic father of the child may sign an acknowledgment of paternity with intent to establish the man’s paternity.
  2. An acknowledgment of paternity of a child born in Wyoming may be filed with the state office of vital records.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

§ 14-2-602. Execution of acknowledgment of paternity.

  1. An acknowledgment of paternity shall:
    1. Be in a record;
    2. Be signed, or otherwise authenticated, under penalty for false swearing by the mother and by the man seeking to establish his paternity;
    3. State that the child whose paternity is being acknowledged:
      1. Does not have a presumed father, or has a presumed father whose full name is stated; and
      2. Does not have another acknowledged or adjudicated father.
    4. State whether there has been genetic testing and, if so, that the acknowledging man’s claim of paternity is consistent with the results of the testing; and
    5. State that the signatories understand that the acknowledgment is the equivalent of a judicial adjudication of paternity of the child and that a challenge to the acknowledgment is permitted only under limited circumstances and is barred after two (2) years.
  2. An acknowledgment of paternity is void if it:
    1. States that another man is a presumed father, unless a denial of paternity signed or otherwise authenticated by the presumed father or a court order rebutting the presumption is filed with the state office of vital records;
    2. States that another man is an acknowledged or adjudicated father; or
    3. Falsely denies the existence of a presumed, acknowledged or adjudicated father of the child.
  3. A presumed father may sign or otherwise authenticate an acknowledgment of paternity.
  4. Before a mother and a man claiming to be the genetic father of a child can sign an acknowledgment of paternity affidavit, the mother and the alleged father shall be provided notice orally or through use of video or audio equipment and in writing of the alternatives to, the legal consequences of, and the rights and responsibilities that arise from, signing the acknowledgment of paternity affidavit. If either the mother or the alleged father is a minor, any rights that attach as a result of the status as a minor shall also be provided orally or through the use of video or audio equipment and in writing, in addition to any other requirements of this subsection.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1; 2004, ch. 10, § 1.

The 2004 amendment, effective July 1, 2004, added (d).

§ 14-2-603. Denial of paternity.

  1. A presumed father may sign a denial of his paternity. The denial is valid only if:
    1. An acknowledgment of paternity signed, or otherwise authenticated, by another man is filed pursuant to W.S. 14-2-605 ;
    2. The denial is in a record, and is signed, or otherwise authenticated, under penalty of perjury; and
    3. The presumed father has not previously:
      1. Acknowledged his paternity, unless the previous acknowledgment has been rescinded pursuant to W.S. 14-2-607 or successfully challenged pursuant to W.S. 14-2-608 ; or
      2. Been adjudicated to be the father of the child.

History. Laws 2003, ch. 93, § 1.

Editor's notes. —
