In developing the plan, the department shall collaborate with the business councils of the Northern Arapaho tribe and Eastern Shoshone tribe, state and local agencies, including the department of health, the department of workforce services, the department of employment, the department of education, the department of corrections, the Wyoming business council, the University of Wyoming, Wyoming community colleges, the judiciary and private groups, service providers and businesses, including faith-based organizations and not-for-profit organizations, that express an interest in participating in the development of the plan. The plan shall:

“(i) Consider development of mechanisms to employ the use of public and private resources in an efficient manner to meet the needs of children and families;

“(ii) Include life span recommendations, including, in particular, prenatal and early childhood intervention and development practices that promote meaningful lifetime changes and minimize delays in life skills development;

“(iii) Review the current judicial system and make recommendations for reforms that may enable courts to better meet the needs of children and families;

“(iv) Examine how schools, community organizations, state agencies and the judicial system can work more closely together to enhance a sharing of resources and information to meet the needs of parents, preschool children and elementary and secondary school students;

“(v) Examine causes of the most serious problems facing children and families, including poverty, mental health needs, violence, the lack of adequate health care, the use of tobacco and illegal drugs and the abuse of alcohol;

“(vi) Examine issues of parent accountability;

“(vii) Encourage and support family stability;

“(viii) Not discriminate against private service providers in favor of governmental providers; and

“(ix) Review the state's existing efforts to determine where present funding and human resources could be employed in a more client-centered and efficient manner.

“(b) The department of family services shall submit a preliminary plan with recommendations for any initial legislation to the joint labor, health and social services interim committee no later than November 1, 2004. The final plan shall be submitted no later than October 1, 2005. Any recommendations contained in the plan shall be science-based or reflect practices that have a record of success. The plan shall specifically include recommendations:

“(i) For institutionalizing collaboration among state and local agencies and the private sector, including the business and faith community to provide seamless and integrated services in which funding is blended, when appropriate, to support client-centered plans that meet the needs of individual children and families;

“(ii) For addressing gaps or deficiencies in services;

“(iii) For early intervention and other services that seek to strengthen the bond between children and parents and place the primary responsibility for raising children on the family;

“(iv) For the consolidation of programs or funding sources where appropriate;

“(v) For the development of comprehensive, integrated state and community level approaches that will leave no child unsupported in critical aspects of life, particularly from birth through five (5) years of age;

“(vi) That will result in more integrated, efficient and effective programs and cost savings.

“(c) The department shall widely disseminate requests, including through electronic media, for the active participation of private groups and organizations in the development of the plans. Before submitting the preliminary and final plans to the joint labor, health and social services interim committee, the department shall issue drafts of the plans for public review and hold at least one (1) public meeting in a central location in the state to receive public comments on each plan.

“(d) In addition to the appropriation contained in subsection (e) of this section, the department of family services, the department of health, the department of workforce services, the department of employment, the department of education, the department of corrections, the Wyoming business council, the University of Wyoming, Wyoming community colleges and the judiciary may utilize existing resources and apply for any federal or private grants that may be available to augment funding for the study and plan required under this act. The department may also contract with recognized experts and consultants to conduct the study and develop the plan and recommendations required by this act.

“(e) There is appropriated from the general fund to the department of family services two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) to implement the purposes of this act.”

Laws 2004, ch. 44, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2004.

Program to reimburse guardians ad litem. —

Laws 2005, ch. 237, § 1, effective July 1, 2005, appropriates $2,100,000, or so much thereof as is necessary for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2005, from the general fund to the Wyoming supreme court to establish and administer a program to reimburse attorneys providing legal representation as guardians ad litem in child protection cases under §§ 14-3-101 through 14-3-440 , children in need of supervision cases under §§ 14-6-401 through 14-6-440 , or termination of parental rights actions brought as a result of a child protection or children in need of supervision action. In order to execute this program, the act, in part, directs the district judges' judicial conference to recommend to the board of judicial policy and administration rules and regulations governing standards for the legal representation by attorneys as guardians ad litem in child protection or children in need of supervision cases and for the training of those attorneys. The act, in part, directs the board of judicial policy and administration to adopt rules and regulations governing standards for the legal representation by attorneys as guardians ad litem in child protection or children in need of supervision cases and for the training of those attorneys. The act, in part, directs the supreme court to enter into agreements with the individual counties of the state participating in the program to provide reimbursement for the legal representation of children by attorneys as guardians ad litem in child protection or children in need of supervision cases, and directs the supreme court to provide necessary administrative support for the reimbursement program. No state money appropriated under the act is to be expended in any county unless the county agrees to match, at a minimum, 25% of the state money for the reimbursement of legal representation of children by attorneys in child protection or children in need of supervision cases. In consultation with the board of judicial policy and administration, the supreme court and the individual county are to establish the reimbursement rate within the county for attorneys providing legal representation as guardians ad litem in child protection and children in need of supervision cases. The supreme court is to report each year on or before November 1 to the joint judiciary interim committee and the joint appropriations interim committee on the results of the program authorized by this section, including the number of cases and the amount of monies expended for reimbursements and the amounts of matching monies from participating counties.

Cited in

In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992).

Article 1. Prohibited Acts

  • §§ 14-3-101 through 14-3-103.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-3-104.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-3-105.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-3-106.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-3-107.  Performing body-art on persons who have not reached the age of majority; penalties; definition.
  • § 14-3-108.  Use of ultraviolet tanning devices by persons who have not reached the age of majority; presence required; consent required; penalty.

Cross references. —

As to penalty for leaving abandoned iceboxes or refrigerators in places easily accessible to children without taking precautions, see § 35-10-407 .

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Constitutionality, with respect to accused's rights to information or confrontation, of statute according confidentiality to sex crime victim's communications to sexual counselor, 43 ALR4th 395.

§§ 14-3-101 through 14-3-103. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1982, ch. 75, § 5; 1983, ch. 171, § 3.

Cross references. —

§ 14-3-104. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 159, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 159, § 3.

Cross references. —

As to sexual battery, see § 6-2-313 .

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1957, ch. 220, § 8, related to penalty for immoral or indecent acts.

§ 14-3-106. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 159, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

This section which derived from Laws 1983, ch. 155, § 1, related to penalties of violation of the restrictions on disclosure of names or publication of information.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and application of state statutes or ordinances regulating sexual performance by child, 42 ALR5th 291.

§ 14-3-107. Performing body-art on persons who have not reached the age of majority; penalties; definition.

  1. No person shall knowingly perform body-art upon or under the skin of a person who has not reached the age of majority, except with the consent of the person’s parent or legal guardian who is present at the time the body-art procedure is performed upon the person. The person performing the body-art procedure shall demand proof of age prior to administering the body-art procedure upon the person. A motor vehicle driver’s license, a registration card issued under the federal Selective Service Act, an identification card issued to a member of the armed forces, a valid United States passport, a tribal identification card issued by the governing body of the Eastern Shoshone tribe of Wyoming or the Northern Arapahoe tribe of Wyoming or an identification card issued by the department of transportation is prima facie evidence of the age and identity of the person. Proof that the person performing the body-art procedure demanded, was shown and acted in reasonable reliance upon the information contained in any one (1) of the above documents as identification and proof of age is a defense to any criminal prosecution under this section.
  2. Any person violating this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or both.
  3. As used in this section:
    1. “Body-art” means the practice of physical body adornment utilizing body piercing, branding, scarification, sculpting or tattooing. This definition does not include practices conducted under the supervision of a physician licensed to practice medicine under Wyoming law nor does this definition include piercing of the outer perimeter or lobe of the ear by means of sterilized stud-and-clasp ear piercing systems;
    2. “Body piercing” means any puncturing or penetration of the skin or mucosa of a person and the insertion of jewelry or other adornment in the opening;
    3. “Branding” means any invasive procedure in which a permanent mark is burned into or onto the skin using either temperature, mechanical or chemical means;
    4. “Scarification” means any invasive procedure in which the intended result is the production of scar tissue on the surface of the skin;
    5. “Sculpting” means any modification of the skin, mucosa, cartilage or tissue of the body for nonmedical purposes;
    6. “Tattoo” means any indelible design, letter, scroll, figure, symbol or any other mark placed upon or under the skin with ink or colors, by the aid of needles or other instruments.

History. Laws 1995, ch. 186, § 1; 2004, ch. 47, § 1; 2005, ch. 130, § 2.

The 2004 amendment, effective July 1, 2004, substituted references pertaining to body-art for references pertaining to tatooing throughout (a); and added (c)(i) through (c)(v), making related changes.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, added the reference to the tribal identification card in (a).

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

§ 14-3-108. Use of ultraviolet tanning devices by persons who have not reached the age of majority; presence required; consent required; penalty.

  1. No person other than the minor’s parent or legal guardian shall knowingly allow a minor who has not reached fifteen (15) years of age to use an ultraviolet tanning device, unless the minor’s parent or legal guardian consents in writing to the use and is present the entire time of use. No person shall knowingly allow a minor age fifteen (15) years to the age of majority to use an ultraviolet tanning device, except with written consent obtained from the minor’s parent or legal guardian. Any person other than the minor’s parent or legal guardian allowing the use of an ultraviolet tanning device by a minor shall demand proof of age prior to allowing the use of an ultraviolet tanning device. A motor vehicle driver’s license, a registration card issued under the federal Selective Service Act, an identification card issued to a member of the armed forces, a valid United States passport, a tribal identification card issued by the governing body of the Eastern Shoshone tribe of Wyoming or the Northern Arapahoe tribe of Wyoming or an identification card issued by the department of transportation is prima facie evidence of the age and identity under this section. Proof that the person allowing the use of the ultraviolet tanning device demanded, was shown and acted in reasonable reliance upon the information contained in any one (1) of the above documents as identification and proof of age is a defense to any criminal prosecution under this section.
  2. Any person violating this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
  3. As used in this section:
    1. “Consent” means that the parent or legal guardian appears at the first time the minor uses the ultraviolet tanning device and signs a written consent form in the presence of the owner or an employee of the facility. The minor’s parent or legal guardian may withdraw this consent at any time. Unless so withdrawn, this consent shall be valid for twelve (12) months from the date the written consent form is signed. The parent or legal guardian must repeat the written consent process annually until the minor reaches the age of majority;
    2. “Present” means being physically present at the facility at which the tanning device is being used, but does not require the presence in the tanning room or booth being used;
    3. “Ultraviolet tanning device” means equipment that emits electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths in the air between two hundred (200) and four hundred (400) nanometers used for tanning of the skin, including, but not limited to, a sunlamp, tanning booth or tanning bed, but does not include equipment that emits ultraviolet radiation used by a health care professional in the treatment of disease or used pursuant to a prescription.

History. Laws 2010, ch. 114, § 1.

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

Article 2. Child Protective Services

  • § 14-3-201.  Purpose.
  • § 14-3-202.  Definitions.
  • § 14-3-203.  Duties of state agency; on-call services.
  • § 14-3-204.  Duties of local child protective agency.
  • § 14-3-205.  Child abuse or neglect; persons required to report.
  • § 14-3-206.  Child abuse or neglect; written report; statewide reporting center; documentation and examination; costs and admissibility thereof.
  • § 14-3-207.  Abuse or neglect as suspected cause of death; coroner's investigation.
  • § 14-3-208.  Temporary protective custody; order; time limitation; remedial health care.
  • § 14-3-209.  Immunity from liability.
  • § 14-3-210.  Admissibility of evidence constituting privileged communications.
  • § 14-3-211.  Appointment of counsel for child and other parties.
  • § 14-3-212.  Child protection teams; creation; composition; duties; records confidential.
  • § 14-3-213.  Central registry of child protection cases; establishment; operation; amendment, expungement or removal of records; classification and expungement of reports; statement of person accused.
  • § 14-3-214.  Confidentiality of records; penalties; access to information; attendance of school officials at interviews; access to central registry records pertaining to child protection cases.
  • § 14-3-215.  Interagency children's collaborative.
  • § 14-3-216.  Other laws not superseded.

Cross references. —

As to privileged communication by a licensed or certified mental health professional, see § 33-38-113 .

Burden of proof in contested hearings. —

Where, in a contested hearing, the department of family services asserts that a child abuse allegation against a parent has been substantiated, the agency has both the initial burden of production and the ultimate burden of persuasion. JM v. Department of Family Servs., 922 P.2d 219, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 118 (Wyo. 1996).

In contested hearings under this article, the traditional preponderance-of-the-evidence standard applies. JM v. Department of Family Servs., 922 P.2d 219, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 118 (Wyo. 1996).

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

The department of family services rule that limits the issues in a contested case hearing to a determination of whether the agency acted in accordance with the law or its own rules does not comply with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act, §§ 16-3-101 through 16-3-115 , because it prevents the department from conducting a full review of the factual issues at the contested hearing. JM v. Department of Family Servs., 922 P.2d 219, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 118 (Wyo. 1996).

Physician-patient and psychologist-client privileges limited by this article. —

Because of the overriding importance that the state attaches to halting and preventing child abuse, privileges created between physician-patient and psychologist-client by §§ 1-12-101 and 33-27-103 (now 33-27-123 ) are limited by the subsequent enactment of this article, which sets forth a procedure for ascertaining and correcting child abuse and neglect. In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

Applied in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “The Family Violence Protection Act: A New Remedy for an Old Problem,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 691 (1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Tort liability of public authority for failure to remove parentally abused or neglected children from parents' custody, 60 ALR4th 942.

Denial or restriction of visitation rights to parent charged with sexually abusing child, 1 ALR5th 776.

Failure of state or local government entity to protect child abuse victim as violation of federal constitutional right, 79 ALR Fed 514.

Physical examination of child's body for evidence of abuse as violative of fourth amendment or as raising fourth amendment issue, 93 ALR Fed 530.

§ 14-3-201. Purpose.

The purpose of W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 is to delineate the responsibilities of the state agency, other governmental agencies or officials, professionals and citizens to intervene on behalf of a child suspected of being abused or neglected, to protect the best interest of the child, to further offer protective services when necessary in order to prevent any harm to the child or any other children living in the home, to protect children from abuse or neglect which jeopardize their health or welfare, to stabilize the home environment, to preserve family life whenever possible and to provide permanency for the child in appropriate circumstances. The child’s health, safety and welfare shall be of paramount concern in implementing and enforcing this article.

History. Laws 1957, ch. 220, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-21; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-105; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1995, ch. 136, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote the section, which read: “The purpose of W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 is to protect the best interest of the child or a disabled adult, to further offer protective services when necessary in order to prevent any harm to the child or any other children living in the home or to a disabled adult, to protect children or disabled adults from abuse or neglect which jeopardize their health or welfare, to stabilize the home environment and to preserve family life whenever possible.”

Grandparents' motion denied.—

Juvenile court did not make an unreasonable decision in denying the grandparents' motion seeking to transfer placement of their grandchild from the foster parents to the grandparents; the child had been in the foster parents' care approximately two and a half years, testimony indicated that changing placement could be detrimental to her, the juvenile court correctly concluded that the best interests of the child were paramount, and the juvenile court's reasoning was in accord with the statute governing permanency hearings. PM v. State (In the Interest of SO), 2016 WY 99, 382 P.3d 51, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 110 (Wyo. 2016).

Quoted in

JM v. Department of Family Servs., 922 P.2d 219, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 118 (Wyo. 1996); Johnson v. State, 922 P.2d 1384, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1996).

Stated in

Michael v. Hertzler, 900 P.2d 1144, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 136 (Wyo. 1995).

Cited in

City of Laramie v. Hysong, 808 P.2d 199, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1991); RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 16, 2014).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Evidence — Child Abuse and the Medical Diagnosis or Treatment Exception to the Hearsay Rule. Goldade v. State, 674 P.2d 721, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1983),” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 735 (1985).

§ 14-3-202. Definitions.

  1. As used in W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 :
    1. “A person responsible for a child’s welfare” includes the child’s parent, noncustodial parent, guardian, custodian, stepparent, foster parent or other person, institution or agency having the physical custody or control of the child;
    2. “Abuse” means inflicting or causing physical or mental injury, harm or imminent danger to the physical or mental health or welfare of a child other than by accidental means, including abandonment, unless the abandonment is a relinquishment substantially in accordance with W.S. 14-11-101 through 14-11-109 , excessive or unreasonable corporal punishment, malnutrition or substantial risk thereof by reason of intentional or unintentional neglect, and the commission or allowing the commission of a sexual offense against a child as defined by law:
      1. “Mental injury” means an injury to the psychological capacity or emotional stability of a child as evidenced by an observable or substantial impairment in his ability to function within a normal range of performance and behavior with due regard to his culture;
      2. “Physical injury” means any harm to a child including but not limited to disfigurement, impairment of any bodily organ, skin bruising if greater in magnitude than minor bruising associated with reasonable corporal punishment, bleeding, burns, fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma or substantial malnutrition;
      3. “Substantial risk” means a strong possibility as contrasted with a remote or insignificant possibility;
      4. “Imminent danger” includes threatened harm and means a statement, overt act, condition or status which represents an immediate and substantial risk of sexual abuse or physical or mental injury. “Imminent danger” includes violation of W.S. 31-5-233(m).
    3. “Child” means any person under the age of eighteen (18);
    4. “Child protective agency” means the field or regional offices of the department of family services;
    5. “Court proceedings” means child protective proceedings which have as their purpose the protection of a child through an adjudication of whether the child is abused or neglected, and the making of an appropriate order of disposition;
    6. “Institutional child abuse and neglect” means situations of child abuse or neglect where a foster home or other public or private residential home, institution or agency is responsible for the child’s welfare;
    7. “Neglect” means a failure or refusal by those responsible for the child’s welfare to provide adequate care, maintenance, supervision, education or medical, surgical or any other care necessary for the child’s well being. Treatment given in good faith by spiritual means alone, through prayer, by a duly accredited practitioner in accordance with the tenets and practices of a recognized church or religious denomination is not child neglect for that reason alone;
    8. “State agency” means the state department of family services;
    9. “Subject of the report” means any child reported under W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 or the child’s parent, guardian or other person responsible for the child’s welfare;
    10. “Unsubstantiated report” means any report made pursuant to W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 that, upon investigation, is not supported by a preponderance of the evidence;
    11. “Substantiated report” means any report of child abuse or neglect made pursuant to W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 that, upon investigation, is supported by a preponderance of the evidence;
    12. through (xiv) Repealed by Laws 2002, ch. 86, § 3.
    13. “Collaborative” means the interagency children’s collaborative created by W.S. 14-3-215 ;
    14. “Department” means the state department of family services and its local offices;
    15. “Transportation” means the provision of a means to convey the child from one place to another by the custodian or someone acting on his behalf in the performance of required duties, but does not require the state to provide incidental travel or to purchase a motor vehicle for the child’s own use to travel.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 181, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.7; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-113; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1983, ch. 146, § 1; 1991, ch. 161, § 3; 1993, ch. 1, § 1; ch. 44, § 1; 1994, ch. 39, § 1; 1995, ch. 136, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 86, §§ 2, 3; ch. 89, § 1; 2003, ch. 167, § 2; 2005, ch. 23, § 1; ch. 236, § 2; 2006, ch. 114, § 1; 2007, ch. 72, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to sexual offenses against children, see chapter 4 of title 6.

The 2005 amendments. —

The first 2005 amendment, by ch. 23, § 1, effective July 1, 2005, in (a)(x) substituted “Unsubstantiated” for “Unfounded,” in (a)(x) and (a)(xi) inserted provisions requiring investigation and changed the standard of evidence from credible to a preponderance, and made stylistic changes.

The second 2005 amendment, by ch. 236, § 2, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “14-3-216” for “14-3-215” in (a), (a)(x) and (a)(xi); added (a)(xv), (a)(xvi), (a)(xvii); and made a stylistic change.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2006 amendment, in (a), substituted “14-3-216” for “14-3-215.”

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, in (a)(ii)(D), added the last sentence referring to “Imminent danger.”

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3 provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Sufficient evidence of abuse.

Evidence was sufficient to support defendants’ convictions for physically abusing the victim because the victim testified that defendant would sometimes use the black belt as punishment if the victim did not complete his chores, the belt would leave bruises on his bottom, back, and legs, and his three siblings testified that both defendants used a backscratcher to beat the victim. Larkins v. State, 2018 WY 122, 429 P.3d 28, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 2018).

Evidence was sufficient to support defendant’s conviction of mentally abusing two victims because one victim was diagnosed with PTSD and a counselor and a physician attributed the victims’ mental illnesses, in part, to the abuse they suffered and witnessed by defendants. Larkins v. State, 2018 WY 122, 429 P.3d 28, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 2018).

In a felony child abuse case, a district court erred when it failed to instruct the jury in the elements instruction of the count relating to the victim that physical injury excluded “reasonable corporal punishment”; the error was plain because the instructions were confusing as to the burden of proof. However, the State was entitled to retry defendant because it presented sufficient evidence to support a verdict finding that the victim's physical injuries due to getting hit in the ribs and slapped in the face were not the result of reasonable corporal punishment. Andersen v. State, 2014 WY 88, 330 P.3d 256, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 2014).

Trial court did not abuse its discretion by denying a motion for judgment of acquittal because the evidence was sufficient to support a conviction for felony child abuse; defendant used wood to spank the victim, which left abrasions, bruises, and lacerations. Defendant's argument that the injuries were not serious and that he acted reasonably was misplaced; because the State was entitled to all favorable inferences that could have been drawn from the evidence, the jury was free to reject defendant's proffered justifications for the abuse. Swan v. State, 2014 WY 38, 320 P.3d 235, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 2014).

“Sexual contact,” as defined by sexual assault provisions, amounts to “abuse.” —

“Sexual contact,” as defined by § 6-2-301(a)(vi) (sexual assault — definitions), obviously poses a serious danger to the physical and mental well-being of a child and amounts to “abuse” within the meaning of subsection (a)(ii) of this section. In re Matter of GP, 679 P.2d 976, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 269 (Wyo. 1984).

Whether injuries accidental or deliberate important factor in ascertaining child abuse. —

In ascertaining whether a child has been a victim of abuse, it is important to discover whether the injuries sustained by the child were accidental or deliberate. Goldade v. State, 674 P.2d 721, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1983), cert. denied, 467 U.S. 1253, 104 S. Ct. 3539, 82 L. Ed. 2d 844, 1984 U.S. LEXIS 2707 (U.S. 1984).

Malnutrition. —

Severe and substantial malnutrition resulting from mother's conscious disregard was sufficient to support conviction for felony child abuse. DeWitt v. State, 917 P.2d 1144, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Wyo. 1996).

Neglect. —

In a termination of parental rights case, it was reasonable to conclude that the developmental deficiencies displayed by a child were the result of neglect by his parents; social workers never saw the parents interact with the child, the house was so cluttered and filthy that the child could not roll over if placed on the floor, the child was constantly observed in his stroller, and at the age of one, the child could not hold up his own head, could not crawl, could not talk, and did not know how to use his fingers. SD v. Carbon County Dep't of Family Servs. (In re SED), 2002 WY 168, 57 P.3d 1235, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 195 (Wyo. 2002).

It was no error to adjudicate a noncustodial father neglectful because Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-202(a)(i) did not require a parent to have physical custody of a child to be defined as “a person responsible for a child's welfare,” as prior to the use of the first “or” in the statute, the legislature listed categories of individuals who, by fitting into one of those categories, inherently were responsible for a child's welfare whether the child was in their custody or not, as long as a noncustodial parent had knowledge and an opportunity to act and failed or refused to do so, and categories listed after the “or” were broad and had no inherent responsibility towards a child, so the legislature modified those falling into that category by requiring physical custody or control of the child. TW v. State (In re JB), 2017 WY 26, 390 P.3d 357, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2017).

In order for a noncustodial parent—whether he or she lives in a different town, state, or country voluntarily, due to military deployment, or any other reason—to be deemed neglectful of a child, the State must prove that he or she had the knowledge and opportunity to act and he or she failed or refused to do so. TW v. State (In re JB), 2017 WY 26, 390 P.3d 357, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2017).

Evidence was sufficient to support the trial court's finding of neglect based on the mother's unsanitary and unkempt home because it showed that: (1) the children's food was rotten, and that it came from the dumpsters of nearby grocery stores; (2) there were bloodied cloth rags strewn about the upstairs bathroom; (3) there was a foul smell throughout the house; (4) one child's room lacked an apparent heat source and was cold; (5) water leaked from the bathroom into the child's room; (6) dog and cat feces remained on the floors without being cleaned up; and (7) trash and dirty laundry was scattered around the house. DL v. State (In re MC), 2013 WY 43, 299 P.3d 75, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 2013).

Evidence was sufficient to support the neglect finding based on the mother's use of and availability of marijuana because the trial court could have reasonably concluded that it was neglectful to expose a 12-year-old child to the use of marijuana to the extent that he was knowledgeable as to its effects and was able to find it in the home. DL v. State (In re MC), 2013 WY 43, 299 P.3d 75, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 2013).

“Substantiated report.” —

Subsection (a)(xi) suggests that an abuse report has been substantiated when an investigation reveals that credible evidence exists to support the allegations. JM v. Department of Family Servs., 922 P.2d 219, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 118 (Wyo. 1996) (decided prior to 2005 amendment).

Sufficient evidence of abuse. —

Trial court had before it sufficient evidence to show that children had been abused under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-202(a)(ii)(B); the children's statements to a detective, as well as photographs, indicated that they were bitten by the mother's boyfriend. SC v. State (In re NC), 2013 WY 2, 294 P.3d 866, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 2013).

Imminent risk of physical injury. —

Jury could reasonably conclude that placing an eight-month-old baby in a fleece bag and tying it shut placed the child in imminent risk of physical injury under Wyo. Stat. §§ 14-3-202(a)(ii) and (vii), 14-2-309 . In re Cs v. Johnson County Dep't of Family Servs., 2006 WY 130, 143 P.3d 918, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 145 (2006).

Parental rights terminated due to domestic violence and other issues. —

Court properly terminated a father's parental rights where the child was subjected to domestic violence, and where the father failed to follow the case plan, failed to obtain consistent and adequate housing, and failed to visit the child as often as allowed. RS v. Dept. of Family Servs. (In re KLS), 2004 WY 87, 94 P.3d 1025, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 115 (Wyo. 2004).

Substantial evidence existed to support the Department's finding, where it found that the available facts, when viewed in light of surrounding circumstances, would cause a reasonable person to believe that the child was abused or neglected. RM v. Department of Family Servs.(In re Fair Hearing Request), 953 P.2d 477, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1998).

In parental-rights-termination proceeding, instructions as to low socioeconomic standing and slovenliness properly refused. —

In a proceeding to terminate parental rights on the grounds of neglect, instructions proffered by the mother stating that parental rights cannot be terminated on the basis that the natural parents, because of low social or economic standing, cannot provide their children with all the advantages that more affluent, better educated foster parents could provide, and stating that parental rights may not be terminated solely on the grounds of slovenliness, were properly refused. MS v. Kuchera, 682 P.2d 982, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 290 (Wyo. 1984).

Mental injury.—

Defendants did not dispute at their trial for multiple counts of child abuse that their children suffered mental injury because each of their children was found to have significant deficits in their social and behavioral development and two of their children were diagnosed with attention deficit disorders. Gifford v. State, 2017 WY 93, 399 P.3d 1240, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 92 (Wyo. 2017).

Opinion evidence concerning abuse. —

Witness could offer his opinions concerning the children's abuse as a lay witness under Wyo. R. Evid. 701 because he did not testify that visits with the mother were abuse under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-202(a)(ii), but merely intended to convey his opinion that the intermittent nature of their visits with the mother was causing problems for the children in adjusting to their lives without their mother. M.L. v. Laramie County Dep't of Family Servs. (In the Interest of L.L.), 2007 WY 92, 159 P.3d 499, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 2007).

Applied in

DS v. Department of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 607 P.2d 911, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1980); In re Child X, 617 P.2d 1078, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 308 (Wyo. 1980); In re SKJ, 673 P.2d 640, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 399 (Wyo. 1983).

Quoted in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982); Keser v. State, 706 P.2d 263, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 553 (Wyo. 1985); Campbell v. State, 709 P.2d 425, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 608 (Wyo. 1985); TR v. Washakie County Dep't of Pub. Assistance & Social Servs., 736 P.2d 712, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 431 (Wyo. 1987); Johnson v. State, 922 P.2d 1384, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1996); Jo v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (in the Interest of Re), 2011 WY 170, 267 P.3d 1092, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Dec. 28, 2011).

Cited in

RS v. Johnson County Dept. of Family Servs. (In re JL), 989 P.2d 1268, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 164 (Wyo. 1999); MN v. Dept' of Family Servs. (In the Interest of MN), 2003 WY 135, 78 P.3d 232, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 163 (Wyo. 2003).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Child Protection: A Suggested Role for Members of the Wyoming State Bar,” see IX Land & Water L. Rev. 187 (1974).

For article, “Goodbye 3-Card Monte: The Wyoming Criminal Code of 1982” (part two), see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 509 (1984).

For comment, “Fetal Equality?: The Equality State's Response to the Challenge of Protecting Unborn Children,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 193 (1997).

For article, “The Wyoming Criminal Code Revisited: Reflections after Fifteen Years,” see XXXIII Land and Water L. Rev. 523 (1998).

§ 14-3-203. Duties of state agency; on-call services.

  1. The state agency shall:
    1. Administer W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 ;
    2. Be responsible for strengthening and improving state and community efforts toward the prevention, identification and treatment of child abuse and neglect in the state; and
    3. Refer any person or family seeking assistance in meeting child care responsibilities, whether or not the problem presented by the person or family is child abuse or neglect, to appropriate community resources, agencies, services or facilities.
    4. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 4.
  2. The state agency may contract for assistance in providing on-call services. The assistance may include screening protection calls, making appropriate referrals to law enforcement and the agency, and maintaining a record of calls and referrals. Contractors shall have training in child protection services.
  3. The state agency shall ensure that all child protective service workers are trained:
    1. In the principles of family centered practice that focus on providing services to the entire family to achieve the goals of safety and permanency for children, including balancing the best interests of children with the rights of parents;
    2. In the duty of the workers to inform the individual subject to a child abuse or neglect allegation, at the earliest opportunity during the initial contact, of the specific complaints or allegations made against the individual;
    3. Concerning constitutional and statutory rights of children and families from and after the initial time of contact and the worker’s legal duty not to violate the constitutional and statutory rights of children and families from and after the initial time of contact;
    4. To know the state’s legal definitions of physical abuse, sexual abuse, neglect, dependency and endangerment;
    5. To know the provisions of federal and state laws governing child welfare practice, including but not limited to the Adoption and Safe Families Act, Indian Child Welfare Act, Multi-Ethnic Placement Act, the Child Abuse Prevention Treatment Act and the Family First Prevention Services Act, as amended;
    6. To make reasonable efforts to determine if the person responsible for the welfare of a child in a suspected case of child abuse or neglect is a member of the armed forces or if the child is enrolled in the defense enrollment eligibility reporting system of the United States department of defense.

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-114; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1989, ch. 125, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, §§ 2, 4; 2006, ch. 114, § 1; 2017, ch. 3, § 1; 2019, ch. 143, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, repealed former (a)(iv) relating to diagnosis and referral for treatment of osteogenesis imperfecta and hemophilia; and added (c).

The 2006 amendment, in (a), inserted “and” at the end of (ii); and made a related change in (iii).

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, added (c)(vi).

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in (c)(v), added “and the Family First Prevention Services Act” and made related changes.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3 provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Stated in

RM v. Department of Family Servs., 953 P.2d 477, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1998).

Federal Law. —

The Adoption and Safe Families Act is PL 105-89 and is codified primarily in 42 U.S.C.S. § 629 et seq. The Indian Child Welfare Act is codified as 29 U.S.C.S. § 1901 et seq. The Multi-Ethnic Placement Act is PL 103-382, which was codified as 42 U.S.C.S. § 5115a et seq. before being repealed. Similar provisions are at 42 U.S.C.S. § 1996b. The Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act is codified as 42 U.S.C.S. § 5101 et seq.

§ 14-3-204. Duties of local child protective agency.

  1. The local child protective agency shall:
    1. Repealed by Laws 2017, ch. 179, §  2.
    2. Receive, assess, investigate or arrange for investigation and coordinate investigation or assessment of all reports of known or suspected child abuse or neglect;
    3. Within twenty-four (24) hours after notification of a suspected case of child abuse or neglect, initiate an investigation or assessment to verify every report. The representative of the child protective agency shall, at the initial time of contact with the individual subject to a child abuse and neglect investigation or assessment, advise the individual of the specific complaints or allegations made against the individual. A thorough investigation or assessment and report of child abuse or neglect shall be made in the manner and time prescribed by the state agency pursuant to rules and regulations adopted in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. If the child protective agency is denied reasonable access to a child by a parent or other persons and the agency deems that the best interest of the child so requires, it shall seek an appropriate court order by ex parte proceedings or other appropriate proceedings to see the child. The child protective agency shall assign a report:
      1. For investigation when allegations contained in the report indicate:
        1. That criminal charges could be filed, the child appears to be in imminent danger and it is likely the child will need to be removed from the home; or
        2. A child fatality, major injury or sexual abuse has occurred.
      2. For assessment when the report does not meet the criteria of subparagraph (A) of this paragraph.
    4. If the investigation or assessment discloses that abuse or neglect is present, initiate services with the family of the abused or neglected child to assist in resolving problems that lead to or caused the child abuse or neglect;
    5. If the child protective agency is able through investigation to substantiate a case of abuse or neglect, it shall notify the person suspected of causing the abuse or neglect by first class mail to his last known address of his right to request a hearing on the agency’s determination for a final determination before the office of administrative hearings pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act;
    6. Make reasonable efforts to contact the noncustodial parent of the child and inform the parent of substantiated abuse or neglect in high risk or moderate risk cases as determined pursuant to rules and regulations of the state agency and inform the parent of any proposed action to be taken;
    7. Cooperate, coordinate and assist with the prosecution and law enforcement agencies;
    8. When the best interest of the child requires court action, contact the county and prosecuting attorney to initiate legal proceedings and assist the county and prosecuting attorney during the proceedings. If the county attorney elects not to bring court action the local child protective agency may petition the court for appointment of a guardian ad litem who shall act in the best interest of the child and who may petition the court to direct the county attorney to show cause why an action should not be commenced under W.S. 14-3-401 through 14-3-439 ;
    9. Refer a child receiving department services who is under the age of six (6) years to the department of health, division of developmental disabilities preschool program for educational and developmental screening and assessment; and
    10. Make reasonable efforts to determine if the person  responsible for the welfare of a child in a suspected case of child  abuse or neglect is a member of the armed forces or if the child is  enrolled in the defense enrollment eligibility reporting system of  the United States department of defense.
  2. The local child protective agency may appeal an adverse determination of the office of administrative hearings.

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.7:2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-115; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1993, ch. 44, § 1; 1997, ch. 199, § 2; 2005, ch. 236, § 2; 2009, ch. 127, § 1; 2013, ch. 142, § 1; 2017, ch. 3, § 1; ch. 179, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, inserted provisions for assessment throughout; rewrote (a)(iii), adding the second and last sentences including (a)(iii)(A) and (a)(iii)(B) and adding provisions that investigation and assessments or reports should be made in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act; added (a)(v), redesignating former (a)(v) through (a)(vii) as (a)(vi) through (a)(viii); and added (a)(ix).

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, inserted “by first class mail to his last known address” and “on the agency's determination for a final determination before the office of administrative hearings” in (a)(v); and added (b).

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, substituted “assessment to verify every report” for “assessment and verification of every report” in the first sentence in (a)(iii).

The 2017 amendments. — The first 2017 amendment, by ch. 3, § 1, effective July 1, 2017, added (a)(x), and made related changes.

The second 2017 amendment, by ch. 179, § 2, deleted (a)(i). Laws 2017, ch. 179, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved Feb. 17, 2017.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

State not required to show reasonable efforts to reunify where abuse and neglect not at issue. —

State was not required to show reasonable efforts to reunify the family in a parental rights termination proceeding where there was no requirement for reasonable efforts because the termination was sought on the basis that the children were left in the care of another for at least a year under and had been in foster care with the state for over fifteen of the last twenty-months. SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs.(In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2005).

Cited in

Gale v. State, 792 P.2d 570, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1990); City of Laramie v. Hysong, 808 P.2d 199, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1991); DH v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re “H” Children), 2003 WY 155, 79 P.3d 997, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 2003).

Quoted in

RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 16, 2014).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Attorney for Child Versus Guardian Ad Litem: Wyoming Creates a Hybrid, but is it a Formula for Malpractice?,” see XXXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 381 (1999).

§ 14-3-205. Child abuse or neglect; persons required to report.

  1. Any person who knows or has reasonable cause to believe or suspect that a child has been abused or neglected or who observes any child being subjected to conditions or circumstances that would reasonably result in abuse or neglect, shall immediately report it to the child protective agency or local law enforcement agency or cause a report to be made. The fact a child, who is at least sixteen (16) years of age, is homeless as defined in W.S. 14-1-102(d) shall not, in and of itself, constitute a sufficient basis for reporting neglect. Female genital mutilation under W.S. 6-2-502(a)(v) when the victim is a minor shall be considered child abuse for mandatory reporting under this section.
  2. If a person reporting child abuse or neglect is a member of the staff of a medical or other public or private institution, school, facility or agency, he shall notify the person in charge or his designated agent as soon as possible, who is thereupon also responsible to make the report or cause the report to be made. Nothing in this subsection is intended to relieve individuals of their obligation to report on their own behalf unless a report has already been made or will be made.
  3. Any employer, public or private, who discharges, suspends, disciplines or penalizes an employee solely for making a report of neglect or abuse under W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 [W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 ] is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or both.
  4. Any person who knowingly and intentionally makes a false report of child abuse or neglect, or who encourages or coerces another person to make a false report of child abuse or neglect, is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or both.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 181, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.8; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-116; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 2005, ch. 23, § 1; 2017, ch. 180, § 2; 2020, ch. 105, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, added (c) and (d).

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, added the last sentence of (a).

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) added the last sentence.

Admissibility of child's statements to physician attributing fault. —

Where a physician, given his duty and his professional responsibility to determine whether a child abuse syndrome or a condition that requires treatment is present, questions a child concerning how the child was injured in order to assist him with respect to a diagnosis of child abuse syndrome, statements elicited attributing fault are pertinent to his diagnosis and treatment, and admitting these statements into evidence pursuant to the exception contained in Rule 803(4), W.R.E., is consistent with the policy of the court in child abuse cases. Goldade v. State, 674 P.2d 721, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1983), cert. denied, 467 U.S. 1253, 104 S. Ct. 3539, 82 L. Ed. 2d 844, 1984 U.S. LEXIS 2707 (U.S. 1984).

Immunity provided from liability resulting from reporting.—

Section 14-3-209 does not limit immunity suits based only on reporting. Rather, it provides immunity from any civil or criminal liability that might otherwise result because of reporting. Immunity includes participation in legal proceedings, as well as the underlying determination of the abuse which then led to the reporting. May v. Southeast Wyo. Mental Health Ctr., 866 P.2d 732, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 1993).

Counselor was immune from civil or criminal liability for reporting the father's alleged abuse of his son under this section, and therefore her motion for summary judgment was properly granted, because she acted upon a reasonable suspicion and the father failed to rebut the presumption of good faith with his negligence allegations. The evidence showed that the son told the counselor that his father watched him shower and touched his genitals and buttocks while assisting him with his showers. Thomas v. Rosenberger, 2015 WY 7, 341 P.3d 390, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 2015).

Counselor was entitled to immunity under this section for her participation in the child abuse investigation because the father presented the court with no genuine issue of material fact that the counselor acted in bad faith as he admitted he had no factual basis for his contention that she made the digital penetration allegations to any law enforcement agents and he did not provide the records or testimony of the investigations. Thomas v. Rosenberger, 2015 WY 7, 341 P.3d 390, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 2015).

Privilege removed from all evidence regarding child. —

District court did not err by allowing a mother's mental health providers to testify to privileged communications because the mother was not entitled to reinstate the privilege for information that was previously disclosed pursuant to an “express waiver” of the privilege; even without the express waivers, the evidence was admissible at trial because there was reasonable cause to believe or suspect that the child was being subjected to conditions or circumstances that would result in neglect. Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

Applied in

In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982).

Quoted in

Large v. State, 2008 WY 22, 177 P.3d 807, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Feb. 28, 2008).

Stated in

Alicea v. State, 13 P.3d 693, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 223 (Wyo. 2000); RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 16, 2014).

Cited in

Leonard v. Converse County Sch. Dist. No. 2, 788 P.2d 1119, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1990); Elmore v. Van Horn, 844 P.2d 1078, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 202 (Wyo. 1992).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Evidence — Child Abuse and the Medical Diagnosis or Treatment Exception to the Hearsay Rule. Goldade v. State, 674 P.2d 721, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1983),” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 735 (1985).

For comment, “Fetal Equality?: The Equality State's Response to the Challenge of Protecting Unborn Children,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 193 (1997).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Civil liability of physician for failure to diagnose or report battered child syndrome, 97 ALR3d 338.

§ 14-3-206. Child abuse or neglect; written report; statewide reporting center; documentation and examination; costs and admissibility thereof.

  1. Reports of child abuse or neglect or of suspected child abuse or neglect made to the local child protective agency or local law enforcement agency shall be:
    1. Conveyed immediately by the agency receiving the report to the appropriate local child protective agency or local law enforcement agency and, if the person responsible for the welfare of a child is a member of the armed forces or if the child is enrolled in the defense enrollment eligibility reporting system of the United States department of defense, to the state judge advocate for the Wyoming military department. The agencies shall continue cooperating and coordinating with each other during the assessment or investigation; and
    2. Followed by a written report by the receiving agency confirming or not confirming the facts reported. The report shall provide to law enforcement, the local child protective agency and the state judge advocate for the Wyoming military department when appropriate, the following, to the extent available:
      1. The name, age and address of the child;
      2. The name and address of any person responsible for the child’s care;
      3. The nature and extent of the child’s condition;
      4. The basis of the reporter’s knowledge;
      5. The names and conditions of any other children relevant to the report;
      6. Any evidence of previous injuries to the child;
      7. Photographs, videos and x-rays with the identification of the person who created the evidence and the date the evidence was created; and
      8. Any other relevant information.
  2. The state agency may establish and maintain a statewide reporting center to receive reports of child abuse or neglect on a twenty-four (24) hour, seven (7) day week, toll free telephone number. Upon establishment of the service, all reports of child abuse or neglect may be made to the center which shall transfer the reports to the appropriate local child protective agency.
  3. Any person investigating, examining or treating suspected child abuse or neglect may document evidence of child abuse or neglect to the extent allowed by law by having photographs taken or causing x-rays to be made of the areas of trauma visible on a child who is the subject of the report or who is subject to a report. The reasonable cost of the photographs or x-rays shall be reimbursed by the appropriate local child protective agency. All photographs, x-rays or copies thereof shall be sent to the local child protective agency, admissible as evidence in any civil proceeding relating to child abuse or neglect, and shall state:
    1. The name of the subject;
    2. The name, address and telephone number of the person taking the photographs or x-rays; and
    3. The date and place they were taken.
  4. Any physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner examining a child and finding reasonable cause to believe the child is a victim of child abuse or neglect and having reasonable cause to believe that other children residing in the same home may also be a victim of child abuse or neglect shall report to law enforcement the results of the examination and facts supporting reasonable cause with respect to the other child or children. Law enforcement may then bring any other child residing in the same home to a physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner for examination. The examination shall take place within twenty-four (24) hours. Any physician, physician’s assistant, nurse practitioner or law enforcement officer denied access to a child for the purposes of examination under this subsection may seek an appropriate court order by ex parte proceedings or other appropriate proceedings to provide for the examination. After receiving the timely results of the examination, the examining physician, physician’s assistant, nurse practitioner or law enforcement officer shall consider whether temporary protective custody is necessary under W.S. 14-3-405 .

History. Laws 1971, ch. 181, § 3; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.9; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-117; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, § 2; 2013, ch. 142, § 1; 2017, ch. 3, § 1; 2019, ch. 77, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote (a), adding paragraph designations, inserting the provisions in (a)(i), and in (a)(ii) deleting the provision that a report may be dispensed with for good cause shown, and specifying the requirements of the report; and in (c), substituted “document evidence of child abuse or neglect to the extent allowed by law” for “document child abuse or neglect.”

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added “assessment or” in (a)(1).

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (a)(i), added “and, if the person responsible for the welfare of a child is a member of the armed forces or if the child is enrolled in the defense enrollment eligibility reporting system of the United States department of defense, to the state judge advocate for the Wyoming military department” in the first sentence; and in (a)(ii), substituted “the local child protective agency and the state judge advocate for the Wyoming military department when appropriate” for “or the local child protective agency.”

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, added (d).

Applied in

Goldade v. State, 674 P.2d 721, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1983).

§ 14-3-207. Abuse or neglect as suspected cause of death; coroner's investigation.

Any person who knows or has reasonable cause to suspect that a child has died as a result of child abuse or neglect shall report to the appropriate coroner. The coroner shall investigate the report and submit his findings in writing to the law enforcement agency, the appropriate district attorney and the local child protective agency.

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.9:1; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-118; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch 22, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to coroners' inquests generally, see § 7-4-201 et seq.

§ 14-3-208. Temporary protective custody; order; time limitation; remedial health care.

  1. When a child is taken into temporary protective custody pursuant to W.S. 14-3-405(a) and (b), the person taking custody shall immediately notify the local department of family services office and place or transfer temporary protective custody to the local department of family services office as soon as practicable. The local department of family services office shall:
    1. Accept physical custody of the child;
    2. Make reasonable efforts to inform the parent, noncustodial parent or other person responsible for the child’s welfare that the child has been taken into temporary protective custody, unless otherwise ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction;
    3. Arrange for care and supervision of the child in the most appropriate and least restrictive setting necessary to meet the child’s needs, including foster homes or other child care facilities certified by the department or approved by the court. When it is in the best interest of the child, the department shall place the child with the child’s noncustodial birth parent or with the child’s extended family, including adult siblings, grandparents, great-grandparents, aunts or uncles. Prior to approving placement with the child’s noncustodial birth parent or extended family, the department shall determine whether anyone living in the home has been convicted of a crime involving serious harm to children or has a substantiated case listed on the central registry established pursuant to W.S. 14-3-213 . The department may leave the child in the care of a physician or hospital when necessary to ensure the child receives proper care. A neglected child shall not be placed in a jail or detention facility other than for a delinquent act;
    4. Initiate an investigation of the allegations; and
    5. Assess the child’s mental and physical needs, provide for the child’s ordinary and emergency medical care and seek emergency court authorization for any extraordinary medical care that is needed prior to the shelter care hearing.
  2. The law enforcement or medical provider shall promptly notify the court and the district attorney of any child taken into temporary protective custody and placed in its care pursuant to W.S. 14-3-405 without a court order.
  3. Temporary protective custody shall not exceed forty-eight (48) hours, excluding weekends and legal holidays.
  4. When the court orders the child into the legal custody of the department pursuant to W.S. 14-3-409(d) or 14-3-429 , the department shall:
    1. Accept legal custody of the child;
    2. Continue or arrange for, care, transportation and supervision of the child as provided in paragraph (a)(iii) of this section;
    3. Assess the child’s mental and physical health needs and provide for the child’s ordinary and emergency medical care;
    4. Arrange for the provision of the education of the child, including participation in individualized education or developmental services;
    5. Participate in multidisciplinary team meetings to develop treatment recommendations for the child;
    6. Perform any other duties ordered by the court relating to the care or custody of the child.

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.9:2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-119; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 2004, ch. 42, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, § 2.

The 2004 amendment, in (b), substituted “district or circuit court judge or district court commissioner” for “district court judge, district court commissioner or justice of the peace.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote the section in conformance with § 14-3-201 as amended by Laws 2005, ch. 236.

Kinship placement. —

District court erred in permanently placing a mother's children with their foster parents for adoption, rather than with their aunt and uncle. Compelling preference as to what was best for the children was placement with nuclear or extended family members. LW v. State (In the Interest of JW), 2010 WY 28, 226 P.3d 873, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 2010).

Applied in

Goldade v. State, 674 P.2d 721, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1983).

Stated in

Michael v. Hertzler, 900 P.2d 1144, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 136 (Wyo. 1995).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity and application of statute allowing endangered child to be temporarily removed from parental custody, 38 ALR4th 756.

Power of court or other public agency to order medical treatment over parental religious objections for child whose life is not immediately endangered, 21 ALR5th 248.

§ 14-3-209. Immunity from liability.

Any person, official, institution or agency participating in good faith in any act required or permitted by W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 is immune from any civil or criminal liability that might otherwise result by reason of the action. For the purpose of any civil or criminal proceeding, the good faith of any person, official or institution participating in any act permitted or required by W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 shall be presumed.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 181, § 5; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.11; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-120; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

Immunity for negligent reporters. —

This section provides immunity for all reporters of child abuse not acting in bad faith. Where there is no evidence of deliberately false accusations but only negligence, good faith will still remain presumed. Elmore v. Van Horn, 844 P.2d 1078, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 202 (Wyo. 1992), reh'g denied, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. Feb. 4, 1993).

Counselor was immune from civil or criminal liability for reporting the father's alleged abuse of his son under this section, and therefore her motion for summary judgment was properly granted, because she acted upon a reasonable suspicion and the father failed to rebut the presumption of good faith with his negligence allegations. The evidence showed that the son told the counselor that his father watched him shower and touched his genitals and buttocks while assisting him with his showers. Thomas v. Rosenberger, 2015 WY 7, 341 P.3d 390, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 2015).

Counselor was entitled to immunity under this section for her participation in the child abuse investigation because the father presented the court with no genuine issue of material fact that the counselor acted in bad faith as he admitted he had no factual basis for his contention that she made the digital penetration allegations to any law enforcement agents and he did not provide the records or testimony of the investigations. Thomas v. Rosenberger, 2015 WY 7, 341 P.3d 390, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 2015).

Immunity provided from liability resulting from reporting. —

This section does not limit immunity suits based only on reporting. Rather, it provides immunity from any civil or criminal liability that might otherwise result because of reporting. Immunity includes participation in legal proceedings, as well as the underlying determination of the abuse which then led to the reporting. May v. Southeast Wyo. Mental Health Ctr., 866 P.2d 732, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 1993).

Cited in

Hall v. State, 851 P.2d 1262, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 1993).

§ 14-3-210. Admissibility of evidence constituting privileged communications.

  1. Evidence regarding a child in any judicial proceeding resulting from a report made pursuant to W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 shall not be excluded on the ground it constitutes a privileged communication:
    1. Between husband and wife;
    2. Claimed under any provision of law other than W.S. 1-12-101(a)(i) and (ii); or
    3. Claimed pursuant to W.S. 1-12-116 .

History. Laws 1971, ch. 181, § 6; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.12; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-121; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1985, ch. 127, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Physician-patient and psychologist-client privileges limited by this article. —

The privileges created between physician-patient and psychologist-client by §§ 1-12-101 and 33-27-103 (now 33-27-123 ) are limited by the subsequent enactment of this article, which sets forth a procedure for ascertaining and correcting child abuse and neglect. In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

There is no indication that the legislature intended to repeal Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-210 when it enacted Wyo. Stat Ann. § 33-38-113 , and the two statutes are complementary; section 33-38-113 (a)(i) provides an exception to the privilege where abuse or harmful neglect of children, the elderly or disabled or incompetent individuals is known or reasonably suspected, and this exception is entirely consistent with § 14-3-210 .Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

Privilege removed from all evidence regarding child. —

The language of this section is definite in removing the named privilege from all evidence “regarding a child”; such language does not restrict application to communications between the child patient or child client and the physician or psychologist, but includes communications between the mother and the physician and psychologist. In re Parental Rights of PP, 648 P.2d 512, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 355 (Wyo. 1982), overruled, Clark v. Alexander, 953 P.2d 145, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1998).

District court did not err by allowing a mother's mental health providers to testify to privileged communications because the mother was not entitled to reinstate the privilege for information that was previously disclosed pursuant to an “express waiver” of the privilege; even without the express waivers, the evidence was admissible at trial because there was reasonable cause to believe or suspect that the child was being subjected to conditions or circumstances that would result in neglect. Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

Because a mother's physical and mental state was at the heart of the claim that she neglected her child, information the mother disclosed to her counselors was clearly “evidence regarding a child.” Cave v. State (In re GAC), 2017 WY 65, 396 P.3d 411, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2017).

Stated in

Seyle v. State, 584 P.2d 1081, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 237 (Wyo. 1978).

Law reviews. —

For discussion of husband-wife testimonial privilege and the Federal Rules of Evidence, see XII Land & Water L. Rev. 601 (1977).

For case note, “Evidence — Recognition of a Federal Psychotherapist-Patient Privilege. Jaffee v. Redmond, 518 U.S. 1, 116 S. Ct. 1923, 135 L. Ed. 2d 337, 1996 U.S. LEXIS 3879 (1996),” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 873 (1997).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Presence of child at communication between husband and wife as destroying confidentiality of otherwise privileged communication between them, 39 ALR4th 480.

Validity, construction and application of statute limiting physician-patient privilege in judicial proceedings relating to child abuse or neglect, 44 ALR4th 649.

§ 14-3-211. Appointment of counsel for child and other parties.

  1. The court shall appoint counsel to represent any child in a court proceeding in which the child is alleged to be abused or neglected. Any attorney representing a child under this section shall also serve as the child’s guardian ad litem unless a guardian ad litem has been appointed by the court. The attorney or guardian ad litem shall be charged with representation of the child’s best interest.
  2. The court may appoint counsel for any party when necessary in the interest of justice.

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.12:1; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-122; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to appointment of guardians ad litem, see Rule 17(c), W.R.C.P.

Court must appoint attorney for child before adjudicating termination issues. —

It is improper for the district court to adjudicate the substantive issues of termination of parental rights without appointing an attorney to protect the welfare of the child. In re Child X, 617 P.2d 1078, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 308 (Wyo. 1980).

Attorney may be appointed as guardian ad litem. —

The trial court did not err in appointing an attorney for one or more of the children to act as guardian ad litem for the children; the person appointed to represent the children was specifically referred to as a guardian ad litem, and his participation in the trial was within the boundaries set forth in case law.DH v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re "H" Children), 2003 WY 155, 79 P.3d 997, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 2003), reh'g denied, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. Jan. 13, 2004).

Proceedings fatally defective where no guardian appointed in parental-rights termination litigation. —

Where no guardian ad litem for the children was appointed to represent the minors' best interest in parental-rights termination litigation, expressly contrary to subsection (a), the proceedings are fatally defective and the case will be remanded to the district court, where a guardian ad litem must be appointed and a new trial conducted. Curutchet v. Bordarrampe, 726 P.2d 500, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 621 (Wyo. 1986).

No reversal despite unjustified ex parte conference. —

An ex parte conference between the trial judge and the guardian ad litem appointed to represent the minor child of the parties could not be ethically justified, but did not require the reversal of an adjudication of child custody in a divorce action where no prejudicial error was manifested. Moore v. Moore, 809 P.2d 261, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 70 (Wyo. 1991).

Stated in

Nation v. Nation, 715 P.2d 198, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 504 (Wyo. 1986).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Attorney for Child Versus Guardian Ad Litem: Wyoming Creates a Hybrid, but is it a Formula for Malpractice?,” see XXXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 381 (1999).

§ 14-3-212. Child protection teams; creation; composition; duties; records confidential.

  1. The state agency and the local child protective agency shall encourage and assist in the creation of child protection teams within the communities in the state. The purposes of the child protection teams shall be to identify or develop community resources to serve abused and neglected children within the community, to advocate for improved services or procedures for such children and to provide information and assistance to the state agency, local child protection agency and multidisciplinary teams, if a multidisciplinary team has been appointed. The department may promulgate reasonable rules and regulations in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act to define the roles and procedures of child protection teams.
  2. The local child protection team shall be composed of:
    1. A member of the district attorney’s office;
    2. A designated representative from the school district or districts within the area served by the team;
    3. A representative from the local field office of the department of family services;
    4. A representative from the county government;
    5. A representative from each city and town in the county;
    6. Representatives from other relevant professions; and
    7. Temporary members selected for the needs of a particular case as determined by the team.
  3. The local child protection team may:
    1. Assist and coordinate with the state agency, the local child protective agency and all available agencies and organizations dealing with children;
    2. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 4.
    3. Coordinate the provision of appropriate services for abused and neglected children and their families;
    4. Identify or develop community resources to serve abused and neglected children and advocate for improved services and procedures for such children;
    5. Identify training needs, sponsor training and raise community awareness of child protection issues; and
    6. Assist and make recommendations of appropriate services in individual cases brought to it by the state agency or the local child protection agency.
  4. The local child protection team shall not act as a multidisciplinary team, but members of the child protection team may serve on a multidisciplinary team if appointed pursuant to W.S. 14-3-427 .
  5. All records and proceedings of the child protection teams are subject to W.S. 14-3-214 .

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.12:2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-123; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 1; 1985, ch. 130, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, §§ 2, 4.
