The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a), deleted “multi-disciplinary” before “child protection teams,” and added last two sentences; inserted present (b)(iii) through (b)(v), redesignating former (b)(iii) and (b)(iv) as (b)(vi) and (b)(vii); repealed former (c)(ii), pertaining to diagnosis and prognosis, rewrote (c)(iii), which read: “Provide an adequate treatment plan for the abused and neglected child and his family,” added (c)(iv) through (c)(vi); and added (d), redesignating former (d) as (e).

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

§ 14-3-213. Central registry of child protection cases; establishment; operation; amendment, expungement or removal of records; classification and expungement of reports; statement of person accused.

  1. The state agency shall establish and maintain a record of all child protection reports and a central registry of “under investigation” or “substantiated” child protection reports in accordance with W.S. 42-2-111 .
  2. Through the recording of reports, the state agency’s recordkeeping system shall be operated to enable the state agency to:
    1. Immediately identify and locate prior reports of cases of child abuse or neglect to assist in the diagnosis of suspicious circumstances and the assessment of the needs of the child and his family;
    2. Continuously monitor the current status of all pending child protection cases;
    3. Regularly evaluate the effectiveness of existing laws and programs through the development and analysis of statistical and other information; and
    4. Maintain a central registry of “under investigation” reports and “substantiated” reports of child abuse or neglect for provision of information to qualifying applicants pursuant to W.S. 14-3-214(f).
  3. Upon good cause shown and upon notice to the subject of an “under investigation” or “substantiated” report, the state agency may list, amend, expunge or remove any record from the central registry in accordance with rules and regulations adopted by the state agency.
  4. All reports of child abuse or neglect contained within the central registry shall be classified in one (1) of the following categories:
    1. “Under investigation”; or
    2. “Substantiated”.
    3. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 23, § 2.
  5. Within six (6) months all reports classified as “under investigation” shall be reclassified as “substantiated” or expunged from the central registry, unless the state agency is notified of an open criminal investigation or criminal prosecution. Unsubstantiated reports shall not be contained within the central registry.
  6. Any person named as a perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in any report maintained in the central registry which is classified as a substantiated report as defined in W.S. 14-3-202(a)(xi) shall have the right to have included in the report his statement concerning the incident giving rise to the report. Any person seeking to include a statement pursuant to this subsection shall provide the state agency with the statement. The state agency shall provide notice to any person identified as a perpetrator of his right to submit his statement in any report maintained in the central registry.
  7. Conviction of a person under W.S. 6-2-502(a)(v) when the victim is a minor shall be included as a substantiated report of child abuse in the central registry under this section.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 181, § 7; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.13; Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-124; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1994, ch. 39, § 1; 1995, ch. 136, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 86, § 2; 2005, ch. 23, §§ 1, 2; 2020, ch. 105, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote the section, to require the state agency to maintain a central registry of “under investigation” and “substantiated” reports of child abuse and neglect, to remove provisions for a “closed” category of reports, to require that within six months all reports classified as “under investigation” be reclassified as “substantiated” or otherwise expunged except as specified, and to provide that unsubstantiated reports not be kept in the central registry, and to otherwise conform to Laws 2005, ch. 23.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, added (g).

Applicability. —

This section applies only to child protective proceedings where there has been an adjudication and finding of child abuse or neglect, not to convictions of sexual assault where no child protective proceedings have occurred. Johnson v. State, 922 P.2d 1384, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1996).

§ 14-3-214. Confidentiality of records; penalties; access to information; attendance of school officials at interviews; access to central registry records pertaining to child protection cases.

  1. All records concerning reports and investigations of child abuse or neglect are confidential except as provided by W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 . Any person who willfully violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned in the county jail not more than six (6) months, or both.
  2. Except as provided in subsection (h) of this section, applications for access to records concerning child abuse or neglect contained in the state agency or local child protective agency shall be made in the manner and form prescribed by the state agency. Upon appropriate application, the state agency shall give access to any of the following persons or agencies for purposes directly related with the administration of W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 :
    1. A local child protective agency;
    2. A law enforcement agency, guardian ad litem, child protection team or the attorney representing the subject of the report;
    3. A physician or surgeon who is treating an abused or neglected child, the child’s family or a child he reasonably suspects may have been abused or neglected;
    4. A person legally authorized to place a child in protective temporary custody when information in the report or record is required to determine whether to place the child in temporary protective custody;
    5. A person responsible for the welfare of the child;
    6. A court or grand jury upon a showing that access to the records is necessary for the determination of an issue, in which case access shall be limited to in camera inspection unless the court finds public disclosure is necessary;
    7. Court personnel who are investigating reported incidents of child abuse or neglect;
    8. An education or mental health professional serving the child, if the state agency determines the information is necessary to provide appropriate educational or therapeutic interventions.
  3. A physician or person in charge of an institution, school, facility or agency making the report shall receive, upon written application to the state agency, a summary of the records concerning the subject of the report.
  4. Any person, agency or institution given access to information concerning the subject of the report shall not divulge or make public any information except as required for court proceedings.
  5. Nothing in W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-215 prohibits the attendance of any one (1) of the following at an interview conducted on school property by law enforcement or child protective agency personnel of a child suspected to be abused or neglected provided the person is not a subject of the allegation:
    1. The principal of the child’s school or his designee; or
    2. A child’s teacher or, counselor, or specialist employed by the school or school district and assigned the duties of monitoring, reviewing or assisting in the child’s welfare in cases of suspected child abuse or neglect.
  6. Upon appropriate application, the state agency shall provide to any employer or entity whose employees or volunteers may have unsupervised access to children in the course of their employment or volunteer service, for employee or volunteer screening purposes, a summary of central registry records maintained under state agency rules since December 31, 1986, for purposes of screening employees or volunteers. The state agency shall provide the results of the records check to the applicant by certified mail if the records check confirms the existence of a report “under investigation” or a “substantiated” finding of abuse or neglect. Otherwise, the state agency shall provide the results of the records check to the applicant in accordance with agency rules and by United States mail. The written results shall confirm that there is a report “under investigation”, a “substantiated” finding of abuse or neglect on the central registry naming the individual or confirm that no record exists. When the individual is identified on the registry as a “substantiated” perpetrator of abuse or neglect, the report to the applicant shall contain information with respect to the date of the finding, specific type of abuse or neglect, a copy of the perpetrator’s voluntary statement and whether an appeal is pending. The applicant, or an agent on behalf of the applicant, shall submit a fee in an amount determined by rule of the state agency and proof satisfactory to the state agency that the prospective or current employee or volunteer whose records are being checked consents to the release of the information to the applicant. The applicant shall use the information received only for purposes of screening prospective or current employees and volunteers who may, through their employment or volunteer services, have unsupervised access to minors. Applicants, their employees or other agents shall not otherwise divulge or make public any information received under this section. The state agency shall notify any applicant receiving information under this subsection of any subsequent reclassification of the information pursuant to W.S. 14-3-213(e). The state agency shall screen all prospective agency employees in conformity with the procedure provided under this subsection.
  7. There is created a program administration account to be known as the “child and vulnerable adult abuse registry account”. All fees collected under subsection (f) of this section shall be credited to this account.
  8. No information, including recorded interviews of the child, shall be disclosed to any person in any civil proceeding not related to an abuse or neglect case brought under this article except upon order of the court which shall determine if good cause exists to disclose the information. Any protective order granting disclosure shall include appropriate protections against further dissemination in any form. The court may conduct an in camera review of a recorded interview prior to issuing a protective order and may impose such conditions as may be appropriate under the circumstances of the proceeding to prevent further dissemination of the recorded interview.
  9. Any person may request a central registry screen and summary report on themselves as provided by subsection (f) of this section upon payment of the fee required by subsection (f) of this section.

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.14; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-125; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1985, ch. 130, § 1; 1991, ch. 113, § 2; 1994, ch. 39, § 1; 1995, ch. 136, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 86, § 2; 2005, ch. 23, § 1; ch. 231, § 1; ch. 236, § 2; 2006, ch. 114, § 1; 2015, ch. 191, § 1; 2017, ch. 108, § 1; 2021, ch. 122, § 1.

The 2005 amendments. —

The first 2005 amendment, by ch. 23, § 1, effective July 1, 2005, added (b)(viii); and rewrote (f), modifying notification procedures for employees and volunteers under investigation, and otherwise conforming the provisions in accordance with Laws 2005, ch. 23.

The second 2005 amendment, by ch. 231, § 1, effective July 1, 2005, in (g), deleted “within the earmarked revenue fund” following “program administration account.”

The third 2005 amendment, by ch. 236, § 2, effective July 1, 2005, in (b), substituted “14-3-216” for “14-3-215.”

See the conflicting legislation note. This section is set out incorporating the amendments by all three 2005 acts.

The 2006 amendment, deleted “and” at the end of (b)(vi).

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in (b), inserted the introduction “Except as provided in subsection (h) of this section” and created a new subsection (h).

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (f), substituted “employer or entity whose employees or volunteers may have unsupervised access to children in the course of their employment or volunteer service” for “employer or entity whose employees or volunteers may have unsupervised access to children in the course of their employment or volunteer service” in the first sentence, added “in accordance with agency rules and” in the third sentence, “or an agent on behalf of the applicant” in the fifth sentence, and “or current” in the sixth sentence; and added (j).

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, substituted "in an amount determined by rule of the state agency" for "of ten dollars ($10.00) " in the sixth sentence of (f).

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2005, ch. 231, § 3, provides: “The provisions of this act shall supersede the provisions of any other bill enacted into law during the 2005 general session which amends or references accounts or funds to the extent any other enactment is inconsistent with the establishment of the funds and accounts created under this act. The state auditor shall account for any fund or account created in any other legislation enacted in the 2005 general session in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated by the governmental accounting standards board (GASB) and in accordance with this act.”

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3 provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Victim's records not released unless constitutionally material. —

Where a defendant was charged with taking indecent liberties with a minor, the nondisclosure to defense counsel of school records concerning the child did not deny the defendant his constitutional rights to a fair trial and to confront witnesses and to compulsory process, nor did the trial court err in conducting an in-camera review of the records and applying a standard of constitutional materiality in determining which records, if any, were to be released to defendant's counsel. Gale v. State, 792 P.2d 570, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 792 P.2d 570, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (Wyo. 1990).

Admission of juvenile court records in parental rights termination proceeding. —

Court did not err in allowing records in a juvenile court neglect proceeding to be used in a parental rights termination proceeding; use of such records is entirely proper and in accord with the Child Protection Services statutes' purpose of protecting the best interests of the child. SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs.(In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2005).

Applied in

LeBlanc v. State (In re ARLeB), 2017 WY 107, 401 P.3d 932, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 2017).

Cited in

Johnson v. State, 922 P.2d 1384, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1996).

§ 14-3-215. Interagency children's collaborative.

  1. There is created an interagency children’s collaborative. The collaborative shall be composed of:
    1. The director of the department of family services, or his designee;
    2. The director of the department of health, or his designee;
    3. The superintendent of public instruction, or his designee;
    4. The director of the department of workforce services, or his designee; and
    5. The governor’s appointee who shall represent families receiving services from the state agencies represented in paragraphs (i) through (iv) of this subsection.
  2. The department of family services shall adopt rules by July 1, 2005, to establish guidelines for review of case files of children in state custody as a result of any action commenced under this title. The rules shall be adopted by the department of family services with the advice of the departments of education, health and workforce services. In addition to providing for the review of cases and the progress made towards returning children in state custody to their homes, communities or other permanent placements, the guidelines shall provide specific processes for:
    1. Local multidisciplinary teams to voluntarily present case files to the collaborative for review;
    2. The review of cases in which more than one (1) state agency provides services to the child and his family; and
    3. The review of statewide availability and utilization of resources for children in state custody.

History. Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

A former § 14-3-215 was renumbered as § 14-3-216 by Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 3.

Effective dates. —

Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 5(a), makes § 14-3-215(a) effective July 1, 2005. Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 5(b), makes § 14-3-215(b) effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 11, 2005.

Cited in

RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 16, 2014).

§ 14-3-216. Other laws not superseded.

No laws of this state are superseded by the provisions of W.S. 14-3-201 through 14-3-216 .

History. Laws 1977, ch. 110, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 14-28.15; W.S. 1977, § 14-2-126; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; W.S. 1977, 14–3–215; Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 3.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, renumbered this section, which was formerly numbered as § 14-3-215 , and substituted “14-3-216” for “14-3-215.”

Article 3. Sale of Nicotine Products

  • § 14-3-301.  Definitions.
  • § 14-3-302.  Prohibited sales or delivery.
  • § 14-3-303.  Posted notice required; location of vending machines.
  • § 14-3-304.  Purchase by person under twenty-one years of age prohibited.
  • § 14-3-305.  Possession or use by person under twenty-one years of age prohibited.
  • § 14-3-306.  Teen court jurisdiction.
  • § 14-3-307.  Compliance inspections.
  • § 14-3-308.  Further regulation by local ordinance.
  • § 14-3-309.  Regulation of mail order and internet purchases and sales; proof of age; penalties.

§ 14-3-301. Definitions.

  1. As used in this article:
    1. “Tobacco products” means any substance containing tobacco leaf or any product made or derived from tobacco that contains nicotine including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping tobacco;
    2. “Vending machine” means any mechanical, electric or electronic self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens, or any other form of payment, dispenses nicotine products;
    3. “Retailer” means a business of any kind at a specific location that sells nicotine products to a user or consumer;
    4. “Self service display” means any display of nicotine products that is located in an area where customers are permitted and where the nicotine products are readily accessible to a customer without the assistance of a salesperson;
    5. “Electronic cigarette” means any device that can be used to deliver aerosolized or vaporized nicotine or synthetic nicotine material to the person using the device and includes any component, part and accessory of the device and any vapor material intended to be aerosolized or vaporized during the use of the device. “Electronic cigarette” includes, without limitation, any electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, electronic hooka, vapor pen and any similar product or device. “Electronic cigarette” does not include a battery or battery charger if sold separately from the electronic cigarette and does not include any product regulated as a drug or device by the United States food and drug administration under subchapter V of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act;
    6. “Nicotine products” means tobacco products and electronic cigarettes;
    7. “Vapor material” means any liquid solution or other material containing nicotine or synthetic nicotine that is depleted as an electronic cigarette is used. “Vapor material” includes liquid solution or other material containing nicotine or synthetic nicotine that is sold with or inside an electronic cigarette.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 76, § 1; 2000, ch. 93, § 2; 2007, ch. 93, § 1; 2013, ch. 144, § 1; 2020, ch. 53, § 1; ch. 83, § 1; ch. 86, § 2.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, added (a)(iv).

The 2013 amendment, in (a), added “or any product made or derived from tobacco that contains nicotine” and “electronic cigarettes,” in (a)(i) and added (a)(v).

Laws 2013, ch. 144, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 13, 2013.

The 2020 amendments. — The first 2020 amendment, by ch. 53, § 1, effective July 1, 2020, rewrote (a)(v), which read “‘Electronic cigarette’ means a product that employs any mechanical heating element, battery or electronic circuit, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to deliver doses of nicotine vapor by means of heating a liquid nicotine solution contained in a cartridge or other delivery system.”

The second 2020 amendment, by ch. 83, § 1, effective July 1, 2020, in (a)(i) deleted “electronic cigarettes” and made stylistic changes; in (a)(ii) through (a)(iv) substituted “nicotine products” for “tobacco products”; rewrote (a)(v), which read “‘Electronic cigarette’ means a product that employs any mechanical heating element, battery or electronic circuit, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to deliver doses of nicotine vapor by means of heating a liquid nicotine solution contained in a cartridge or other delivery system”; and added (a)(vi) and (a)(vii).

The third 2020 amendment, by ch. 86, § 2, effective July 1, 2020, in (a)(i) deleted “electronic cigarettes” and made stylistic changes; rewrote (a)(v), which read “‘Electronic cigarette’ means a product that employs any mechanical heating element, battery or electronic circuit, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to deliver doses of nicotine vapor by means of heating a liquid nicotine solution contained in a cartridge or other delivery system”; and added (a)(vi) and (a)(vii).

This section is set out as reconciled by the Wyoming legislative service office.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 14-3-302. Prohibited sales or delivery.

  1. No individual shall sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver nicotine products to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years.
  2. Any individual violating W.S. 14-3-309 or subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than:
    1. Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a first violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period. The court may allow the defendant to perform community service or attend a tobacco or nicotine cessation program and be granted credit against his fine and court costs at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each hour of work performed or each hour of tobacco or nicotine cessation program attended;
    2. Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period, regardless of the locations where the violations occurred. The court may allow the defendant to perform community service or attend a tobacco or nicotine cessation program and be granted credit against his fine and court costs at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each hour of work performed or each hour of tobacco or nicotine cessation program attended;
    3. Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or subsequent violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period, regardless of the locations where the violations occurred. The court may allow the defendant to perform community service and be granted credit against his fine and court costs at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) for each hour of work performed.
  3. No retailer shall sell, permit the sale, offer for sale, give away or deliver nicotine products to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years.
  4. Any person violating subsection (c) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than:
    1. Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a first violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period;
    2. Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period;
    3. Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or subsequent violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period.
  5. In addition to the penalties under paragraph (d)(iii) of this section, any person violating subsection (c) of this section for a third or subsequent time within a two (2) year period may be subject to an injunction. The department of revenue or the district attorney of the county in which the offense occurred, may petition the district court for an injunction to prohibit the sale of nicotine products in the establishment where the violation occurred. If the court finds that the respondent in the action has violated the provisions of subsection (c) of this section for a third or subsequent time within a two (2) year period and may continue to violate such provisions, it may grant an injunction prohibiting the respondent from selling nicotine products in the establishment where the violation occurred for a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days. For the purposes of this subsection, multiple violations occurring before the petition for the injunction is filed shall be deemed part of the violation for which the injunction is sought. If the person against whom the injunction is sought operates multiple, geographically separate establishments, the injunction shall apply only to the establishment where the violation occurred. The injunction shall prohibit all sales of nicotine products in the establishment where the violation occurred, regardless of any change in ownership or management of the establishment that is not a bona fide, arms length transaction while the injunction is in effect.
  6. It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution under subsections (a) and (c) of this section that, in the case of a sale, the person who sold the nicotine product was presented with, and reasonably relied upon, an identification card which identified the person buying or receiving the nicotine product as being over twenty-one (21) years of age.
  7. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, no fine for a violation of subsection (c) of this section shall be imposed for a first offense in a twenty-four (24) month period if the retailer can show it had:
    1. Adopted and enforced a written policy against selling nicotine products to persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years;
    2. Informed its employees of the applicable laws regarding the sale of nicotine products to persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years;
    3. Required employees to verify the age of nicotine product customers by way of photographic identification or by means of electronic transaction scan device; and
    4. Established and imposed disciplinary sanctions for noncompliance.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 76, § 1; 2000, ch. 93, § 2; 2020, ch. 83, § 1; ch. 86, § 2.

The 2020 amendments. —

The first 2020 amendment, by ch. 83, § 1, effective July 1, 2020, substituted “nicotine products” for “tobacco products” with variation throughout; in (a), (c), (f), (g)(i), and (g)(ii) substituted “twenty-one (21) years” for “eighteen (18) years”; in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) substituted “community service or attend a tobacco or nicotine cessation program” for “community service,” “ten dollars ($10.00)” for “five dollars ($5.00),” and “work performed or each hour of tobacco or nicotine cessation program attended” for “work performed”; in (b)(i) and (d)(i) substituted “Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)” for “Fifty dollars ($50.00)”; in (b)(ii) and (d)(ii) substituted “Five hundred dollars ($500.00)” for “Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).”

The second 2020 amendment, by ch. 86, § 2, effective July 1, 2020, in the introductory language of (b) substituted “violating W.S. 14-3-309 or subsection (a)” for “violating subsection (a).”

While neither amendment gave effect to the others, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

§ 14-3-303. Posted notice required; location of vending machines.

  1. Any person who sells nicotine products shall post signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided by this article at or near every display of nicotine products and on or upon every vending machine which offers nicotine products for sale. Each sign shall be plainly visible and shall contain a statement communicating that the sale of nicotine products to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age is prohibited by law. Any person who owns, operates or manages a business where nicotine products are offered for sale at retail and at which persons under the age of twenty-one (21) are allowed admission with or without an adult, shall maintain all nicotine products within the line of sight of a cashier or other employee or under the control of the cashier or other employee. For purposes of this subsection:
    1. “Within the line of sight” means visible to a cashier or other employee while at the sales counter; and
    2. “Under control” means protected by security, surveillance or detection methods.
  2. No person shall sell or offer nicotine products:
    1. Through a vending machine unless the vending machine is located in:
      1. Businesses, factories, offices or other places not open to the general public;
      2. Places to which persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age are not permitted access; or
      3. Business premises where alcoholic or malt beverages are sold or dispensed and where entry by persons under twenty-one (21) years of age is prohibited.
    2. Through a self service display except in:
      1. A vending machine as permitted in paragraph (i) of this subsection; or
      2. A business where entry by persons under twenty-one (21) years of age is prohibited.
  3. Any person violating subsection (a) or (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than:
    1. Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a first violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period;
    2. Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period;
    3. Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or subsequent violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period.
  4. For purposes of subsection (c) of this section, each day of continued violation under subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be deemed a separate offense.
  5. In addition to the penalties under paragraph (c)(iii) of this section, any person violating subsection (a) or (b) of this section for a third or subsequent time within a two (2) year period may be subject to an injunction. The department or the district attorney of the county in which the offense occurred, may petition the district court for an injunction to prohibit the sale of nicotine products from the vending machines or the establishment where the violation occurred. If the court finds that the respondent in the action has violated the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section for a third or subsequent time within a two (2) year period and may continue to violate such provisions, it may grant an injunction prohibiting the respondent from selling nicotine products from vending machines or from the establishment where the violation occurred for a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days. For the purposes of this subsection, multiple violations occurring before the petition for the injunction is filed shall be deemed part of the violation for which the injunction is sought. If the person against whom the injunction is sought operates multiple, geographically separate establishments or vending machines, the injunction shall apply only to the establishment where the violation occurred and to the vending machines resulting in the violation. The injunction shall prohibit all sales of nicotine products from the vending machines or the establishment involved in the violation, regardless of any change in ownership or management of the vending machines or the establishment that is not a bona fide, arms length transaction while the injunction is in effect.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 76, § 1; 2000, ch. 93, § 2; 2007, ch. 93, § 1; 2020, ch. 83, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, added (b)(i) and redesignated the remaining paragraphs accordingly; and added present (b)(ii).

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, substituted “nicotine products” for “tobacco products” and “twenty-one (21) years of age” for “eighteen (18) years of age” throughout; in the introductory language of (a) deleted “Effective January 1, 2001” at the beginning of the third sentence; in (c)(i) substituted “Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)” for “Fifty dollars ($50.00)”; and in (c)(ii) substituted “Five hundred dollars ($500.00)” for “Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).”

§ 14-3-304. Purchase by person under twenty-one years of age prohibited.

  1. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall purchase or attempt to purchase nicotine products, or misrepresent his identity or age, or use any false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing or attempting to purchase nicotine products. A person shall not be arrested for an alleged violation of this subsection but shall be issued a citation as a charging document by a peace officer having probable cause to believe the person violated this subsection. An officer issuing a citation shall deposit one (1) copy of the citation with the court having jurisdiction over the alleged offense. Bond may be posted and forfeited for an offense charged under this section in an amount equal to the fine imposed by subsection (b) of this section.
  2. Any person violating subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 2020, ch. 83, § 2.
  3. In lieu of the fine under subsection (b) of this section, the court may allow the defendant to perform community service or attend a tobacco or nicotine cessation program and be granted credit against his fine and court costs at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each hour of work performed or each hour of tobacco or nicotine cessation program attended.
  4. No conviction under this section, whether by guilty plea, adjudication of guilt or forfeiture of bond shall be reported by the court to any law enforcement agency. Upon payment of the fine imposed by subsection (b) of this section, a criminal conviction under this section shall be expunged by operation of law from all records of the court six (6) months after the entry of conviction. For any person whose record of conviction was expunged under this subsection, the conviction is deemed not to have occurred and the individual may reply accordingly upon any inquiry in the matter. No expungement under this subsection shall be considered for purposes of any other law providing for expungement.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 76, § 1; 2000, ch. 93, § 2; 2020, ch. 83, §§ 1, 2.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) substituted “twenty-one (21) years” for “eighteen (18) years” and “nicotine products” for “tobacco products” twice and added the last two sentences; redesignated the introductory language of (b) as (b) and substituted “twenty-five dollars ($25.00)” for “not more than”; repealed (b)(i) through (b)(iii), which read “(i) Fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period; (ii) Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a second violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period; (iii) Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or subsequent violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period”; in (c) substituted “tobacco or nicotine cessation program” for “tobacco cessation program” twice and “ten dollars ($10.00)” for “five dollars ($5.00)”; and rewrote (d), which read “After twenty-four (24) months or upon reaching the age of majority, whichever occurs later, a criminal conviction under this section may be expunged in accordance with W.S. 14-6-241 .”

§ 14-3-305. Possession or use by person under twenty-one years of age prohibited.

  1. It is unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to possess or use any nicotine products. A person shall not be arrested for an alleged violation of this subsection but shall be issued a citation as a charging document by a peace officer having probable cause to believe the person violated this subsection. An officer issuing a citation shall deposit one (1) copy of the citation with the court having jurisdiction over the alleged offense. Bond may be posted and forfeited for an offense charged under this section in an amount equal to the fine imposed by subsection (b) of this section.
  2. Any person violating subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 2020, ch. 83, § 2.
  3. Repealed by Laws 2000, ch. 93, § 4.
  4. In lieu of the fine under subsection (b) of this section, the court may allow the defendant to perform community service or attend a tobacco or nicotine cessation program and be granted credit against his fine and court costs at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each hour of work performed or each hour of tobacco or nicotine cessation program attended.
  5. No conviction under this section, whether by guilty plea, adjudication of guilt or forfeiture of bond shall be reported by the court to any law enforcement agency. Upon payment of the fine imposed by subsection (b) of this section, a criminal conviction under this section shall be expunged by operation of law from all records of the court six (6) months after the entry of conviction. For any person whose record of conviction was expunged under this subsection, the conviction is deemed not to have occurred and the individual may reply accordingly upon any inquiry in the matter. No expungement under this subsection shall be considered for purposes of any other law providing for expungement.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 76, § 1; 2000, ch. 93, §§ 2, 4; 2020, ch. 83, §§ 1, 2.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) substituted “twenty-one (21) years” for “eighteen (18) years” and “nicotine products” for “tobacco products” and added the last two sentences; redesignated the introductory language of (b) as (b) and substituted “twenty-five dollars ($25.00)” for “not more than”; repealed (b)(i) through (b)(iii), which read “(i) Fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period; (ii) Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a second violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period; (iii) Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a third or subsequent violation committed within a twenty-four (24) month period”; in (d) substituted “tobacco or nicotine cessation program” for “tobacco cessation program” twice and “ten dollars ($10.00)” for “five dollars ($5.00)”; and rewrote (e), which read “After twenty-four (24) months or upon reaching the age of majority, whichever occurs later, a criminal conviction under this section may be expunged in accordance with W.S. 14-6-241 .”

Cited in

Cloud v. State, 2014 WY 113, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Sept. 10, 2014).

§ 14-3-306. Teen court jurisdiction.

The teen court program authorized under W.S. 7-13-1203 may have jurisdiction over any offense committed by a minor under this article.

History. Laws 2000, ch. 93, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

Former § 14-3-306 was renumbered as § 14-3-308 by Laws 2000, ch. 93, § 3.

§ 14-3-307. Compliance inspections.

  1. The department of health, working with local law enforcement agencies and other local individuals and organizations at the discretion of the department, shall be the lead agency to ensure compliance with this article.
  2. The department of health shall develop strategies to coordinate and support local law enforcement efforts to enforce all state statutes relating to the prohibition of the sale of nicotine products to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age.
  3. The department shall have discretion to:
    1. Work with each local law enforcement agency; and
    2. Coordinate local enforcement efforts that appropriately reflect the needs of the community.
  4. To coordinate the enforcement of state statutes relating to the prohibition of the sale of nicotine products to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age and to comply with applicable federal law, the department of health shall have authority to contract with or provide grants to local law enforcement agencies or other local individuals or entities having the appropriate level of enforcement authority on the local level to conduct random, unannounced inspections at retail locations where nicotine products are sold. The local law enforcement agencies or other local individuals or entities authorized to conduct inspections shall be permitted to use minors and persons under twenty-one (21) years of age subject to the following:
    1. Prior to the inspection, the local law enforcement agency or other authorized individual or entity shall obtain the written consent of the person being used in the inspection or if using a minor, the written consent of the minor’s parents or guardian shall be obtained prior to the minor participating in an inspection. The written consent required under this paragraph shall include a notification that testimony in a subsequent court proceeding may be required;
    2. Any person under twenty-one (21) years of age participating in an inspection shall, if questioned, state his true age and that he is less than twenty-one (21) years of age;
    3. The appearance of a person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall not be altered to make him appear to be twenty-one (21) years of age or older;
    4. Neither a minor nor his parents or guardians shall be coerced into participating in such inspections;
    5. The person conducting the inspection shall photograph the participant immediately before the inspection and any photographs taken of the participant shall be retained by the person conducting the inspection;
    6. Any participant in an inspection under this section shall be granted immunity from prosecution under W.S. 14-3-304 or 14-3-305 .
  5. The person conducting an inspection under this section shall:
    1. Remain within sight or sound of the participant attempting to make the purchase;
    2. Immediately inform in writing a representative or agent of the business establishment that an inspection has been performed and the results of the inspection;
    3. Within two (2) days, prepare a report of the inspection containing:
      1. The name of the person who supervised the inspection;
      2. The age and date of birth of the participant who assisted in the inspection;
      3. The name and position of the person from whom the participant attempted to purchase nicotine products;
      4. The name and address of the establishment inspected;
      5. The date and time of the inspection; and
      6. The results of the inspection, including whether the inspection resulted in the sale or distribution of, or offering for sale, nicotine products to a person under twenty-one (21) years of age.
    4. Immediately upon completion of the report required under this subsection, provide a copy of the report to a representative or agent of the business establishment that was inspected;
    5. Request a law enforcement officer to issue a citation for any illegal acts relating to providing nicotine products to persons under twenty-one (21) years of age during the inspection.

History. Laws 2000, ch. 93, § 1; 2020, ch. 83, § 1.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, substituted “nicotine products” for “tobacco products,” “persons under twenty-one (21) years of age” for “minors” with variation, and “twenty-one (21) years of age” for “eighteen (18) years of age” throughout; in the introductory language of (d) substituted “The local law enforcement agencies or other local individuals or entities authorized to conduct inspections shall be permitted to use minors and persons under twenty-one (21) years of age subject to the following” for “The use of minors during inspections is authorized subject to the following”; in (d)(i) substituted “Prior to the inspection, the local law enforcement agency or other authorized individual or entity shall obtain the written consent of the person being used in the inspection or if using a minor, the written consent” for “The written consent shall include notification that testimony in a subsequent court proceeding may be required. The written consent” and added the last sentence; in (d)(ii) substituted “Any person under twenty-one (21) years of age participating” for “A minor participating”; and in (d)(iii) substituted “The appearance of a person under twenty-one (21) years of age” for “The minor's appearance.”

§ 14-3-308. Further regulation by local ordinance.

  1. Except as specified under subsection (b) of this section, this article shall not be construed to prohibit the imposition by local law or ordinance of further regulation or prohibition upon the sale, use and possession of nicotine products to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age, but the governmental entity shall not permit or authorize the sale, use or possession of nicotine products to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age in violation of this article.
  2. No governmental entity shall enact any law or ordinance which changes the standards provided by W.S. 14-3-302(a) and (c), 14-3-303(a), 14-3-304(a) and 14-3-305(a).
  3. The governmental entity may require that sellers of nicotine products obtain a license to sell nicotine products and may deny or revoke the license in the case of reported violations of W.S. 14-3-302 or similar local ordinance.

History. Laws 1991, ch. 76, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-306 ; Laws 2000, ch. 93, § 3; 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2020, ch. 83, § 1.

The 2004 amendment, in (b), deleted “and (c)” from the end; and made stylistic changes.

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (a) and (c) substituted “nicotine products” for “tobacco products”; in (a) substituted “twenty-one (21) years of age” for “eighteen (18) years of age” twice.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

§ 14-3-309. Regulation of mail order and internet purchases and sales; proof of age; penalties.

  1. No person shall sell at retail or wholesale any nicotine product through the internet or any other remote sales method to any person in this state, other than a vendor licensed under W.S. 39-15-106 , unless the seller performs an age verification on the purchaser through an independent third party age verification service. The age verification service utilized shall compare information available from public records to the personal information entered by the purchaser during the ordering process to establish that the purchaser is twenty-one (21) years of age or older.
  2. No person shall sell at retail or wholesale any nicotine product through the internet or any other remote sales method to any person in this state, other than a vendor licensed under W.S. 39-15-106 , unless the seller uses a method of mailing or shipping that, upon delivery, requires the signature of a person at least twenty-one (21) years of age before the nicotine product will be released for delivery.
  3. The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply if the seller employs one (1) of the following protections to ensure age verification:
    1. The purchaser is required to create an online profile or account with personal information verifying that the purchaser is at least twenty-one (21) years of age including, but not limited to, the purchaser’s name, address and a valid phone number, if that personal information is verified by the seller through publicly available records and delivery is made to the same name and address; or
    2. The purchaser is required to upload a copy of the purchaser’s government issued identification and a current photograph of the purchaser verifying that the purchaser is at least twenty-one (21) years of age and delivery is made to the same name on the identification provided.
  4. Any person violating subsection (a) or (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in W.S. 14-3-302(b).

History. Laws 2020, ch. 86, § 1.

Effective date. — Laws 2020, ch. 86, § 3, makes the act effective July 1, 2020.

Article 4. Child Protection Act

  • § 14-3-401.  Short title.
  • § 14-3-402.  Definitions.
  • § 14-3-403.  Juvenile court authority over certain issues.
  • § 14-3-404.  Venue; change of venue or judge.
  • § 14-3-405.  Taking of child into custody; when permitted.
  • § 14-3-406.  Child in custody; no shelter care placement without court order; exceptions; notice to parent or guardian; release.
  • § 14-3-407.  Shelter care; delivery of child pending hearing; placing children; notice if no court order.
  • § 14-3-408.  Notice of shelter care to be given district attorney; written statement required; duty of district attorney.
  • § 14-3-409.  Taking of child into custody; shelter care hearing where no court order; conditional release; evidence; rehearing.
  • § 14-3-410.  Shelter care hearing conducted by commissioner; authority and duty; review by court.
  • § 14-3-411.  Complaints alleging neglect; investigation and determination by district attorney.
  • § 14-3-412.  Commencement of proceedings; contents of petition.
  • § 14-3-413.  Order to appear; contents thereof; when child taken into immediate custody; waiver of service.
  • § 14-3-414.  Service of process; order of custody.
  • § 14-3-415.  Presence of parent, custodian or guardian at hearing; failure to appear; avoidance of service; issuance of bench warrant.
  • § 14-3-416.  Appointment of guardian ad litem.
  • § 14-3-417.  Subpoenas for witnesses and evidence.
  • § 14-3-418.  Search warrant; when authorized; affidavit required; contents of affidavit and warrant; service and return.
  • § 14-3-419.  Physical and mental examinations.
  • § 14-3-420.  Emergency medical, surgical or dental examination or treatment.
  • § 14-3-421.  Reports of medical or mental examinations; use of results; copies.
  • § 14-3-422.  Advising of right to counsel required; appointment of counsel; verification of financial condition.
  • § 14-3-423.  Rights of parties generally; demand for and conduct of jury trial.
  • § 14-3-424.  Conduct of hearings generally; exclusion of general public and child; exceptions; consolidations, continuances or deferrals permitted.
  • § 14-3-425.  Burden of proof required; verdict of jury; effect thereof.
  • § 14-3-426.  Initial hearing; adjudicatory hearing; entry of decree and disposition; evidentiary matters; continuance of disposition hearing.
  • § 14-3-427.  Predisposition studies and reports.
  • § 14-3-428.  Abeyance of proceedings by consent decree; term of decree; reinstatement of proceedings; effect of discharge or completing term.
  • § 14-3-429.  Decree where child adjudged neglected; dispositions; terms and conditions; legal custody.
  • § 14-3-430.  Orders of protection; requirements.
  • § 14-3-431.  Duration of orders of disposition; termination of orders; permanency hearings; petition for termination of parental rights.
  • § 14-3-432.  Appeal; right generally; transcript provided; cost thereof.
  • § 14-3-433.  Stay of orders pending appeal; securing of payment; staying transfer of legal custody.
  • § 14-3-434.  Fees, costs and expenses.
  • § 14-3-435.  Ordering payment for support and treatment of child; how paid; enforcement.
  • § 14-3-436.  Proceedings deemed in equity.
  • § 14-3-437.  Records and reports confidential; inspection.
  • § 14-3-438.  Liability for contempt; penalties.
  • § 14-3-439.  Separate docket for juvenile cases; availability of records for statistics.
  • § 14-3-440.  Reasonable efforts for family reunification; exceptions.
  • § 14-3-441.  Confidentiality in court proceedings.

Cross references. —

As to privilege communication by a licensed or certified mental health professional, see § 33-38-113 .

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

47 Am. Jur. 2d Juvenile Courts §§ 45 to 51.

Construction and effect of statutes mandating consideration of, or creating presumptions regarding, domestic violence in awarding custody of children, 51 ALR5th 241.

§ 14-3-401. Short title.

This act shall be known and may be cited as the “Child Protection Act.”

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

Due process.—

Child Protection Act (CPA) clearly requires a noncustodial parent be given timely notice of the juvenile court proceedings and an opportunity to be heard regarding the placement of the child; the CPA expresses the clear and unequivocal rule of law that the juvenile court shall involve the noncustodial parent in the proceedings at the earliest possible time. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

Authority of Department of Family Services. —

Department of Family Services (DFS), a public social service agency, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 9-2-2101(a), with authority to oversee the custody and care of children in cases of abuse and neglect under the Child Protection Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-3-401 through 14-3-441 , was an “authorized agency” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-2-308 and 14-2-310 with authority to file a petition to terminate a mother's parental rights, even though DFS did not have custody of the children. State v. DH (In the Interest of LB), 2014 WY 10, 316 P.3d 1184, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 2014).

Cited in

E.F.W. v. Saint Stephen’s Mission Indian High Sch., 51 F. Supp. 2d 1217, 1999 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 8693 (D. Wyo. 1999); RS v. Dept. of Family Servs. (In re KLS), 2004 WY 87, 94 P.3d 1025, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 115 (2004); SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (2005); JA v. State, 2008 WY 15, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Feb. 8, 2008); Jet v. State (In re Drt), 2010 WY 137, 241 P.3d 489, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (Oct. 21, 2010); NC v. State, 2013 WY 2, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Jan 9, 2013); RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 16, 2014).

§ 14-3-402. Definitions.

  1. As used in this act:
    1. “Adjudication” means a finding by the court or the jury, incorporated in a decree, as to the truth of the facts alleged in the petition;
    2. “Adult” means an individual who has attained the age of majority;
    3. “Child” means an individual who is under the age of majority;
    4. “Clerk” means the clerk of a district court acting as the clerk of a juvenile court;
    5. “Commissioner” means a district court commissioner;
    6. “Court” means the juvenile court established by W.S. 5-8-101 ;
    7. “Custodian” means a person, institution or agency responsible for the child’s welfare and having legal custody of a child by court order or having actual physical custody and control of a child and acting in loco parentis;
    8. “Deprivation of custody” means transfer of legal custody by the court from a parent or previous legal custodian to another person, agency, organization or institution;
    9. “Judge” means the judge of the juvenile court;
    10. “Legal custody” means a legal status created by court order which vests in a custodian the right to have physical custody of a minor, the right and duty to protect, train and discipline a minor, the duty to provide him with food, shelter, clothing, transportation, ordinary medical care, education and in an emergency, the right and duty to authorize surgery or other extraordinary medical care. The rights and duties of legal custody are subject to the rights and duties of the guardian of the person of the minor, and to residual parental rights and duties;
    11. “Minor” means an individual who is under the age of majority;
    12. “Neglected child” means a child:
      1. Who has been subjected to neglect as defined in W.S. 14-3-202(a)(vii);
      2. Who has been subjected to abuse as defined in W.S. 14-3-202(a)(ii).
        1. through (IV) Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 4.
    13. “Parent” means either a natural or adoptive parent of the child, a person adjudged the parent of the child in judicial proceedings or a man presumed to be the father under W.S. 14-2-504 ;
    14. “Parties” include the child, his parents, guardian or custodian, the state of Wyoming and any other person made a party by an order to appear, or named by the juvenile court;
    15. “Protective supervision” means a legal status created by court order following an adjudication of neglect, whereby the child is permitted to remain in his home subject to supervision by the department of family services, a county or state probation officer or other qualified agency or individual the court may designate;
    16. “Residual parental rights and duties” means those rights and duties remaining with the parents after legal custody, guardianship of the person or both have been vested in another person, agency or institution. Residual parental rights and duties include but are not limited to:
      1. The duty to support and provide necessities of life;
      2. The right to consent to adoption;
      3. The right to reasonable visitation unless restricted or prohibited by court order;
      4. The right to determine the minor’s religious affiliation; and
      5. The right to petition on behalf of the minor.
    17. “Shelter care” means the temporary care of a child in physically unrestricting facilities pending court disposition or execution of a court order for placement or commitment;
    18. “Ordinary medical care” means medical, dental and vision examinations, routine medical, dental and vision treatment and emergency surgical procedures, but does not include nonemergency surgical procedures;
    19. “Temporary protective custody” means a legal status created prior to a shelter care hearing when a court, law enforcement officer, physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner takes a child into protective custody pursuant to W.S. 14-3-405 . Temporary protective custody vests in a custodian the duty to protect the child and arrange for the provision of food, shelter, clothing, transportation, ordinary medical care and education. Temporary protective custody shall be transferred from the law enforcement officer, physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner to the local child protection agency as soon as practicable to facilitate such care. Temporary protective custody divests the parent or custodian of his right to the custody and control of the child;
    20. “Transportation” means as defined in W.S. 14-3-202(a)(xvii);
    21. “Initial hearing” means a hearing held in accordance with W.S. 14-3-426 ;
    22. “Shelter care hearing” means a hearing held in accordance with W.S. 14-3-409 ;
    23. “Transfer hearing” means a hearing held in accordance with W.S. 14-6-237 ;
    24. “Another planned permanent living arrangement” means a permanency plan for youth sixteen (16) years of age or older other than reunification, adoption, legal guardianship or placement with a fit and willing relative;
    25. “Qualified individual” means a person who meets the requirements of 42 U.S.C. § 675a(c)(1)(D);
    26. “Qualified residential treatment program” means a program that meets the requirements of 42 U.S.C. § 672(k)(4);
    27. “This act” means W.S. 14-3-401 through 14-3-441 .

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2001, ch. 61, § 2; 2003, ch. 93, § 2; 2005, ch. 236, §§ 2, 4; 2011, ch. 79, § 1; 2016, ch. 95, § 2; 2020, ch. 2, § 1; ch. 87, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a)(x), inserted “transportation” before “ordinary medical care”; rewrote the definition of “neglected child” in (a)(xii); in (a)(xvi), inserted “legal” before “custody”; and inserted (a)(xviii) through (a)(xx), redesignating former (a)(xviii) as present (a)(xxi).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, added (a)(xxi) through (a)(xxiii), and redesignated former (a)(xxi) as (a)(xxiv).

The 2016 amendment renumbered former (a)(xxiv) as (a)(xxv), and added (a)(xxiv).

Laws 2016, ch. 95, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8, Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 4, 2016.

The 2020 amendments. — The first 2020 amendment, by ch. 2, § 1, effective July 1, 2020, added (a)(xxv), (a)(xxvi); redesignated former (a)(xxv) as (a)(xxvii); and in (a)(xxvii), substituted “14-3-440” for “14-3-441.”

The second 2020 amendment, by ch. 87, § 1, effective July 1, 2020, in (a)(xxv) substituted “14-3-441” for “14-3-440.”

This section is set out as reconciled by the Wyoming legislative service office.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Residual parental rights.—

Mother’s claim that a permanency order should have designated her preferred adoptive parents as the court-ordered adoptive parents had not been waived, but failed on the merits where the permanency order had not terminated the mother’s parental rights or changed legal custody, and nothing in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-431(k) (2017) required findings as to the merits of the prospective adoption applicants. DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Jurisdiction. —

In a termination of parental rights proceedings, the father was a party over whom the court had jurisdiction, and his failure to comply with the case plan constituted neglect. RS v. Dept. of Family Servs. (In re KLS), 2004 WY 87, 94 P.3d 1025, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 115 (Wyo. 2004).

Neglected children. —

Trial court did not err in finding neglect under this section where: (1) the mother's daughter was unable to find the mother at home, so the daughter called a bar where the mother was known to frequent, (2) the mother and her boyfriend went to the bar nearly every night and drank, (3) the mother was drunk at the time her daughter called her, (4) the mother's boyfriend threatened the mother's father and the children with physical violence, (5) the children had seen the mother and boyfriend doing drugs, (6) there had been many family arguments and fighting, and (7) the oldest daughter had attempted, or at least threatened, suicide; thus, the circumstances constituted the failure or refusal to provide the adequate care and supervision necessary for the children's well-being. DH v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re H Children), 2003 WY 155, 79 P.3d 997, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 2003).

Father had standing because he was adjudicated as neglectful based on the Mother's alleged violations of the consent decree. MR v. State (In the Interest of CDR), 2015 WY 79, 351 P.3d 264, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2015).

Court erred by revoking a consent decree in the neglect case because, although the court did not lose jurisdiction when the court was empowered to conduct a hearing and rule on the accusations, the court erred in concluding that the Mother violated the terms of the consent decree by drinking alcohol when the consent decree agreement did not expressly prohibit Mother from drinking but only required her to undergo alcohol/substance abuse evaluation and follow the regimen of treatment recommended. MR v. State (In the Interest of CDR), 2015 WY 79, 351 P.3d 264, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2015).

Juvenile court properly found that a mother had neglected her child by failing to provide adequate education for his well being because the child had numerous unexplained absences, the compulsory attendance statutes did not apply, the child protective services statutes and the Child Protection Act were complied with,and the mother received notice and an opportunity to be heard before the juvenile court made its findings. RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 334 P.3d 568, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo. 2014).

Contempt proceeding. —

Adjudication of neglect under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-402 et seq., the Wyoming Child Protection Act, was entered against defendant for not providing adequate care necessary for the well-being of his minor children; the juvenile court ordered defendant to satisfy certain requirements within a specified period of time. Because the contempt proceeding against defendant was not conducted as an independent criminal action apart from the underlying juvenile case as required by Wyo. R. Crim. P. 42(c), with its own caption and docket number, the juvenile court never acquired jurisdiction to proceed; its judgment and sentence of contempt was null and void. BD v. State, 2010 WY 18, 226 P.3d 272, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 2010).

Cited in

LW v. State (In the Interest of JW), 2010 WY 28, 226 P.3d 873, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Mar. 18, 2010); Jo v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (in the Interest of Re), 2011 WY 170, 267 P.3d 1092, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Dec. 28, 2011).

HP v. State, 2004 WY 82, 93 P.3d 982, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (2004).

Quoted in

DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Stated in

DT v. State, 2017 WY 36, 391 P.3d 1136, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 2017).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Rights of unwed father to obstruct adoption of his child by withholding consent, 61 ALR5th 151.

§ 14-3-403. Juvenile court authority over certain issues.

  1. Coincident with proceedings concerning a minor alleged to be neglected, the court has jurisdiction to:
    1. Determine questions concerning the right to legal custody of the minor;
    2. Order any party to the proceedings to perform any acts, duties and responsibilities the court deems necessary; or
    3. Order any party to the proceedings to refrain from any act or conduct the court deems detrimental to the best interest and welfare of the minor or essential to the enforcement of any lawful order of disposition of the minor made by the court.
  2. Nothing contained in this act is construed to deprive the district court of jurisdiction to determine questions of custody, parental rights, guardianship or any other questions involving minors, when the questions are the subject of or incidental to suits or actions commenced in or transferred to the district court as provided by law, except:
    1. If a petition involving the same child is pending in juvenile court or if continuing jurisdiction has been previously acquired by the juvenile court, the district court may certify the question of custody to the juvenile court; and
    2. The district court at any time may request the juvenile court to make recommendations pertaining to guardianship or legal custody.
  3. A party to the proceeding may file a petition for adoption or an appointment of guardianship in the underlying juvenile action in lieu of filing a petition with the district court.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2009, ch. 196, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, added (b)(i) and (b)(ii) and substituted “, except:” for the former period at the end of the introductory paragraph of (b); and added (c).

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

Claim precluded.—

This section precluded the mother's claim that the district court's jurisdiction was deficient. SAS v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re AGS), 2014 WY 143, 337 P.3d 470, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Wyo. 2014).

Cited in

In the Interest of MM v. Dep't of Family Servs., 2009 WY 28, 202 P.3d 409, 2009 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Mar. 3, 2009).

§ 14-3-404. Venue; change of venue or judge.

Proceedings under this act may be commenced in the county where the child is living or is present when the proceedings are commenced. Change of venue or change of judge may be had under the circumstances and upon the terms and conditions provided by law in a civil action in the district court.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

§ 14-3-405. Taking of child into custody; when permitted.

  1. A child, or any other child residing in the same household, may be taken into custody by a law enforcement officer without a warrant or court order and without the consent of the parents, guardians or others exercising temporary or permanent control over the child when:
    1. There are reasonable grounds to believe a child is abandoned, lost, suffering from illness or injury or seriously endangered by the child’s surroundings and immediate custody appears to be necessary for his protection;
    2. The child’s conduct or behavior seriously endangers himself and immediate custody appears necessary; or
    3. The child is as evidenced by an examination being abused or neglected by a parent, guardian or legal custodian, a member of the parent’s, guardian’s or legal custodian’s household or any other person known to the parent, guardian or legal custodian.
  2. A child may be taken into temporary protective custody by a physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner without a warrant or court order and without the consent of the parents, guardians or others exercising temporary or permanent control over the child when the physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner treating the child, or a hospital in which the child is being treated, finds that there is reasonable cause to believe an imminent danger to the child’s life, health or safety exists unless the child is taken into protective custody, whether or not additional medical treatment is required, and there is not time to apply for a court order.
  3. A district attorney may file an emergency petition, or the department of family services, a local law enforcement officer, an administrator of a hospital in which a child reasonably believed to have been abused or neglected is being treated, or any physician, physician’s assistant or nurse practitioner who treated the child may request the court for a protective order. After considering the emergency petition or request, the judge or commissioner, upon finding that there is reasonable cause to believe that a child has been abused or neglected and that the child, by continuing in his place of residence or in the care and custody of the person responsible for his health, safety and welfare, would be in imminent danger of his life, health or safety, may:
    1. Issue an ex parte order or search warrant. The order shall place the child in the temporary protective custody of the local child protection agency;
    2. Issue an emergency order or search warrant upon application and hearing, authorizing ordinary or emergency care of the child or authorizing a forensic examination to collect evidence.
  4. Temporary protective custody shall not exceed forty-eight (48) hours, excluding weekends and legal holidays.
  5. When necessary for the best interest or welfare of the child in temporary protective custody, a court may order medical or other necessary health care, including mental health and substance abuse care, notwithstanding the absence of a prior finding of child abuse or neglect.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, § 2; 2019, ch. 77, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, inserted the language pertaining to consent in the introductory language in (a); and added (b) through (e).

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in the introductory language in (a), substituted “A child, or any other child residing in the same household, may” for “A child may,” in (a)(i), substituted “the child's” for “his,” added (a)(iii), and made related changes.

Due process.—

Juvenile court violated a father’s right to due process because it failed to give him reasonable notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard in the child protection action; many of the requirements of the Child Protection Act were not followed because the father was not informed when the child was taken into protective custody or of the shelter care hearing; the father was materially prejudiced by the due process violations because his lack of involvement colored the juvenile court’s ruling. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

Cited in

Lara v. State, 2001 WY 53, 25 P.3d 507, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 2001); RS v. Dept. of Family Servs. (In re KLS), 2004 WY 87, 94 P.3d 1025, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 115 (2004).

Applicability. —

Because children already had been adjudicated neglected before they were removed from their mother's custody and placed with relatives, the juvenile court correctly applied Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-429(a)(iv) instead of this section in deciding its conclusions of law. RH v. State (In the Interest of DRS), 2011 WY 128, 261 P.3d 697, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Wyo. 2011).

§ 14-3-406. Child in custody; no shelter care placement without court order; exceptions; notice to parent or guardian; release.

  1. A child taken into temporary protective custody shall not be placed in shelter care without a court order unless shelter care is required to:
    1. Protect the child’s person;
    2. Prevent the child from being removed from the jurisdiction of the court; or
    3. Provide the child having no parent, guardian, custodian or other responsible adult with supervision and care and return him to the court when required.
  2. Any person taking a child into temporary protective custody under this act shall as soon as possible notify the child’s parent, guardian or custodian. Unless the child’s shelter care is authorized by court order or required for one (1) of the reasons in subsection (a) of this section, the child shall be released to the care of his parent, guardian, custodian or other responsible adult upon that person’s written promise to present the child before the court upon request.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “temporary protective custody” for “custody” in the introductory language in (a) and in (b), and made a related change.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

Due process.—

Juvenile court violated a father’s right to due process because it failed to give him reasonable notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard in the child protection action; many of the requirements of the Child Protection Act were not followed because the father was not informed when the child was taken into protective custody or of the shelter care hearing; the father was materially prejudiced by the due process violations because his lack of involvement colored the juvenile court’s ruling. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

Cited in

Lara v. State, 2001 WY 53, 25 P.3d 507, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 2001).

§ 14-3-407. Shelter care; delivery of child pending hearing; placing children; notice if no court order.

  1. If shelter care of a child appears necessary to the person taking custody of the child, the child shall be delivered as soon as possible to the court or to the department of family services pending a hearing.
  2. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 236, § 4.
  3. The department of family services shall promptly notify the court and the district attorney of any child being cared for by the department without a court order and shall deliver the child to the court upon request.
  4. The department of family services shall care for the child under this section pursuant to temporary protective custody provisions as specified in W.S. 14-3-208 .

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, §§ 2, 4.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote the section to provide that the department of family services rather than a shelter care facility is responsible where a child is in immediate need of placement prior to a hearing, repealing former (b), which pertained to shelter care placement, and adding (d).

§ 14-3-408. Notice of shelter care to be given district attorney; written statement required; duty of district attorney.

  1. When a child is taken into temporary protective custody without a court order and is placed in shelter care pursuant to W.S. 14-3-405(a) or (b), the person taking temporary protective custody of the child shall notify the district attorney without delay. Also the person shall as soon as possible file a brief written statement with the district attorney setting forth the facts which led to taking the child into custody and the reason why the child was not released.
  2. Upon receiving notice that a child is being held in shelter care, the district attorney shall immediately review the need for shelter care and may order the child released unless he determines shelter care is necessary under the provisions of W.S. 14-3-406(a) or unless ordered by the court.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2005, ch. 236, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a) substituted “temporary protective custody” for “custody” and inserted the internal reference.

Due process.—

Juvenile court violated a father’s right to due process because it failed to give him reasonable notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard in the child protection action; many of the requirements of the Child Protection Act were not followed because the father was not informed when the child was taken into protective custody or of the shelter care hearing; the father and his family were not considered by the State or the juvenile court as options for the child’s placement. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

§ 14-3-409. Taking of child into custody; shelter care hearing where no court order; conditional release; evidence; rehearing.

  1. When a child is taken into temporary protective custody without a court order or under an ex parte emergency order, a petition as provided in W.S. 14-3-412 shall be promptly filed and presented to the court. A shelter care hearing shall be held as soon as reasonably possible not later than forty-eight (48) hours, excluding weekends and legal holidays, after the child is taken into temporary protective custody to determine if further shelter care is required pending further court action.
