  1. An order of disposition shall remain in force for an indefinite period until terminated by the court whenever it appears the purpose of the order has been achieved and it is in the child’s best interest that he be discharged from further court jurisdiction.
  2. Unless sooner terminated by court order, all orders issued under this act shall terminate with respect to a child adjudicated neglected, when he reaches eighteen (18) years of age unless the court has ordered care or services to continue beyond that time. The court shall conduct a review hearing at least six (6) months before the child reaches eighteen (18) years of age to determine whether care or transitional services should continue and for what period of time prior to the individual reaching the age of twenty-one (21) years.
  3. The court shall conduct a review hearing six (6) months from the date of the child’s removal from the home and every six (6) months thereafter. If the child is placed in a qualified residential treatment program, the department of family services shall present to the court at the six (6) month review hearing the information required under subparagraphs (j)(iii)(A) through (D) of this section. At the six (6) month review hearing the court shall review the case plan to determine:
    1. The health and safety of the child;
    2. The continuing necessity for the placement;
    3. The appropriateness of the current placement;
    4. The reasonableness of efforts made to reunify the family and the consistency of those efforts with the case plan;
    5. The appropriateness of the case plan and the extent of compliance with the case plan including the permanent placement of the child;
    6. If progress has been made toward alleviating or mitigating the causes necessitating placement outside the home and the extent of that progress; and
    7. The date the child is expected to be returned to the home or placed for adoption or legal guardianship.
  4. The court shall conduct a permanency hearing no later than twelve (12) months from the date of the child’s removal from the home and not less than once every twelve (12) months thereafter if the child remains in out-of-home placement or more frequently as deemed necessary by the court.
  5. If the court determines as provided in W.S. 14-2-309(a)(vi), (b) or (c) that reasonable efforts to preserve and reunify the family are not required, a permanency hearing shall be held for the child within thirty (30) days after the determination.
  6. At the permanency hearing, the court shall make determinations of reasonable efforts as outlined in W.S. 14-3-440 .
  7. A permanency hearing is not required if the case was dismissed, the child was not removed from the home or the child was returned to the child’s parent or guardian.
  8. The permanency hearing may be combined with a hearing required by other sections of this chapter if the hearing is held within twelve (12) months from the date of the child’s removal from the home. If a permanency hearing is combined with another hearing, the requirements of the court related to the disposition of the other hearing shall be met in addition to the requirements of this section.
  9. At the permanency hearing, the department of family services shall present to the court:
    1. Efforts made to:
      1. Effectuate the permanency plan for the child, address the options for the child’s permanent placement, examine the reasons for excluding other permanency options and set forth the proposed plan to carry out the placement decision, including specific times for achieving the permanency plan; and
      2. Ensure the child be provided, to the greatest extent possible, the opportunity to participate in age appropriate or developmentally appropriate activities and experiences as defined in W.S. 14-13-101 (a)(i) to promote healthy child and adolescent development consistent with W.S. 14-13-101 through 14-13-104 .
    2. If the permanency plan is classified as another planned permanent living arrangement:
      1. A compelling reason for establishing another planned permanent living arrangement; and
      2. Documentation of the ongoing and unsuccessful efforts to return the child home, place the child for adoption or with a legal guardian or a fit and willing relative for purposes of guardianship or adoption, including evidence of efforts to use social media or other search technology to find biological family members for the child.
    3. If the child is placed in a qualified residential treatment program:
      1. Information to show that ongoing assessment of the child’s strengths and needs continues to support the determination that placement in a qualified residential treatment program provides the most effective and appropriate level of care for the child in the least restrictive environment consistent with the short-term and long-term goals of the child and the child’s permanency plan;
      2. The specific treatment needs that will be met for the child in the placement;
      3. The length of time the child is expected to remain in the placement;
      4. The efforts made by the department of family services to prepare the child to return home or be placed for adoption or legal guardianship.
  10. At the permanency hearing, the court shall:
    1. Determine whether the permanency plan is in the best interest of the child and whether the department of family services has made reasonable efforts to finalize the plan;
    2. Order the department of family services to take any additional steps necessary to effectuate the terms of the permanency plan;
    3. Ask the child about his desired permanency outcome if it is determined that the child should be present at the hearing;
    4. Ask the child’s guardian ad litem or other legal representative about the child’s desired permanency outcome if it is determined inappropriate for the child to be present at the hearing;
    5. If the permanency plan is classified as another planned permanent living arrangement:
      1. Make a judicial determination and explain why, as of the date of the hearing, another planned permanent living arrangement is the best permanency plan for the child; and
      2. Provide reasons why it continues not to be in the best interest of the child to return home or be placed for adoption or with a legal guardian or a fit and willing relative for purposes of guardianship or adoption.
    6. Require that the child be provided, to the greatest extent possible, the opportunity to participate in age appropriate or developmentally appropriate activities and experiences as defined in W.S. 14-13-101 (a)(i) to promote healthy child and adolescent development consistent with W.S. 14-13-101 through 14-13-104 .
  11. When a child has been placed in foster care under the responsibility of the state for fifteen (15) of the most recent twenty-two (22) months the state shall file a petition to terminate parental rights or seek to be joined as a party to the petition if a petition has been filed by another party, unless:
    1. The child is in the care of a relative;
    2. The state agency has documented in the case plan a compelling reason for determining that filing the petition is not in the best interest of the child; or
    3. The state agency has not provided services to the child’s family deemed to be necessary for the safe return of the child to the home, if reasonable efforts described in W.S. 14-3-440 are required to be made.
  12. Concurrently with the filing of a petition under subsection (m) of this section, the state agency shall identify, recruit, process and approve a qualified family for adoption of the child.
  13. A petition to terminate parental rights shall be filed within sixty (60) days of a judicial determination that reasonable efforts to reunify the child and parent are not required pursuant to W.S. 14-2-309(a)(vi), (b) or (c).
  14. A termination of parental rights hearing shall be held within ninety (90) days of the filing of the termination petition unless continued by the court for good cause shown.
  15. At each of the review hearings, the court shall enter findings on the record pursuant to subsection (c) of this section.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 1998, ch. 44, § 1; 1999, ch. 4, § 1; 2001, ch. 61, § 2; 2004, ch. 127, § 2; 2005, ch. 201, § 1; 2016, ch. 95, § 2; 2020, ch. 2, § 1.

The 2004 amendment, effective July 1, 2004, in (b), substituted “unless the court has ordered care or services to continue beyond that time. The court shall conduct a review hearing at least six (6) months before the child reaches eighteen (18) years of age to determine whether care or transitional services should continue and for what period of time prior to the individual reaching the age of twenty-one (21) years” for “or has graduated from high school”; and added (g).

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote the introductory language in (c) to provide for a review hearing once every six months rather than once every 12 months; added (d) through (k), redesignating former (d) and (e) as (m) and (n); and added (o), redesignating former (f) and (g) as (p) and (q).

The 2016 amendment rewrote (j) and added (j)(i)(A), (j)(i)(B), (j)(ii)(A), and (j)(ii)(B), and rewrote (k) and added (k)(i) through (k)(iv), (k)(v)A) and (k)(v)(B), and (k)(vi).

Laws 2016, ch. 95, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, Section 8, Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 4, 2016.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (c), added the second sentence; and added (j)(iii).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) or (l) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

Due process. —

After the juvenile court issued an order that authorized removal of neglected children from their mother's custody without a subsequent order, the mother's due process rights were not violated by removing the children without first conducting an evidentiary hearing. She had notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard at the review hearing. RH v. State (In the Interest of DRS), 2011 WY 128, 261 P.3d 697, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Wyo. 2011).

In Wyoming dependency/neglect proceedings, due process requires that if a change in a permanency plan includes adoption or permanent placement other than reunification, parents must have the right to request, and on request must be provided with, an evidentiary hearing, and a parent must request the hearing if he or she desires one, because there may be instances in which parents do not dispute a recommendation or are content with a non-evidentiary hearing, so the failure to request such a hearing waives that right. KC v. State (In the Interest of GC), 2015 WY 73, 351 P.3d 236, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 84 (Wyo. 2015).

Hearing on change in goal of a permanency plan from reunification to adoption did not violate a mother's due process rights because (1) the mother did not seek a hearing or directly claim the hearing held violated due process, and (2) lack of a full evidentiary hearing was not plain error, as such a right was not clear at the time of the hearing, since Wyo. R. Evid. 1101(b)(3) said the rules of evidence only applied to juvenile adjudicatory hearings. KC v. State (In the Interest of GC), 2015 WY 73, 351 P.3d 236, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 84 (Wyo. 2015).

Juvenile court properly changed the permanency plan for a mother's child from family reunification to termination and adoption because, while the delays in holding review hearings were unacceptable and contrary to the child's best interests, the mother waived her due process and other claims relating to the change in permanency from reunification to adoption when she advocated a permanency goal of adoption, the Child Protection Act did not require that the permanency order include findings regarding the merits of prospective adoption applicants or that the order give effect to the mother's adoption preference, and determination of the adoptive parent(s) was a matter for a separate proceeding. DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Revocation of consent decree. —

Revocation of consent decree. — Court erred by revoking a consent decree in the neglect case because, although the court did not lose jurisdiction when the court was empowered to conduct a hearing and rule on the accusations, the court erred in concluding that the Mother violated the terms of the consent decree by drinking alcohol when the consent decree agreement did not expressly prohibit Mother from drinking but only required her to undergo alcohol/substance abuse evaluation and follow the regimen of treatment recommended. MR v. State (In the Interest of CDR), 2015 WY 79, 351 P.3d 264, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2015).

Commencement of termination proceedings. — Termination of a mother's parental rights was not invalidated due to a decision not to place children with their maternal grandmother because the placement decision did not affect the mother's ability to visit the children or strengthen a relationship with them; moreover, that placement was unsuitable due to the grandmother's failure to cooperate and the fact that she lived with a convicted sex offender. In addition, the Wyoming Department of Family Services was not required to wait for a second home evaluation for the grandmother after she moved to a different state before commencing termination proceedings against the mother. K.H. v. Wyo. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re D.H.), 2007 WY 196, 173 P.3d 365, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (Wyo. 2007).

Authorized agency. — Department of Family Services (DFS), a public social service agency, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 9-2-2101(a), with authority to oversee the custody and care of children in cases of abuse and neglect under the Child Protection Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-3-401 through 14-3-441 , was an “authorized agency” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 14-2-308 and 14-2-310 with authority to file a petition to terminate a mother's parental rights, even though DFS did not have custody of the children. State v. DH (In the Interest of LB), 2014 WY 10, 316 P.3d 1184, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 2014).

Presence of children.—

While this section clearly required the juvenile court to determine whether the children should be present at the permanency hearing, the juvenile court made the required determination at the end of the hearing and the statute did not expressly require that the decision be made prior to the hearing DT v. State, 2017 WY 36, 391 P.3d 1136, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 2017).

Residual parental rights.—

Mother’s claim that a permanency order should have designated her preferred adoptive parents as the court-ordered adoptive parents had not been waived, but failed on the merits where the permanency order had not terminated the mother’s parental rights or changed legal custody, and nothing in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-431(k) (2017) required findings as to the merits of the prospective adoption applicants. DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Mother’s claim that a permanency order should have designated the her preferred adoptive parents as the court-ordered adoptive parents had not been waived, but failed on the merits where the permanency order had not terminated the mother’s parental rights or changed legal custody, and nothing in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-431(k) (2017) required findings as to the merits of the prospective adoption applicants. DM v. State (In re L-MHB), 2017 WY 110, 401 P.3d 949, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2017).

Sufficiency of evidence. —

Sufficient evidence supported a trial court's decisions to change the goal of a permanency plan from reunification to adoption because a child's mother did not comply with the mother's case plan. KC v. State (In the Interest of GC), 2015 WY 73, 351 P.3d 236, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 84 (Wyo. 2015).

It was not an abuse of discretion to alter a father’s sons’ permanency plan from reunification to termination of parental rights and adoption because sufficient evidence showed the Wyoming Department of Family Services (DFS) made reasonable reunification efforts, but those efforts were unsuccessful when the father (1) refused to cooperate with DFS or utilize rehabilitation programs available to the father while incarcerated, (2) engaged in misconduct limiting the father’s ability to have contact with the sons, and (3) then communicated with the sons only sporadically. TW v. State (In re JW), 2018 WY 22, 411 P.3d 422, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2018).

Termination of parental rights was proper. —

There was sufficient evidence to support the finding that termination of a mother's parental rights, rather than reunification, was in the best interest of her children under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-431(k) because she failed to improve her parenting skills despite 14 months of sustained assistance; she had irregular attendance and lack of engagement at visitations. JO v. State, Dep't of Family Servs. (In the Interest of RE), 2011 WY 170, 267 P.3d 1092, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Wyo. 2011).

Quoted in

Jet v. State (In re Drt), 2010 WY 137, 241 P.3d 489, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 146 (Oct. 21, 2010).

Cited in

LW v. State (In the Interest of JW), 2010 WY 28, 226 P.3d 873, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Mar. 18, 2010); SAS v. Dep't of Family Servs. (In re AGS), 2014 WY 143, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Nov. 7, 2014).

HP v. State, 2004 WY 82, 93 P.3d 982, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (2004).

Jurisdiction.—

Juvenile court’s jurisdiction lapsed on a child’s 18th birthday because the juvenile court made the required findings over three months after the child turned 18; necause the juvenile court’s failure to address the procedural requirement deprived it of jurisdiction over the child, its belated order that its jurisdiction would continue until either an adult guardianship was in place or the child turned 21 was without effect. RH v. State (In the Interest of BG), 2019 WY 116, 451 P.3d 1161, 2019 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 2019).

Grandparents' motion denied.—

Juvenile court did not make an unreasonable decision in denying the grandparents' motion seeking to transfer placement of their grandchild from the foster parents to the grandparents; the child had been in the foster parents' care approximately two and a half years, testimony indicated that changing placement could be detrimental to her, the juvenile court correctly concluded that the best interests of the child were paramount, and the juvenile court's reasoning was in accord with the statute governing permanency hearings. PM v. State (In the Interest of SO), 2016 WY 99, 382 P.3d 51, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 110 (Wyo. 2016).

Stated in

E.R.C.K. v. State Dep't of Family Servs., 2013 WY 160, 314 P.3d 1170, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 166 (Dec 24, 2013).

§ 14-3-432. Appeal; right generally; transcript provided; cost thereof.

  1. Any party including the state may appeal any final order, judgment or decree of the juvenile court to the supreme court within the time and in the manner provided by the Wyoming Rules of Appellate Procedure.
  2. Upon motion of the child’s parents, guardian or custodian, supported by affidavit stating they are financially unable to purchase a transcript of the proceeding, a transcript or so much thereof necessary to support the appeal shall be provided at no cost or at a cost the court determines they are able to pay. Any cost of the transcript not charged to the appellant shall be certified by the court to the county treasurer and paid from the funds of the county in which the proceedings were held.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

Order in Child Neglect Proceeding Constituted Final Appealable Order. —

Juvenile court’s order in the prior neglect proceedings was a final, appealable order under the Child Protection Act and the Wyoming Rules of Appellate Procedure, and constituted a judgment, the collateral attack of which generally was disallowed; thus, the mother could not collaterally attack the order in the prior neglect proceedings on appeal under the guise of appealing the district court’s order terminating her parental rights. Reed v. State (In re Parental Rights To AM-LR), 2018 WY 76, 421 P.3d 551, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 78 (Wyo. 2018).

§ 14-3-433. Stay of orders pending appeal; securing of payment; staying transfer of legal custody.

  1. If an appeal is taken, an order to pay a fine, costs, support for a child, restitution or any order for the payment of money may be stayed by the juvenile court or by the supreme court pending appeal. The court may require the appellant to deposit with the clerk of court the whole or any part of the payment ordered, to give bond for the payment thereof or any other terms and conditions to secure payment upon final determination of the appeal as the court deems proper. The court may also issue any appropriate order to restrain the appellant from dissipating his assets pending appeal.
  2. Either the juvenile court or the supreme court may stay an order transferring legal custody of a child to a person, agency, organization or institution other than his parents, guardian or former custodian, provided that suitable provision is made for the shelter care of the child pending the appeal.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

§ 14-3-434. Fees, costs and expenses.

  1. There is no fee for filing a petition under this act nor shall any state, county or local law enforcement officer charge a fee for service of process under this act. Witness fees, juror fees and travel expenses in the amounts allowable by law may be paid to persons other than the parties who are subpoenaed or required to appear at any hearing pursuant to this act.
  2. The following costs and expenses, when approved and certified by the court to the county treasurer, shall be a charge upon the funds of the county where the proceedings are held and shall be paid by the board of county commissioners of that county:
    1. Witness fees and travel expense;
    2. Jury fees, costs and travel expense;
    3. Costs of service of process or notice by certified mail;
    4. Costs of any physical or mental examinations or treatment ordered by the court;
    5. Reasonable compensation for services and costs of counsel appointed by the court;
    6. Reasonable compensation for services and costs of a guardian ad litem appointed by the court, unless the county participates in the guardian ad litem program pursuant to W.S. 14-12-101 through 14-12-104 and the program was appointed to provide the guardian ad litem; and
    7. Any other costs of the proceedings which would be assessable as costs in the district court.
  3. In every case in which a guardian ad litem has been appointed to represent the child under this act or in which counsel has been appointed under this act to represent the child’s parents, guardian or custodian, the court shall determine whether the child’s parents, guardian, custodian or other person responsible for the child’s support is able to pay part or all of the costs of representation and shall enter specific findings on the record. If the court determines that any of the parties is able to pay any amount as reimbursement for costs of representation, the court shall order reimbursement or shall state on the record the reasons why reimbursement was not ordered. The court may also in any case order that all or any part of the costs and expenses enumerated in paragraphs (b)(i), (iii), (iv) and (vii) of this section, be reimbursed to the county by the child’s parents or any person legally obligated for his support, or any of them jointly and severally, upon terms the court may direct. An order for reimbursement of costs made pursuant to this subsection may be enforced as provided in W.S. 14-3-435 . Any reimbursement ordered for guardian ad litem services provided pursuant to W.S. 14-12-101 through 14-12-104 shall be apportioned between the county and the guardian ad litem program in accordance with payments made for those services.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2012, ch. 76, § 3.

The 2012 amendment, in (b)(vi), inserted “unless the county participates in the guardian ad litem program pursuant to W.S. 14-12-101 through 14-12-104 and the program was appointed to provide the guardian ad litem”; and in (c), added the last sentence.

Laws 2012, ch. 76 § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 13, 2012.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

§ 14-3-435. Ordering payment for support and treatment of child; how paid; enforcement.

  1. When legal custody of a child, other than temporary guardianship, is vested by court order in an individual, agency, institution or organization other than the child’s parents, the court shall in the same or any subsequent proceeding inquire into the financial condition of the child’s parents or any other person who may be legally obligated to support the child. After due notice and hearing the court shall order the parents or any other legally obligated person to pay a reasonable sum for the support and treatment of the child during the time that a dispositional order is in force. The requirements of W.S. 20-2-101 through 20-2-406 apply to this section. The amount of support shall be determined in accordance with the presumptive child support established by W.S. 20-2-304 . In any case where the court has deviated from the presumptive child support, the reasons therefor shall be specifically set forth in the order. The amount ordered to be paid shall be paid to the clerk of the juvenile court for transmission to the person, institution or agency having legal custody of the child or to whom compensation is due. The clerk of court is authorized to receive periodic payments payable in the name or for the benefit of the child, including but not limited to social security, veteran’s administration benefits or insurance annuities, and apply the payments as the court directs. An order for support under this subsection shall include a statement of the addresses and social security numbers if known, of each obligor, the names and addresses of each obligor’s employer and the names and birth dates of each child to whom the order relates. The court shall order each obligor to notify the clerk of court in writing within fifteen (15) days of any change in address or employment. If any person who is legally obligated to support the child does not have full time employment, the court may require that person to seek full time employment and may require community service work in lieu of payment until full time employment is obtained.
  2. An order for the payment of money entered against a parent or other person legally obligated to support a child under the provisions of W.S. 14-3-434 , 20-2-101 through 20-2-406 or this section shall be entered separately from the decree of disposition under W.S. 14-3-429 and shall not be treated as a part of the confidential court record under W.S. 14-3-437 . The order may be filed in the district court of any county in the state. From the time of filing, the order shall have the same effect as a judgment or decree of the district court in a civil action and may be enforced by the district attorney, or the department of family services in the same manner and with the same powers as in other child support cases under W.S. 20-2-303 , 20-2-304 , 20-2-307 , 20-2-311 , 20-2-401 through 20-2-406 and 20-6-101 through 20-6-222 , or in any manner provided by law for enforcement of a civil judgment for money.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2000, ch. 1, § 1; ch. 34, § 3; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 70, § 2; 2018, ch. 42, § 1.

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, in (b), substituted “ W.S. 20-2-303 , 20-2-304 , 20-2-307 ” for “ W.S. 20-2-303 through 20-2-305 , 20-2-307 .”

§ 14-3-436. Proceedings deemed in equity.

All proceedings under this act shall be regarded as proceedings in equity and the court shall have and exercise equitable jurisdiction.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

§ 14-3-437. Records and reports confidential; inspection.

  1. Throughout proceedings pursuant to this act the court shall safeguard the records from disclosure. Upon completion of the proceedings, whether or not there is an adjudication, the court shall order the entire file, except for child support orders, and record of the proceeding sealed and the court shall not release these records except to the extent necessary to meet the following inquiries:
    1. From another court of law;
    2. From an agency preparing a presentence report for another court;
    3. From a party to the proceeding;
    4. From the department of family services for purposes of establishing, modifying or enforcing a support obligation.
  2. Upon receipt of inquiries as set out in this section, the court may release a copy of the presentence investigation report together with a cover letter stating the disposition of the proceeding.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1; 2000, ch. 1, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

§ 14-3-438. Liability for contempt; penalties.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the court upon its own motion or upon the motion of the district or county attorney, or guardian ad litem, may find that the child’s parent, parents, or guardian or any other person who willfully violates, or neglects or refuses to obey or perform any order or provision of this act is liable for contempt of court and may be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or incarcerated not more than ninety (90) days, or both.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

Due process requirements not met. —

Adjudication of neglect under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-402 et seq., the Wyoming Child Protection Act, was entered against defendant for not providing adequate care necessary for the well-being of his minor children; the juvenile court ordered defendant to satisfy certain requirements within a specified period of time. Because the contempt proceeding under pursuant to Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 14-3-438 against defendant was not conducted as an independent criminal action apart from the underlying juvenile case as required by Wyo. R. Crim. P. 42(c), with its own caption and docket number, the juvenile court never acquired jurisdiction to proceed; its judgment and sentence of contempt was null and void. BD v. State, 2010 WY 18, 226 P.3d 272, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 2010).

Defendant's due process right to notice of criminal contempt charges was violated because (1) an order to show cause gave no adequate notice of the terms of the order defendant allegedly violated or defendant's alleged conduct constituting some violations, and (2) the error was compounded by a refusal to give defendant's counsel access to the juvenile court file containing the underlying order. Brown v. State, 2017 WY 45, 393 P.3d 1265, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 2017).

Concurrent criminal contempt jurisdiction.—

Juvenile court criminal contempt jurisdiction was concurrent with district courts because (1) the legislative grant of jurisdiction to juvenile courts did not use the terms “exclusive” or “concurrent,” (2) Wyo. Const. art. 5, § 10 granted district courts general criminal jurisdiction, and (3) juvenile court jurisdiction was to be strictly construed. Brown v. State, 2017 WY 45, 393 P.3d 1265, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 2017).

Cited in

DB v. State (In re CRA), 2016 WY 24, 368 P.3d 294, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2016).

§ 14-3-439. Separate docket for juvenile cases; availability of records for statistics.

The clerk of the court shall maintain a separate docket for cases under this act and record therein the case number, the allegations of the petition, the age of the child involved and the disposition made. The records shall be made available for statistical purposes provided the names of the parties are not revealed.

History. Laws 1997, ch. 199, § 1.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 14-3-402(a)(xxiv).

§ 14-3-440. Reasonable efforts for family reunification; exceptions.

  1. Except as provided in W.S. 14-2-309(b) or (c), reasonable efforts shall be made to preserve and reunify the family:
    1. Prior to placement of the child outside the home, to prevent or eliminate the need for removing the child from the child’s home; and
    2. To make it possible for the child to safely return to the child’s home.
  2. In determining what reasonable efforts shall be made with respect to a child and in making those reasonable efforts, the child’s health and safety shall be the paramount concern.
  3. Reasonable efforts to place a child for adoption or with a legal guardian may be made concurrently with the reasonable efforts described in subsection (a) of this section.
  4. If continuation of reasonable efforts described in subsection (a) of this section is determined to be inconsistent with the permanency plan for the child, reasonable efforts shall be made for placement of the child in a timely manner in accordance with the permanency plan, and to complete the steps necessary to finalize the permanent placement of the child.
  5. Reasonable efforts determinations shall include whether or not services to the family have been accessible, available and appropriate.
  6. The court shall make the reasonable efforts determinations required under this section at every court hearing. The reasonable efforts determinations shall be documented in the court’s orders.
  7. If the court determines as provided in W.S. 14-2-309(a)(vi), (b) or (c) that reasonable efforts to preserve and reunify the family are not required:
    1. A permanency hearing as provided in W.S. 14-3-431(e) shall be held for the child within thirty (30) days after the determination; and
    2. Reasonable efforts shall be made to place the child in a timely manner in accordance with the permanency plan, and to complete whatever steps are necessary to finalize the permanent placement of the child.
  8. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 201, § 2.

History. Laws 2001, ch. 61, § 1; 2005, ch. 201, §§ 1, 2; 2009, ch. 196, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, deleted former (g)(i), providing for a permanency hearing if a court determined that reasonable effort to reunify a family were not required, redesignating former (g)(ii) as present (g); and repealed former (h), requiring a petition to terminate parental rights to be filed within 60 days of a judicial determination that reasonable efforts to reunify a family were not required.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, redesignated former (g) as (g)(ii); and added the present introductory language in (g) and (g)(i).

Aggravating circumstances not shown.—

Juvenile court abused its discretion by concluding the State had proven by clear and convincing evidence that aggravating circumstances existed that would make reunification between a father and a child unlikely because the facts did not establish severe misconduct toward child; the father was never charged with abuse or neglect of child, and he was taking drug tests and following the case plan so he could have visitation with the child. AA v. State, 2021 WY 18, 479 P.3d 1252, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2021).

Construction.—

Reunification efforts are aimed at preventing removal of the child from the home or making it possible to return the child to his home, and this statutory language references a preexisting home and family. GS v. State (In the Interest of VS), 2018 WY 119, 429 P.3d 14, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 123 (Wyo. 2018).

Proper efforts made.—

Department of Family Services made reasonable efforts to reunify the family for 20 months, without success; the department’s primary legal obligation was to reunify the existent family, which was with the mother, but she failed to comply with her case plan, and despite the father being in prison with a release date of 2022, the department tried to find a placement for the child within his family. The father had no relationship with the child, and it was in the child’s best interest to change the permanency plan to adoption. GS v. State (In the Interest of VS), 2018 WY 119, 429 P.3d 14, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 123 (Wyo. 2018).

Applicability. —

State was not required to show reasonable efforts to reunify the family in a parental rights termination proceeding where there was no requirement for reasonable efforts because the termination was sought on the basis that the children were left in the care of another for at least a year under and had been in foster care with the state for over fifteen of the last twenty-months. SLJ v. Dep't of Family Servs.(In re SJJ), 2005 WY 3, 104 P.3d 74, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2005).

It was not an abuse of discretion to alter a father’s sons’ permanency plan from reunification to termination of parental rights and adoption because sufficient evidence showed the Wyoming Department of Family Services (DFS) made reasonable reunification efforts, but those efforts were unsuccessful when the father (1) refused to cooperate with DFS or utilize rehabilitation programs available to the father while incarcerated, (2) engaged in misconduct limiting the father’s ability to have contact with the sons, and (3) then communicated with the sons only sporadically. TW v. State (In re JW), 2018 WY 22, 411 P.3d 422, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2018).

§ 14-3-441. Confidentiality in court proceedings.

In the event a confidentiality order has been entered pursuant to W.S. 35-21-112 or any other court order allowing a party to maintain confidentiality of addresses or other information identifying the residence of the victim of domestic abuse, the address and city or state of residence and other information identifying the residence of the victim of domestic abuse and any child residing with the victim of domestic abuse shall remain confidential in any court proceedings under this title.

History. Laws 2013, ch. 98, § 1.

Effective dates. —

Laws 2013, ch. 98, § 3, makes the act effective July 1, 2013.

Cited in

RM v. State (In re JM), 2014 WY 114, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 16, 2014); DB v. State (In re CRA), 2016 WY 24, 368 P.3d 294, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2016).

Chapter 4 Child Care Facilities

  • Article 1. Child Care Facilities Certification
  • Article 2. Quality Child Care

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Tort liability of private nursery school or day-care center, or employee thereof, for injury to child while attending facility, 58 ALR4th 240.

Governmental liability for negligence in licensing, regulating or supervising private day-care home in which child is injured, 68 ALR4th 266.

Article 1. Child Care Facilities Certification

  • § 14-4-101.  Definitions.
  • § 14-4-102.  Certification required; exceptions.
  • § 14-4-103.  Certification board; establishment; composition; appointment of lay members; duties.
  • § 14-4-104.  Certification; application; standards; notification to certify or refuse; term.
  • § 14-4-105.  Provisional certificate.
  • § 14-4-106.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-4-107.  Inspection by certifying board; right of entrance.
  • § 14-4-108.  Suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of certificate; grounds; approval.
  • § 14-4-109.  Denial of certification; notice and hearing; appeal.
  • § 14-4-110.  Enjoining operations in violation.
  • § 14-4-111.  Penalty for uncertified operation.
  • § 14-4-112.  Contracts by department of family services.
  • § 14-4-113.  Commitment of uncontrollable child; refusal to receive.
  • § 14-4-114.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-4-115.  Authority of counties and municipalities to have detention homes.
  • § 14-4-116.  Mandatory immunizations for children attending child caring facilities.
  • § 14-4-117.  Juvenile detention facilities standards; definitions; report.

§ 14-4-101. Definitions.

  1. As used in W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-115 :
    1. “Applicant” means any person making formal application to the certifying authority for certification to operate a child caring agency in the state of Wyoming;
    2. “Board” means the certification board;
    3. “Board of review” means the “certification board” sitting as a board of review;
    4. “Certified agency” means any person certified to do business under the provisions of W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 ;
    5. “Certifying authority” means the department of family services operating as the agency which issues certificates, makes inspections, enforces standards and handles all administrative details relating to enforcement of W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 ;
    6. “Child caring facility” means any person who operates a business to keep or care for any minor at the request of the parents, legal guardians or an agency which is responsible for the child and includes any of the following privately operated facilities:
      1. Children’s institutions;
      2. Child placing agencies whether for permanent or temporary placement;
      3. Foster homes not supervised by the state, any local government, school district or agency or political subdivision thereof;
      4. Group day care agencies;
      5. Detention homes;
      6. Public or private receiving homes;
      7. Correctional schools;
      8. Repealed by Laws 2013, ch. 193 § 2.
      9. Ranches for children whether for summer operation only or otherwise;
      10. Day or hourly nurseries, nursery schools, kindergartens or any other preschool establishment not accredited by the state board of education;
      11. Boarding homes not supervised by the state, any local government, school district or agency or political subdivision thereof;
      12. Boards of cooperative educational services established under W.S. 21-20-104 and providing services to children with disabilities of any school district; and
      13. Except as provided under subparagraph (a)(vi)(N) of this section, any other person not legally related to a minor, having legal or physical care, custody or control of the child, receiving payment therefor and not supervised by the state, any local government, school district or agency or political subdivision thereof.
    7. “Person” shall mean any individual, partnership, association or corporation.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, §§ 1, 2; W.S. 1957, §§ 14-46.1, 14-46.2; Laws 1963, ch. 153, §§ 1-3; 1965, ch. 93, § 1; 1971, ch. 141, §§ 1, 2; W.S. 1977, §§ 14-3-206 , 14-3-207 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1991, ch. 161, § 3; 1994, ch. 34, § 1; 1997, Sp. Sess., ch. 3, § 501; 2012, ch. 84, § 103; 2013, ch. 193, § 2.

The 2012 amendment, effective July 1, 2012, substituted present (a)(vi)(H) for former (a)(vi)(H), which read: “Homes for defective children.”

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, repealed former (a)(vi)(H), which read: “Homes for children with developmental disabilities.”

Editor's notes. —

There is no subparagraph (a)(vi)(I) or (a)(vi)(L) or subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 14-4-102. Certification required; exceptions.

  1. All child caring facilities except those excluded in subsection (b) of this section, are required to be certified by the certifying authority before exercising care, custody or control of any minor.
  2. W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 do not apply to:
    1. A legal parent’s or legal relative’s care of a minor;
    2. Occasional care of a neighbor’s or friend’s child if the caretaking person does not regularly engage in this activity;
    3. Parents exchanging child care on a mutually cooperative basis;
    4. Child care by a person employed to come to the home of the child’s parent or guardian;
    5. Day-care agencies providing care for less than three (3) minors;
    6. Foster homes supervised by the state, any local government, school district or agency or political subdivision thereof;
    7. Ranches or farms not offering services to children who are homeless, delinquent or have an intellectual disability; and
    8. Summer camps operated by nonprofit organizations;
    9. Day-care facilities providing care to the children of only one (1) immediate family unit.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, §§ 2, 3; W.S. 1957, §§ 14-46.2, 14-46.3; Laws 1963, ch. 153, §§ 3, 4; 1965, ch. 93, §§ 1, 2; W.S. 1977, §§ 14-3-207 , 14-3-208 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1995, ch. 179, § 1; 2008, ch. 70, § 1.

The 2008 amendment, substituted “children who are homeless, delinquent or have an intellectual disability” for “homeless, delinquent or retarded children” in (b)(vii).

Laws 2008, ch. 70, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 7, 2008.

Applicability.

There was sufficient evidence for the district court to conclude that a cattle ranch offered services to children who were delinquent, and therefore it was a facility which was required to obtain certification pursuant to this section. Triangle Cross Ranch, Inc. v. State, 2015 WY 47, 345 P.3d 890, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 2015).

§ 14-4-103. Certification board; establishment; composition; appointment of lay members; duties.

  1. A certification board of not more than fifteen (15) members reflecting statewide representation is established and shall be composed of:
    1. One (1) representative from the department of family services;
    2. One (1) representative from the state department of education;
    3. Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 161, § 4.
    4. The state fire marshal or his designee;
    5. Six (6) lay members who are residents of the state and operators of child caring facilities or parents;
    6. Not more than four (4) additional lay members with an interest in child care;
    7. One (1) representative from the state department of agriculture or other state or local agency which may be responsible for sanitation inspections of child care facilities; and
    8. One (1) representative from the state department of health.
  2. The lay members shall be appointed by the governor for terms of two (2) years and may be removed by the governor as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . Any vacancies among the lay members shall be filled by gubernatorial appointment.
  3. The board shall:
    1. Designate investigators to investigate any child caring facility within the provisions of W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 ;
    2. Act as the board of review; and
    3. Act as an advisor to the state in all matters pertaining to child care programs and child care facility licensing.
  4. When the board is acting as a board of review pursuant to paragraph (c)(ii) of this section, the chairman of the board may designate, on a case by case basis, a committee of the board made up of at least three (3) disinterested members of the board to hear the case and recommend a decision on behalf of the board.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 4; W.S. 1957, § 14-46.4; Laws 1963, ch. 153, § 5; 1969, ch. 110, § 1; 1971, ch. 141, §§ 3, 4; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-209 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1987, ch. 175, § 1; 1991, ch. 161, §§ 3, 4; 1995, ch. 179, § 1; 1999, ch. 118, § 1.

§ 14-4-104. Certification; application; standards; notification to certify or refuse; term.

  1. Application for certification of a child caring facility within W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 shall be made to the certifying authority.
  2. A certificate shall be issued upon compliance with the following standards:
    1. Good moral character of the applicant, his employees and any other person having direct contact with a child under the care, custody or control of the applicant;
    2. Practical experience, education or training of the applicant in child care and treatment;
    3. Uncrowded, safe, sanitary and well repaired facilities; and
    4. Wholesome food prepared in a clean and healthy environment.
  3. The certifying authority shall notify the applicant of its decision to certify or refuse certification of the applicant within thirty (30) days after the application has been filed.
  4. All full certificates are nontransferable. Duration of the certificate shall be determined pursuant to rules and regulations of the department, subject to an annual continuation fee.
  5. The department is authorized to establish pursuant to rules and regulations full and provisional certificate fees and fees for continuation of a full certificate. Fees for continuation of a full certificate shall be due on the anniversary date of the original certificate. Fees collected by the department under this section shall be deposited in the general fund to offset the cost of administration of the board.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, §§ 4, 5; W.S. 1957, §§ 14-46.4, 14-46.5; Laws 1963, ch. 153, §§ 5, 6; 1965, ch. 93, § 3; 1969, ch. 110, § 1; 1971, ch. 141, §§ 3-6; W.S. 1977, §§ 14-3-209 , 14-3-210 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1995, ch. 179, § 1; 1999, ch. 118, § 1; 2010, ch. 69, § 203.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, in (e), deleted the former last sentence, which read: “For the balance of the biennium that began July 1, 1998, the governor may add the fees collected under this section to the department's budget through the B-11 process.”

§ 14-4-105. Provisional certificate.

The certifying authority may issue a provisional certificate if a substandard child caring agency is attempting to meet the standards or to comply with the rules and regulations pursuant to W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 . A provisional certificate is effective for a period of not more than six (6) months and is nonrenewable.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 6; W.S. 1957, § 14-46.6; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-211 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

§ 14-4-106. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1995, ch. 179, § 2.

Cross references. —

For present provisions relating to child care certificate renewal, see § 14-4-104(d) and (e).

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 7, related to child care certificate renewal, time, and expiration.

§ 14-4-107. Inspection by certifying board; right of entrance.

  1. The certifying board shall periodically and at reasonable times inspect, investigate and examine all certified agencies and applicants for certification.
  2. Any certified agency or applicant for certification shall give right of entrance and inspection of the facility to inspectors authorized by the certifying board. Any certified agency or applicant who denies admission to any authorized inspector shall have the certificate revoked or application denied.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 8; W.S. 1957, § 14-46.8; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-213 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

§ 14-4-108. Suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of certificate; grounds; approval.

  1. Any certificate made or issued pursuant to W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 may be suspended, nonrenewed or revoked by the certifying authority upon proof of violation of any provision within W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 .
  2. Thirty (30) days prior to initiating suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of any certificate made or issued pursuant to W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 , the certifying authority shall give written notice to the certified agency of the alleged facts warranting the intended action and provide the certified agency an opportunity to request a hearing with the board of review within ten (10) days of the receipt of notice. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.
  3. Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, if the certifying authority finds the life, health or safety of a child is in imminent danger, the certifying authority may immediately temporarily suspend certification of the agency pending hearing.
  4. The certified agency may appeal to the district court for review of any adverse decision of the board of review as provided by the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 9; W.S. 1957, § 14-46.9; Laws 1963, ch. 153, § 7; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-214 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1991, ch. 213, § 1.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See §§ 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

§ 14-4-109. Denial of certification; notice and hearing; appeal.

  1. Upon receiving a notice of denial of certification, any applicant may request a hearing with the board of review by serving proper notice to the certifying authority. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.
  2. Any applicant may appeal to the district court for review of the decision of the board of review as provided by the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, §§ 10, 11; W.S. 1957, §§ 14-46.10, 14-46.11; Laws 1963, ch. 153, § 8; W.S. 1977, §§ 14-3-215 , 14-3-216 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1991, ch. 213, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to judicial review of administrative action, see Rule 12, W.R.A.P.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

§ 14-4-110. Enjoining operations in violation.

Any person may be enjoined from operating a child caring facility for violating any provision within W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 .

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 12; W.S. 1957, § 14-46.12; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-217; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

Cross references. —

For procedure relating to injunctions, see Rule 65, W.R.C.P.

§ 14-4-111. Penalty for uncertified operation.

Any child caring facility operating without certification under W.S. 14-4-101 through 14-4-111 is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. Each day of operation without certification is a separate offense.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 135, § 13; W.S. 1957, § 14-46.13; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-218; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

§ 14-4-112. Contracts by department of family services.

The department of family services is authorized to contract with any lawful authority of any child caring facility for the care and custody of Wyoming children which have been placed therein by court order under the Juvenile Justice Act or otherwise. The department shall select those child caring facilities requiring the least expense to the state for the care and custody of children.

History. Laws 1884, ch. 53, § 5; R.S. 1887, § 2336; R.S. 1899, § 4934; C.S. 1910, § 3131; C.S. 1920, § 3898; R.S. 1931, § 20-705; C.S. 1945, § 58-605; W.S. 1957, § 14-39; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-203 ; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 1991, ch. 161, § 3; 2019, ch. 186, § 1.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, substituted “Juvenile Justice Act” for “Juvenile Court Act.”

§ 14-4-113. Commitment of uncontrollable child; refusal to receive.

  1. If a child is committed to a child caring facility by a court under the Juvenile Justice Act or otherwise and the child caring facility cannot exercise proper control over the child, the child caring facility may report the facts to the court with jurisdiction for a reconsideration or rehearing on the order. If the facts warrant, the child shall then be committed to the Wyoming boys’ school, the Wyoming girls’ school, or such other privately or publicly operated facility as the court deems appropriate.
  2. If a child caring facility refuses to receive a child under court order, then the court of competent jurisdiction shall provide for placement under other provisions of law.

History. Laws 1907, ch. 60, § 3; C.S. 1910, § 3125; C.S. 1920, § 3892; R.S. 1931, § 20-604; C.S. 1945, § 58-615; W.S. 1957, § 14-49; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-220; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2019, ch. 186, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to establishment of Wyoming boys' school and Wyoming girls' school, see § 25-1-201 .

The 2004 amendment, in (a), substituted “Wyoming boys' school” for “industrial institute.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in (a), substituted “Juvenile Justice Act” for “Juvenile Court Act.”

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

§ 14-4-114. [Repealed.]

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1907, ch. 60, § 4, related to state payments to a child care facility receiving a child under court order.

§ 14-4-115. Authority of counties and municipalities to have detention homes.

The board of county commissioners of any county or the governing body of any municipal corporation may acquire and maintain a detention home for care of delinquent minors, provided the detention home is not used for any other purpose.

History. Laws 1945, ch. 90, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 58-618; W.S. 1957, § 14-52; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-223; Laws 1978, ch. 25, § 1.

§ 14-4-116. Mandatory immunizations for children attending child caring facilities.

  1. As used in this section “child caring facility” means a facility required to be certified under W.S. 14-4-102 .
  2. All persons over eighteen (18) months old attending or transferring into a child caring facility are required to be completely immunized in a similar manner to W.S. 21-4-309 .
  3. The operator of the child caring facility shall be responsible for an audit of the immunization status of any child attending the child caring facility in a similar manner to W.S. 21-4-309 .

History. Laws 1979, ch. 23, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 14-3-224.

Editor's notes. —

This section was enacted as § 14-3-224 but has been renumbered in accordance with the 1978 revision of this title.

§ 14-4-117. Juvenile detention facilities standards; definitions; report.

  1. Sheriffs, in consultation with other operators of juvenile detention facilities, shall develop and implement uniform standards after consideration of nationally recognized criteria for the operation of all hardware secure and staff secure juvenile detention facilities.
  2. No minor shall be detained in a hardware secure or staff secure juvenile detention facility unless the facility has adopted the standards specified under subsection (a) of this section.
  3. The sheriffs shall report to the joint judiciary interim committee by November 15, 2012 with respect to their progress in developing and implementing the standards specified under subsection (a) of this section.
  4. As used in this section:
    1. “Hardware secure juvenile detention facility” means a facility used for the detention of minors that is characterized by locks on the doors and other restrictive hardware designed to restrict the movement of the minors and protect public safety;
    2. “Staff secure juvenile detention facility” means a facility used for the detention of minors that is characterized by a trained staff to supervise the movement and activities of detained minors at the facility, without the additional use of hardware secure equipment.
  5. Nothing in this section shall apply to the Wyoming boys’ school or the Wyoming girls’ school.

History. Laws 2010, ch. 21, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2010, ch. 21, § 2, effective July 1, 2010, provides: “(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this act, this act is effective March 31, 2013.

“(b) W.S. 14-4-117(a), created by section 1 of this act, is effective July 1, 2010.”

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 4, amends Laws 2010, ch. 21, § 2, to read: “(b) W.S. 14-4-117(a) and (c), created by section 1 of this act, is effective July 1, 2010.”

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6(b), makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

Article 2. Quality Child Care

  • § 14-4-201.  Quality child care system established.
  • §§ 14-4-202 and 14-4-203.  [Repealed.]
  • § 14-4-204.  Educational development scholarships and continuing education grants.
  • § 14-4-205.  Technical assistance and business management assistance; quality support; family strengthening program.
  • § 14-4-206.  Parental education and public awareness.
  • § 14-4-207.  Reporting requirements.

Appropriations. —

Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 4 (a) appropriates seven million three hundred eighty-one thousand four hundred seventy-three dollars ($7,381,473.00) from the general fund to the department of workforce services for the purposes of the act, with the proviso under subsection (c) that of the general fund appropriation in subsection (a) six million dollars ($6,000,000.00) shall only be expended after further legislative action by the 59th Legislature, and also that the department shall not enter into any contract obligating any of these funds under W.S 14-4-201 , 14-4-203, 14-4-204 or 14-4-205 created by the act without future legislative action.

Effective dates. —

Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 5, makes the act generally effective July 1, 2006.

Annual Report. —

Laws 2006, Ch. 64, § 3 provides:

  1. The department of family services shall report annually to the joint education interim committee, the joint labor, health and social services interim committee and the joint appropriations interim committee by October 1 and to the oversight committee created in Section 2 of this act quarterly. The report shall include:
    1. The department's progress in establishing the system under this act;
    2. The participating child care facilities and their ratings;
    3. Information that demonstrates the impacts of the services provided by the system on children, families and communities and how the department plans to measure these impacts;
    4. Public awareness activities;
    5. The collaborative efforts of the departments of education, family services, health, workforce services and others to provide comprehensive early childhood development and preschool experiences for children while meeting the needs of Wyoming's workforce and economic development;
    6. System expenditures of public and private funds; and
    7. Recommendations for changes in the system's operation.

      Legislative Oversight Committee. —

      Laws 2006, Ch. 64, § 2 provides:

  2. There is created a legislative oversight committee to oversee the progress of the department on implementing the provisions of this act. The committee shall consist of:
    1. Four (4) members of the joint appropriations committee. The members shall be appointed by the cochairmen of the joint appropriations committee, who shall also appoint a co-chairman of the committee;
    2. Four (4) members of the joint labor, health and social services interim committee. The members shall be appointed by the co-chairmen of the joint labor, health and social services interim committee, who shall also appoint a co-chairman of the committee.
  3. The oversight committee shall provide oversight of the department's work toward implementing the quality child care program provided under this act.
  4. The oversight committee shall meet at least quarterly to receive progress reports from the department and consider future legislation necessary to facilitate speedy implementation of the quality child care program provided under this act. The department shall recommend to the committee specific and readily calculable formulae for expenditures under this act, including but not limited to the monthly quality incentive payments to eligible quality child care facilities.
  5. The oversight committee shall report its findings and recommendations to the joint appropriations committee and the joint labor, health and human services interim committee no later than November 15, 2006.
  6. There is appropriated to the legislative service office sixteen thousand dollars ($16,000.00) for funding the oversight committee under this section for the period from April 1, 2006 through June 30, 2007.

§ 14-4-201. Quality child care system established.

  1. A quality child care system is created for the purpose of assisting the working families of the state by encouraging the availability of high quality care for children in licensed child caring facilities. The system may consist of:
    1. A quality rating system;
    2. Incentive payments for higher levels of quality care;
    3. Grants for professional educational development;
    4. Technical assistance, business management services and family strengthening programs.
  2. The quality child care system shall also provide for a parental education and public awareness program.
  3. The department of workforce services is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations for the purpose of implementing all or any portion of this article. All rules and regulations shall be promulgated in consultation with the department of education, the department of family services, the department of health, University of Wyoming and early childhood specialists from the private sector.
  4. The state’s responsibility for payments under this article shall be limited to the amount of funding provided for the quality child care system by the legislature. The department may receive donations from foundations or other private sources. Any such funds received shall be deposited into a separate account and are continuously appropriated to the department, which may distribute those funds in accordance with the provisions of this article. Services eligible to be paid for by another public program shall not be reimbursed under this article.
  5. Infants and preschool children served under this article who qualify for disability services shall receive those services through a regional developmental preschool that is supported by state funding for this purpose, provided the parents or caretakers agree to those services. The cost of these services shall not be reimbursed by payments made to providers under this article.
  6. In the delivery of services, facilities that receive funds under this article shall not discriminate against any individual on the basis of sex, color, race, religion, national origin, disability or age other than the age of the qualifying child. Notwithstanding this subsection, facilities shall retain the ability to refer children with developmental disabilities to appropriate services.
  7. Upon approval of the application for funds as provided in this article, the facility shall enter into a contract with the state, wherein the facility shall agree:
    1. To provide child care services in this state for a minimum of one (1) year;
    2. To serve children from families eligible for support for child care under programs, other than the program created by this article, managed by the department of family services;
    3. To submit the reports required by W.S. 14-4-203(d) and to submit information as required in the department’s rules and regulations; and
    4. To immediately repay all funds provided to the facility pursuant to this article, attorney fees and costs incurred in collection, if the facility breaches the contract during the one (1) year period.
  8. The department of workforce services shall structure its contracts with facilities to ensure necessary data is reported uniformly. The contracts shall specify what services will be provided under the contract and the outcome measures to be achieved to allow the department to determine compliance with contract provisions, the services provided, the outcomes achieved and to determine the extent of statewide needs based on the reports received.
  9. Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 3.
  10. The department, in rating facilities for quality and making payments to facilities pursuant to this article, shall not discriminate against any facility due to religious orientation, affiliation or instruction or the lack thereof. No state funds shall be used for materials for religious instruction, salaries and benefits for staff primarily engaged in religious instruction, or for any other incremental cost of religious instruction or observances. Any facility receiving state funds shall be prepared to demonstrate, if audited, that sufficient nongovernmental funds were available to cover all expenses of religious instruction or observance.
  11. For purposes of this article:
    1. “Department” means the department of workforce services;
    2. “Facility” means child caring facility as defined in W.S. 14-4-101(a)(vi)(D) and (K);
    3. Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 3.

History. Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 1; 2007, ch. 156, §§ 2, 3.

Cross References. —

As to Child Care Facilities Act, see § 14-4-101 et seq. As to Child Protection Act, see § 14-3-401 et seq.

The 2007 amendment, in (a), substituted “assisting the working families of the state by encouraging the availability of high quality care for children” for “supplementing high quality care to children,” and substituted “The system may consist” for “consisting” in the last sentence of the introductory language, substituted “Grants for professional-educational” for “Scholarships for professional-educational” in (iii), substituted “business management services and family strengthening programs” for “and quality support” in (iv); inserted “all or any portion of” in (c); substituted “children with developmental disabilities to appropriate services” for “developmentally disabled children to regional developmental preschools supported by state funding” in (f); inserted “of family services” in (g)(ii); repealed former (m)(iii), which read: “Task force” means a joint task force of employees of the department of workforce services and department of family services appointed by the governor”; repealed former (j), which read: “The task force created pursuant to paragraph (m)(iii) of this section shall develop an outcomes measurement and data infrastructure system for purposes of performance measurement and quality improvement of services provided by facilities under contract with the department to address statewide planning for quality improvement and increased availability of child care facilities”; and made related changes.

Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 1, 2007.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) or (l) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Appropriations. —

Laws 2007, ch.157, §§ 1 and 2 state as follows:

“Section 1.

(a) For the fiscal biennium ending June 30, 2008, one million five hundred fifty-three thousand dollars ($1,553,000.00) of funds remaining from the appropriation made in 2006 Wyoming Session Laws, Chapter 64, Section 4 for the purpose of funding a quality child care program pursuant to W.S. 14-4-201 et seq., is hereby reappropriated to the department of workforce services for the following purposes:

  1. Educational grants pursuant to W.S. 14-4-204(a) – three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00);
  2. Continuing education training grants pursuant to W.S. 14-4-204(c) – three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00);
  3. Business management services pursuant to W.S. 14-4-205(b) – one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00);
  4. Parent education and public awareness programs pursuant to W.S. 14-4-206 – five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00);
  5. Technical assistance pursuant to W.S. 14-4-205(b) – one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00);
  6. Family strengthening programs pursuant to W.S. 14-4-205(c) – one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); and
  7. Administrative costs – one hundred fifty-three thousand dollars ($153,000.00). Section 2. For the fiscal biennium ending June 30, 2008, four million five hundred thirty-four thousand three hundred eight dollars ($4,534,308.00) of funds remaining from the appropriation made in 2006 Wyoming Session Laws, Chapter 64, Section 4 for the purpose of funding a quality child care program pursuant to W.S. 14-4-201 et seq., is hereby reappropriated to the department of family services to increase the reimbursement for child care under the Child Care Development Fund 45 C.F.R. 98 to the seventy-fifth percentile of the statewide average market rate and to provide an additional one dollar and forty cents ($1.40) per hour of reimbursement for the care of children less than one (1) year of age and an additional one dollar ($1.00) per hour of reimbursement for care of children one (1) year of age but less than two (2) years of age. All increases apply for qualifying families beginning July 1, 2007.” Effective dates. — Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 5, makes subsections (a), (b), and (c) effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become a law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Approved March 21, 2006.

§§ 14-4-202 and 14-4-203. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

These sections, which derived from Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 1, related to quality rating system.

§ 14-4-204. Educational development scholarships and continuing education grants.

  1. The department by rule and regulation shall provide educational development scholarships to assist the owners or staff of child caring facilities to attain certificates or degrees in early childhood development or a related field. Payments under this subsection shall be conditioned upon the recipient of the educational development scholarship entering into a contract to work for a child caring facility in this state for a period as provided in subsection (d) of this section after receiving the certificate or degree.
    1. and (ii) Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 3.
  2. A recipient of an educational development scholarship pursuant to this section who breaches the contract required by subsection (a) of this section shall repay that portion of funds provided to the recipient pursuant to this article that is for educational developmental expenses accruing during or after the semester in which the recipient breached the contract, together with attorney fees and costs incurred in collection.
  3. The department by rule and regulation shall provide continuing education grants to child caring facilities to assist the owners or staff of those facilities to obtain continuing education training in early childhood development or related topics. Payments under this subsection shall be conditioned on the following:
    1. The recipient of the continuing education training provided through the grant entering into a contract to work for a child caring facility in this state for a period as provided in subsection (d) of this section after receiving the training; and
    2. An in-cash cost sharing contribution of at least ten percent (10%) from the facility employing the staff member at the time of continuing education training.
  4. The department shall set a formula for duration of contractual commitments under this section through rule and regulation. Commitment duration shall be based on the value of the educational opportunity and shall be commensurate with the magnitude of the grant.
  5. A recipient of a continuing education grant pursuant to this section shall repay all funds provided to the recipient pursuant to the grant, together with attorney fees and costs incurred in collection, if the recipient breaches the contract required by subsection (c) of this section.

History. Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 1; 2007, ch. 156, §§ 2, 3; 2008, ch. 82, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, added (c) and (d); rewrote (a) and (b), regarding the purpose and conditions of educational development grants; repealed former (a)(i) through (a)(ii), regarding the staff member wages and benefits; and made stylistic changes.

Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 1, 2007.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, in (a), twice substituted references to grants with references to development scholarships; in (a) and (c)(i) substituted “contract” for “written agreement”; rewrote (b); in (c), substituted “continuing education” for “staff development”; and added (e).

§ 14-4-205. Technical assistance and business management assistance; quality support; family strengthening program.

  1. Quality support payments may be made available to facilities through a competitive process to provide quality care for infants or other children whose care may otherwise be difficult to obtain in the community. Grants shall be awarded as follows:
    1. Repayment shall be required if the facility closes the business within one (1) year after receiving the grant or if the facility fails to comply with any provision of the grant;
    2. Grant requests for increasing capacity shall only be awarded to existing licensed facilities that are at a quality level of three (3) or higher in the quality rating system;
    3. Quality support grants shall not be used for capital construction or purchase of land or buildings;
    4. Grants to any one (1) facility shall not exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per child.
  2. The department shall provide technical assistance to facilities on best practices for quality operational improvements and business management services of child caring facilities.
  3. The department of health shall contract for delivery of voluntary family strengthening educational programs to promote family involvement in children’s development.

History. Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 1; 2007, ch. 156, § 2.

The 2007 amendment, in (b), deleted “department of family services and” preceding “department”, deleted “of workforce services” preceding “shall provide technical” and substituted “quality operational improvements and business management services” for “management”; and added (c).

Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 1, 2007.

§ 14-4-206. Parental education and public awareness.

  1. The department shall develop and distribute materials to:
    1. Promote knowledge of the quality child care system;
    2. Promote an understanding of the benefits that accrue to children, families and communities from quality child care programs, as based upon the latest findings in research reports and studies;
    3. Promote the advantages of parents personally providing care for their own children whenever possible;
    4. Promote parent involvement in their child’s development and provide information and activities to parents or caretakers to promote early childhood learning and development at home;
    5. Emphasize the importance of parental responsibility and the involvement of the family in quality early childhood development; and
    6. Inform parents about choices available in childcare programs and how to choose an appropriate child caring facility.

History. Laws 2006, ch. 64, § 1; 2007, ch. 156, § 2.

The 2007 amendment added (a)(vi).

Laws 2007, ch. 156, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 1, 2007.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 14-4-207. Reporting requirements.
